##  28 [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra ]  A diameter and breadth of one hundred thousand
yojanas, six hundred and twenty-six yojanas and one-eighth of a yojana, A
circumference of three hundred thousand yojanas, eighteen thousand yojanas and
two hundred and seventy-nine yojanas, This is the measure of the day, eighteen
muhurtas less two one-eighth muhurtas, twelve muhurtas is the day, two one-
eighth muhurtas is the night. 2. When the sun enters, it moves in a circle
outside the outermost circle, and when the sun moves in a circle outside the
outermost circle, then the measure of that circle is eighty-four yojanas and
one-eighth of a yojana, A diameter and breadth of one hundred thousand yojanas,
six hundred and eighty-two yojanas and fifty-two yojanas and one-eighth of a
yojana, A circumference of three hundred thousand yojanas, eighteen thousand
yojanas and two hundred and ninety-nine yojanas, This is the measure of the day,
eighteen muhurtas less four one-eighth muhurtas, twelve muhurtas is the day,
four one-eighth muhurtas is the night. Thus, when the sun enters, it moves from
one circle to another, and as it moves from one circle to another, it increases
in diameter and breadth by five yojanas and thirty-five one-eighth yojanas, and
as it moves from one circle to another, it increases in circumference by
eighteen yojanas, and as it moves from one circle to another, it moves in a
circle outside the outermost circle, When the sun moves in a circle outside the
outermost circle, then the measure of that circle is eighty-four yojanas and
one-eighth of a yojana, a diameter and breadth of nine thousand nine hundred and
sixty-four yojanas, A circumference of three hundred thousand yojanas, fifteen
thousand yojanas and one hundred and ninety-nine yojanas, a little more than
that, This is the measure of the day, eighteen muhurtas is the day, twelve
muhurtas is the night, This is the measure of the six months, this is the
measure of the end of the six months, this is the measure of the year, this is
the measure of the end of the year.

[First Prabhrita - Eighth Prabhrita Prabhrita] The outer diameter of all the
celestial spheres is half the measure. All the celestial spheres have a diameter
of 42,000 yojanas, [29 All the celestial spheres have a diameter of two yojanas,
This half is equal to 55 yojanas, So, what is the distance between the inner and
outer celestial spheres? It is 55 yojanas. What is the distance between the
inner and outer celestial spheres? It is 55 yojanas and 1/2 yojana. What is the
distance between the inner and outer celestial spheres? It is 59 yojanas and
13/2 yojanas. What is the distance between the inner and outer celestial
spheres? It is 55 yojanas.

## Suraṇ Teriṣṣagāī ## Second Prābhṛta [First Prābhṛta]  21. "How then is the
Teriṣṣagāī?" Thus it is asked. There, indeed, these eight interpretations are
established, as follows: There, they said thus:  1. "From the eastern horizon,
the rays of the Marīcī rise in the sky, it makes this world slant, having made
it, it sets in the western horizon in the evening in the sky." Thus some said.
Some, however, said thus:  2. "From the eastern horizon, the Sun rises in the
sky, it makes this world slant, having made it, it sets in the western horizon
in the evening." Thus some said. Some, however, said thus:  3. "From the eastern
horizon, the Sun rises in the sky, it makes this world slant, having made it, it
enters the sky in the evening, having entered, it goes to sleep, having gone to
sleep, it rises again from the lower eastern horizon in the sky." Thus some
said. Some, however, said thus:  4. "From the eastern horizon, the Sun rises
from the earth, it makes this world slant, having made it, it sets in the
western horizon in the evening." Thus some said. Some, however, said thus:  5.
"From the eastern horizon, the Sun rises from the earth, it makes this world
slant, having made it, it enters the earth in the evening, having entered, it
goes to sleep, having gone to sleep, it rises again from the lower eastern
horizon." Thus some said. Some, however, said thus:

| Romanization (original text) |
======================

## Second Prabhruta - First Prabhruta Prabhruta  6. Some say that the sun rises
in the east, then traverses this world horizontally, and sets in the west.  [31
Some others say - 7. The sun rises in the east, then traverses this world
horizontally, then sets in the west, then enters (the earth), then descends,
then again rises in the east. Some say this. Some others say - 8. The sun rises
far away in the east, many yojanas, many yojana-hundreds, many yojana-thousands
high, then traverses this southern hemisphere horizontally, then sets in the
northern hemisphere, then traverses this northern hemisphere horizontally, then
sets in the southern hemisphere, then traverses these southern and northern
hemispheres horizontally, then rises far away in the east, many yojanas, many
yojana-hundreds, many yojana-thousands high. Some say this.  We, however, say
this: The two suns rise in the sky, eight yojana-hundreds high, in the regions
of the earth, which are very worthy of being remembered, in the four-part
mandala, which is the southern, eastern, northern, and western part of the
Jambudvipa island, which is the living mandala of the four directions, the
north, south, east, and west.  Then they traverse these southern and northern
parts of Jambudvipa horizontally, then set in the eastern and western parts of
Jambudvipa.  Then they traverse these eastern and western parts of Jambudvipa
horizontally, then set in the southern and northern parts of Jambudvipa.  They
traverse these southern and northern, eastern and western parts of Jambudvipa
horizontally, then rise in the sky in the regions of the earth, which are very
worthy of being remembered, in the four-part mandala, which is the southern,
eastern, northern, and western part of the Jambudvipa island, which is the
living mandala of the four directions, the north, south, east, and west.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |

paccatthimAiM jaMbuddIvabhAgAiM tiriyaM kareMti, kareMtittA jaMbuddIvassa

Page #83 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):

## Second Chapter [Second Chapter] The Sun's Transition from one Mandala to
another  22. How does the Sun move from one Mandala to another? There are two
different opinions on this, as follows:  1. Some say that the Sun moves from one
Mandala to another by breaking through (**bhedha**). 2. Others say that the Sun
moves from one Mandala to another by leaving a hole (**kannakala**).  Those who
say that the Sun moves from one Mandala to another by breaking through
(**bhedha**) have this fault:  "If the Sun moves from one Mandala to another by
breaking through (**bhedha**), then it does not fully enter the other Mandala.
It would only partially enter the other Mandala and would not be able to
complete its cycle."  Those who say that the Sun moves from one Mandala to
another by leaving a hole (**kannakala**) have this fault:  "If the Sun moves
from one Mandala to another by leaving a hole (**kannakala**), then it would not
be able to move from one Mandala to another. It would be stuck in the hole."
Therefore, the Sun moves from one Mandala to another by breaking through
(**bhedha**). The **bhedha** is the space between the two Mandalas. The Sun
moves through this space and enters the other Mandala. Once it enters the other
Mandala, it continues to move within it.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 dvitIya prAbhRta [dvitIya prAbhRtaprAbhRta] sUrassa maMDalAo maMDalAMtara-
saMkamaNaM 22. tA kahaM te maMDalAo maMDalaM saMkamamANe saMkamamANe sUrie cAraM

## Second Prabhrita - Second Prabhrita Prabhrita ] 2. When the Sun transits from
one mandala to another, it detaches the *kanna-kala* (ear-point). However, it
does not go completely through it in half the time. When it goes completely
through it, it does not leave the mandala-kala. This is the special feature of
it. There, those who said this - "When the Sun transits from one mandala to
another, it detaches the *kanna-kala* (ear-point) at that particular place, and
not by this means," The Sun, desiring to transit from one mandala to another,
detaches the *kanna-kala* (ear-point) of the next mandala from the first moment
onwards. This is the contemplation here - "Like Bharat or Airavata, the Sun,
having risen in its own place, aims at the *kanna* (ear-point) of the next
mandala, which is the first koti-bhaga (part), and gradually detaches the next
mandala with that particular *kala* (time), and moves in that way." By which,
when that day and night have passed, it is present at the beginning of the next
mandala. The *kanna-kala* (ear-point) should be understood as a specific action,
and it should be contemplated in this way - "The Sun detaches the next mandala,
aiming at the *kanna* (ear-point), which is the first koti-bhaga (part) of the
next mandala, from the first moment onwards, moment by moment, as it is crossed
by the *kala* (time)." - Surya. Tika.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 dvitIya prAbhRta - dvitIya prAbhRtaprAbhRta ] 2. tA maMDalAo maMDalaM
saMkamamANe sUrie kaNNakalaM' nivveDhei, evaiyaM ca NaM addhaM purao na gacchai,
purao gacchamANe maMDalakAlaM na parihavei, tesi NaM ayaM visese| tattha NaM je
te evamAhaMsu - maMDalAo maMDalaM saMkamamANe sUrie kaNNakalaM nivveDhei eeNaM
ThAeNaM NeyavvaM, No ceva NaM iyareNaM, maNDalAnmaNDalaM saMkrAman
saMkramitumicchan sUryastadadhikRtaM maMDalama prathamakSaNAdRrdhvamArabhya
karNa-kalaM nirveSTayati muMcati, iyamatra bhAvanA-'bhArata airAvato vA sUryaH

## Second Chapter  **[Third Chapter]** The measure of the Sun's movement in a
Muhurta.  23. What is the distance the Sun travels in one Muhurta? The learned
ones say: There are four different opinions on this matter, as follows:  (1)
Some say that the Sun travels six thousand Yojanas in one Muhurta.  (2) Some say
that the Sun travels five thousand Yojanas in one Muhurta.  (3) Some say that
the Sun travels four thousand Yojanas in one Muhurta.  (4) Some say that the Sun
travels six, five, or four thousand Yojanas in one Muhurta.  Now, those who say
that the Sun travels six thousand Yojanas in one Muhurta, say:  When the Sun
travels the entire inner circle, it takes eighteen Muhurtas for the day and
twelve Muhurtas for the night. In this case, the distance traveled in one day is
one hundred thousand Yojanas plus eight thousand Yojanas.  When the Sun travels
the entire outer circle, it takes eighteen Muhurtas for the night and twelve
Muhurtas for the day.  In this case, the distance traveled in one day is eight
thousand Yojanas. Therefore, the Sun travels six thousand Yojanas in one
Muhurta.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 dvitIya prAbhRta _ [tRtIya prAbhRtaprAbhRta] sUrassa muhutta-gai-pamANaM 23. tA
kevaiyaM te khettaM sUrie egamegeNaM muhutteNaM gacchai ? Ahie tti vejaa| tattha
khalu imAo cattAri paDivattIo paNNattAo, taM jahA - tatthege evamAhaMsu - (1) tA
cha cha joyaNasahassAI sUrie egamegeNaM muhutteNaM gacchai, ege evamAhaMsu - ege
puNa evamAhaMsu - (2) tA paMca paMca joyaNasahassAI sUrie egamegeNaM muhutteNaM
gacchai, ege evamAhaMsu - ege puNa evamAhaMsu - (3) tA cattAri cattAri
joyaNasahassAiM sUrie egamegeNaM muhutteNaM gacchai, ege evamAhaMsu - ege puNa

## Second Praabhrut - Third Praabhrut Praabhrut  [ 35 There, those who said -
(2) The sun travels five five yojana-sahasras in one muhurta, they said - Those
who said the sun travels in the inner circle, for them, the day is eighteen
muhurtas, when the night is twelve muhurtas, due to the rising of the sun at the
highest point. In that, the distance travelled in a day is nine yojana-sahasras.
Those who said the sun travels in the outer circle, for them, the night is
eighteen muhurtas, when the day is twelve muhurtas, due to the setting of the
sun at the highest point. In that, the distance travelled in a day is sixteen
yojana-sahasras. Therefore, the sun travels five five yojana-sahasras in one
muhurta. There, those who said - (3) The sun travels four four yojana-sahasras
in one muhurta, they said - Those who said the sun travels in the inner circle,
for them, the day is eighteen muhurtas, when the night is twelve muhurtas, due
to the rising of the sun at the highest point. In that, the distance travelled
in a day is seventy-two yojana-sahasras. Those who said the sun travels in the
outer circle, for them, the night is eighteen muhurtas, when the day is twelve
muhurtas, due to the setting of the sun at the highest point. In that, the
distance travelled in a day is sixty-nine yojana-sahasras. Therefore, the sun
travels four four yojana-sahasras in one muhurta. There, those who said - (4)
The sun travels six, five, or four yojana-sahasras in one muhurta, they said -
The sun travels six six yojana-sahasras in one muhurta, when it rises and sets
quickly. The sun travels five five yojana-sahasras in one muhurta, when it
travels at an average speed, in the middle of the distance. The sun travels four
four yojana-sahasras in one muhurta, when it travels slowly, at the end of the
middle distance. Those who said the sun travels in the inner circle, for them,
the day is eighteen muhurtas, when the night is twelve muhurtas, due to the
rising of the sun at the highest point.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

##  36 [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra ]  A day with eighteen muhurtas is when there are
twelve muhurtas of night. In such a day, the distance traveled by the sun is set
at one thousand and one yojanas. _When the sun travels in the outer circle, then
the day with eighteen muhurtas is when there are twelve muhurtas of night. In
such a day, the distance traveled by the sun is set at one thousand and one
yojanas. Some say that the sun travels one thousand yojanas, five thousand
yojanas, or four thousand yojanas in one muhurta. We, however, say that the sun
travels five thousand yojanas in one muhurta. _Question: What is the size of
Jambudvipa? Answer: Jambudvipa is a circular island with a diameter of one
hundred thousand yojanas, and it is surrounded by the ocean. It is three
thousand yojanas wide, two hundred and twenty-seven yojanas long, and three
kosas deep. It is also eight hundred dhanus wide, thirteen angulas deep, and a
little more than half an angula deep. When the sun travels in the outer circle,
it travels five thousand yojanas, two hundred and eleven yojanas, and thirty-six
yojanas in one muhurta. The sun appears to a human being on earth at a distance
of seventy-two thousand yojanas, two hundred yojanas, and twenty-one yojanas.
When the sun travels in the outer circle, then the day with eighteen muhurtas is
when there are twelve muhurtas of night. When the sun is setting, it travels in
the inner circle during the first day and night of the new year. When the sun
travels in the inner circle, it travels five thousand yojanas, two hundred and
eleven yojanas, and seventy-two yojanas in one muhurta. The sun appears to a
human being on earth at a distance of seventy-two thousand yojanas, one hundred
and seventy-seven yojanas, and sixty yojanas. It is also one-sixth of a yojana,
one-twenty-second of a yojana, and one-twenty-fourth of a yojana. When the sun
travels in the inner circle, then the day with eighteen muhurtas is when there
are twelve muhurtas of night. When the sun is setting, it travels in the inner
circle during the second day and night of the new year.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

pnnnntte| _tA jayA NaM sUrie savvabAhiraM maMDalaM uvasaMkamittA cAraM carai,

## Second Prabhruta - Third Prabhruta Prabhruta  [ 37 _When the Sun travels
within the innermost circle, it travels five thousand yojanas, two hundred and
fifty-two yojanas, and sixty parts of a yojana in each muhurta. For a human
being on Earth, the Sun's apparent diameter is sixty thousand yojanas, sixty-six
yojanas, thirty-three parts of a yojana, and sixty parts of a yojana, all
combined, and this is equal to two parts of a chuniya. Thus, there are eighteen
muhurtas in a day, minus four parts of a muhurta. There are twelve muhurtas in a
night, plus four parts of a muhurta. As the Sun moves outward, it travels from
one circle to the next, and in each muhurta, it travels eighteen parts of a
yojana. As it moves outward, the shadow of a man decreases by eighty-four
yojanas, and it continues to decrease until it reaches the outermost circle.
When the Sun travels within the outermost circle, it travels five thousand
yojanas, one hundred and fifty-three yojanas, and fifteen parts of a yojana in
each muhurta. For a human being on Earth, the Sun's apparent diameter is thirty-
one thousand yojanas, eighty-one thousand yojanas, thirty parts of a yojana, and
this is equal to sixty parts of a yojana. Thus, there are eighteen muhurtas in a
night, and twelve muhurtas in a day. This is the first six months, and this is
the end of the first six months. When the Sun enters the second six months, it
travels within the outermost circle in the first day and night. When the Sun
travels within the outermost circle, it travels five thousand yojanas, one
hundred and forty-seven yojanas, and fifty-seven parts of a yojana in each
muhurta. For a human being on Earth, the Sun's apparent diameter is thirty-one
thousand yojanas, one hundred and sixteen yojanas, forty-one parts of a yojana,
and sixty parts of a yojana, all combined, and this is equal to sixty parts of a
chuniya. Thus, there are eighteen muhurtas in a night, minus two parts of a
muhurta. There are twelve muhurtas in a day, plus two parts of a muhurta. When
the Sun enters the second six months, it travels within the innermost circle in
the first day and night. When the Sun travels within the innermost circle, it
travels five thousand yojanas,

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 dvitIya prAbhRta - tRtIya prAbhRtaprAbhRta ] [ 37 _tA jayA NaM sUrie abhiMtaraM
taccaM maMDalaM uvasaMkamittA cAraM carai, tayA NaM paMca paMca joyaNasahassAI
doNNi ya bAvaNNe joyaNasae paMca ya saTThibhAe joyaNassa egamegeNaM muhutteNaM
gcchi| tayA NaM ihagayassa maNUsassa sIolIsAe joyaNasahassehiM chaNNauIe ya

##  38 [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra ]  The sun travels one sixty-fourth of a yojana
in one muhurta, in the northern direction.  Therefore, for a human being on
earth, the sun's visual appearance (chakkhuphaasam) occurs after traveling
32,000 yojanas, minus one-fourth, plus sixty-fourths of a yojana, and twenty-
seven parts of a hundred.  Therefore, the day is eighteen muhurtas, minus one-
fourth of a muhurta, and the night is twelve muhurtas, minus one-fourth of a
muhurta.  Thus, as the sun enters the different mandalas (regions), it travels
from one mandala to the next, covering eighteen sixty-fourths of a yojana in
each mandala, in one muhurta. As it travels, it gradually increases its speed,
reaching a speed of eighty-five yojanas, and then gradually decreases its speed,
covering the entire mandala in four muhurtas.  When the sun covers the entire
mandala in four muhurtas, it travels five thousand yojanas, plus two hundred and
eighty-eight sixty-fourths of a yojana, in one muhurta.  Therefore, for a human
being on earth, the sun's visual appearance (chakkhuphaasam) occurs after
traveling 73,000 yojanas, plus two hundred and twenty-one sixty-fourths of a
yojana.  Therefore, the day is eighteen muhurtas, when the sun is at its highest
point (uttamakatthapatte), and the night is twelve muhurtas.  This is the
duration of the six months, and this is the duration of the six months of the
sun's journey. This is the duration of the year, and this is the duration of the
year of the sun's journey.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

The third Prabhrita, the field of the moon and sun's **Oobhas** (radiance), the
field of **Ujjoy** (illumination), the field of **Tav** (heat), and the field of
**Pagas** (light).  24. P. - What are the fields where the moon and sun
**Oobhas**, **Ujjoy**, **Tav**, and **Pagas**? Please tell me. U. - There are
twelve **Pativvatti** (interpretations) as follows:  1. Some say that the moon
and sun **Oobhas**, **Ujjoy**, **Tav**, and **Pagas** on one island and one
ocean. 2. Some say that the moon and sun **Oobhas**, **Ujjoy**, **Tav**, and
**Pagas** on three islands and three oceans. 3. Some say that the moon and sun
**Oobhas**, **Ujjoy**, **Tav**, and **Pagas** on half of four islands and half
of four oceans. 4. Some say that the moon and sun **Oobhas**, **Ujjoy**,
**Tav**, and **Pagas** on seven islands and seven oceans. 5. Some say that the
moon and sun **Oobhas**, **Ujjoy**, **Tav**, and **Pagas** on ten islands and
ten oceans. 6. Some say that the moon and sun **Oobhas**, **Ujjoy**, **Tav**,
and **Pagas** on twelve islands and twelve oceans. 7. Some say that the moon and
sun **Oobhas**, **Ujjoy**, **Tav**, and **Pagas** on forty-two islands and
forty-two oceans.  1. **Avabhasayanti** (illuminate), **Avabhaso**
(illumination) is also used for knowledge, therefore, to differentiate, it is
said **Udyotayanti** (radiate). **Udyoto** (radiation) is known in the world
with different meanings, like **Atap** (sunlight) for the sun and **Prakash**
(light) for the moon. However, the word **Atap** is also used for the moon's
light, as it is said "**Chandrika** (moonlight), **Kaumudi** (moonlight),
**Jyothsna** (moonlight), and **Chandragata** (moonlight)". Similarly, the word
**Prakash** is also used for the sun's light. This is understood by many,
therefore, to understand the meaning, both words are used together, which have
the same meaning. **Tapayanti** (heat) and **Prakashayanti** (illuminate) are
the verbs.  - Sanskrit Commentary

| Romanization (original text) |

one hundred thousand yojanas, its circumference is three hundred thousand
yojanas, two hundred and twenty-seven yojanas, three kosas, twenty-eight dhanus,
thirteen angulas and a little more than half an angula, as per the calculation.

Jambudvipa, there are twenty-four thousand oceans and fifty-six thousand oceans,
as per the calculation. In the Jambudvipa island, there are five parts of the

wheel in the Jambudvipa island? Please tell us. 1. The text from the first
chapter of the Jambudvipa Prajnapti, from Sutra 4 to Sutra 125 of the sixth
chapter, is to be understood here.

[Third Prabhrita] U. - When these two suns, having encompassed the entire outer
circle, move around, then they illuminate three and five chakra-bhagas of
Jambudvipa, the island, until they set. Just as one sun illuminates one chakra-
bhaga until it sets, and one sun illuminates one chakra-bhaga until it sets,
then, when the sun rises from the Uttarakatta-patta, there are eighteen muhurtas
of day and twelve muhurtas of night. - - [41] When these two suns, having
encompassed the entire outer circle, move around, then they illuminate two and
five chakra-bhagas of Jambudvipa, the island, until they set. One sun
illuminates one chakra-bhaga until it sets, one sun illuminates one chakra-bhaga
until it sets, then, when the sun rises from the Uttarakatta-patta, there are
eighteen muhurtas of night and twelve muhurtas of day.

From the fourth (day) onwards, the arrangement is made. P. - So, how is the
arrangement made? U. - There are two types of arrangements mentioned here,
namely: 1. - The arrangement of the Moon and the Sun. 2. - The arrangement of
the field. The arrangement of the Moon and the Sun P. - So, how is the
arrangement of the Moon and the Sun? U. - There are sixteen types of
arrangements mentioned here. 1. - Some say - The arrangement of the Moon and the
Sun is made with the arrangement of the rays. Some say. 2. - Some say - The
arrangement of the Moon and the Sun is made with the arrangement of the rays
that are not equal. Some say. 3. - Some say - The arrangement of the Moon and
the Sun is made with the arrangement of the angles. Some say. 4. - Some say -
The arrangement of the Moon and the Sun is made with the arrangement of the
angles that are not equal. Some say. 5. - Some say - 1. The commentator explains
'whiteness' as follows - 'This whiteness exists in the Moon and Sun vehicles as
well, and also in the field created by them. Therefore, both are called by the
word whiteness due to the presence of whiteness.' 2. The arrangement of the Moon
and Sun vehicles has been mentioned elsewhere. Therefore, the commentator
explains the questioner's intention regarding the arrangement of the Moon and
Sun vehicles as follows - 'This arrangement in the form of the arrangement of
the Moon and Sun vehicles has been mentioned earlier. Therefore, the arrangement
of the Moon and Sun vehicles mentioned here should be understood as the
arrangement of the four positions.'

[Fourth Chapter] [ 43 Some said that the moon and sun are formed by the
Samchakkavala-santhiti. 6. - Some others said - That the moon and sun are formed
by the Visamchakkavala-santhiti. 7. - Some others said - That the moon and sun
are formed by the Chakkaddhachakkavala-santhiti. 8. - Some others said - That
the moon and sun are formed by the Chhattagara-santhiti. 9. - Some others said -
That the moon and sun are formed by the Geh-santhiti. 10. - Some others said -
That the moon and sun are formed by the Gehavana-santhiti. 11. - Some others
said - That the moon and sun are formed by the Pasaya-santhiti. 12. - Some
others said - That the moon and sun are formed by the Gopura-santhiti. 13. -
Some others said - That the moon and sun are formed by the Pechchaghar-santhiti.
14. - Some others said - That the moon and sun are formed by the Valabhi-
santhiti. 15. - Some others said - That the moon and sun are formed by the
Hammiyatala-santhiti. 16. - Some others said - That the moon and sun are formed
by the Balaggrapotia-santhiti. There, those who said - The word Balaggrapotika
is a local word, and in the sky and the lake, it is a place for playing and
bathing, a small palace. - Surya. Vritti

## 44 [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra ]  **The arrangement of the Moon and Sun, as
described in the Samchaturansa-Santhita, is not to be accepted. The arrangement
of the Sun's orbit is as follows:**  **P. - How is the arrangement of the Sun's
orbit?**  **U. - There are sixteen different views on this matter, as follows:**
1. **Some say:** The arrangement of the Sun's orbit is based on the arrangement
of houses. 2. **Some say:** The arrangement of the Sun's orbit is based on the
arrangement of the courtyard. 3. **Some say:** The arrangement of the Sun's
orbit is based on the arrangement of the passageway. 4. **Some say:** The
arrangement of the Sun's orbit is based on the arrangement of the gate. 5.
**Some say:** The arrangement of the Sun's orbit is based on the arrangement of
the back room. 6. **Some say:** The arrangement of the Sun's orbit is based on
the arrangement of the Valabhi. 7. **Some say:** The arrangement of the Sun's
orbit is based on the arrangement of the Hamiyatala.  **Only one of these
sixteen views is accepted by the Sutrakar. The Vrittikar says:**  "Tathetyadi -
tatra tesham sodasham paratirthikanam madhye ye te vadin evam ahuḥ -
samchaturansasanthita chandrasuryasanthitiḥ prajnasai iti, etena nayena,
netavyaṁ etena abhiprāyeṇāsmānmate'pi chandra-suryasanthitiravadharyeti bhavah,
tathahi - 'iha sarve'pi kalaviseshaḥ susamasusamadayo yugamulaḥ. yugasya chadau
shravana mase bahulapakshapratipadi pratarudayasamaye ekasuryo dakshinapurvasyaṁ
disi vartate, tadvitiyastva parottarasyaṁ, chandramā api tat samaye eko
dakshinaparasyaṁ disi vartate, dvitiya uttarapurvasyamata eteshv yugasya dau
chandra-suryah samchaturansasanthita vartante."  **Translation:**  "The word
'Tathetyadi' refers to the fact that among these sixteen views of the
Paratirthikas, some say that the arrangement of the Moon and Sun is based on the
Samchaturansa-Santhita. This view is not to be accepted. Our view is that the
arrangement of the Moon and Sun should be understood in this way:  "All these
specific times, like the beginning of the Yuga, are based on the balance of the
seasons. At the beginning of the Yuga, on the first day of the bright fortnight
of the month of Shravana, at sunrise, the Sun is in the southeast direction, the
second Sun is in the northeast direction, and the Moon is in the south
direction, and the second Moon is in the northeast direction. At the beginning
of the Yuga, the Moon and Sun are arranged in a square."

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 44 ] [ sUryaprajJaptisUtra tA samacauraMsa-saMThiyA caMdima-sUriyasaMThitI
paNNattA, eeNaM NaeNaM NeyavvaM No ceva NaM iyrehi| sUriyassa
tAvakkhettasaMThitI pa. - tA kahaM te tAvakkhettasaMThitI ? Ahietti vejjaa| u. -
tattha khalu imAo solasa naDivattIo paNNattAo, taM jahA - tattha NaM - 1. - ege
evamAhaMsu - tA geha saMThitA tAvakkhettasaMThitI paNNattA, ege evmaahNsu| 2. -
ege puNa evamAhaMsu - gehAvaNasaMThiyA tAvakkhettasaMThitI paNNattA, ege
evmaahNsu| 3. - ege puNa evamAhaMsu - pAsAyasaMThiyA tAvakkhettasaMThitI
paNNattA, ege evmaahNsu| 4. - ege puNa evamAhaMsu - gopurasaMThiyA
tAvakkhettasaMThitI paNNattA, ege evmaahNsu| 5. - ege puNa evamAhaMsu -
picchAgharasaMThiyA tAvakkhettasaMThitI paNNattA, ege evmaahNsu| 6. - ege puNa
evamAhaMsu - valabhIsaMThiyA tAvakkhettasaMThitI paNNattA, ege evmaahNsu| 7. -
ege puNa evamAhaMsu - hammiyatalasaMThiyA tAvakkhettasaMThitI paNNattA, ege
evmaahNsu| 1. paratIrthikoM kI ina solaha pratipattiyoM meM se kevala eka
pratipatti sUtrakAra kI mAnyatAnusAra hai - isa viSaya meM vRttikAra kA kathana
yaha hai - 'tatthetyAdi-tatra teSAM SoDazAnAM paratIrthikAnAM madhye ye te

Page #96 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
## Fourth Chapter  [45]  8. - Some say - The arrangement of the *Tavak Khett* is
according to the arrangement of the *Balagg* *Poti*. Some say this. 9. - Some
say - The arrangement of the *Tavak Khett* is according to the arrangement of
the *Jambudvipa*. Some say this. 10. - Some say - The arrangement of the *Tavak
Khett* is according to the arrangement of the *Bharat* *Vasa*. Some say this.
11. - Some say - The arrangement of the *Tavak Khett* is according to the
arrangement of the *Ujaan*. Some say this. 12. - Some say - The arrangement of
the *Tavak Khett* is according to the arrangement of the *Nijan*. Some say this.
13. - Some say - The arrangement of the *Tavak Khett* is according to the
arrangement of the *Ega Nisadh*. Some say this. 14. - Some say - The arrangement
of the *Tavak Khett* is according to the arrangement of the *Duha Nisadh*. Some
say this. 15. - Some say - The arrangement of the *Tavak Khett* is according to
the arrangement of the *Seyanag*. Some say this. 16. - Some say - The
arrangement of the *Tavak Khett* is according to the arrangement of the
*Seyanag* *Patth*. Some say this. But we say - The arrangement of the *Tavak
Khett* is according to the arrangement of the *Uddhi* *Muh* *Kalamb* *Apupph*.
It is contracted inside, and expanded outside. It is round inside, and flat
outside.  The discrepancy in the arrangement of the circles, as the Sun is in
the innermost circle and the Moon is in the outermost circle, is not considered
significant. This is because, at the beginning of the *Yuga*, when all the time
periods are in balance, the Sun and the Moon are situated in a square shape.
Therefore, their arrangement is described as being in a square shape. Otherwise,
according to tradition, the square shape should be considered.  No other theory,
including the theory of the arrangement of the Sun and the Moon, should be
considered, as they are false. This is the correct description of the
arrangement of the Sun and the Moon.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

Page #97 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
46 ] [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra Inside, the Ankamukhasanathiya, outside the
Satthiya Mukhasanathiya. In that, there are two Bahas, On both sides, there are
thirty-two Bahas, which are Avattthiyas, with an extent of 49,000 yojanas. There
are thirty-two Bahas which are Anavattthiyas, as follows: 1. - The Sarvabhtariya
Baha. 2. - The Sarvabahiriya Baha. P. - What is that? Vaeja. U. - That is the
Jambudvipa, the island - The entire island, the entire ocean, the entire
mountain. It is round, with a Tellapuy-santhana-santhi. It is round, with a
Rahchakkaval-santhana-santhi. It is round, with a Pukkharakanniya-santhana-
santhi. It is round, with a Padipunna Chand-santhana-santhi. With an extent and
diameter of 100,000 yojanas. With an extent of 3,000,000 yojanas, 16,000
yojanas, 270 yojanas, 3 kosas, 28 dhanus, 13 angulas, and half an angula, with a
little excess, it is established by calculation. That is the calculation of the
Tavakhetasanthi. When the Sun traverses the entire inner circle, the Uddhi Mukha
Kalambua Pupha Santhi is in the Tavakhetasanthi, Vaeja. Inside, it is
contracted, outside, it is expanded, inside, it is round, outside, it is thick,
1. In the direction of the inner Meru, the Anka-Padmasana-upavishtasya Utsanga-
rupa Asanabandh, its mouth is in the shape of a circle in the front, its own
position is the position of that. 2. Similarly, in the direction of the outer
Lavana, the Svastika-mukha-santhita, the Svastika is well-known, its mouth is
the front, its own position is very wide, That is that. 3. 'These two Bahas are
situated in the extent of the Jambudvipa, according to the extent of the
Jambudvipa.' Suri. Vritti. 4. 'Two Bahas are not situated, as follows: the
Sarvabhyantara, the Sarvabahirya.' (a) The Baha which is near the Meru, with a
greater diameter, is the Sarvabhyantara. (b) The Baha which is in the direction
of the Lavana, up to the Jambudvipa, with a greater diameter, is the
Sarvabahirya Baha. (c) The extent is to be understood as south-north, the
diameter as east-west.

[Fourth Prabhrita] [47] The inner circumference is measured in Ankamuhasthaniya,
the outer circumference is measured in Shastrimuhasthaniya, both are measured in
the same way up to the outermost circumference.  (a) The innermost circumference
is: The Mandaraparvata is surrounded by it, which is 9,004 yojanas in
circumference. Q - What is the specific measurement of this circumference? A -
The circumference of the Mandaraparvata, when multiplied by three and then
divided by ten, is the specific measurement of this circumference.  (b) The
outermost circumference is: The Lavaṇa ocean, which is 84,008 yojanas and 84
yojana-parts in circumference. Q - What is the specific measurement of this
circumference? A - The circumference of the Jambudvipa, when multiplied by three
and then divided by ten, is the specific measurement of this circumference. This
also describes the dimensions of the Andhakara-kshetra.  Q - What is the
measurement of this Andhakara-kshetra? A - It is 78,033 yojanas in length.  Q -
What is the shape of the Andhakara-kshetra? A - It is shaped like an inverted
lotus flower.  The innermost circumference is the Mandaraparvata, which is 6,624
yojanas in circumference. Q - What is the specific measurement of this
circumference? A - The circumference of the Mandaraparvata, when multiplied by
two and then divided by ten, is the specific measurement of this circumference.
The outermost circumference is the Lavaṇa ocean, which is 63,262 yojanas in
circumference. Q - What is the specific measurement of this circumference? A -
The circumference of the Jambudvipa, when multiplied by two and then divided by
ten, is the specific measurement of this circumference.  1. The circumference of
Meru is 31,623 yojanas. When multiplied by three, it becomes 94,869 yojanas.
When divided by ten, it becomes 9,486 9/10 yojanas - this is the circumference
of the innermost baha. 2. The circumference of Jambudvipa is 316,227 yojanas,
three kosa, twenty-eight dhanus, and thirteen and a half angulas. When divided
by ten, it becomes 94,868 yojanas. Four parts out of ten of one yojana is the
specific circumference of the outermost baha.

48 ] P. So, what is the specific circumference of the Jambudvipa island? Please
tell me. U. - The circumference of the Jambudvipa island is calculated by
multiplying the circumference by two, then dividing by ten, then dividing by
ten, and then by ten again. This is the specific circumference. Please tell me.
P. So, what is the length of the darkness? Please tell me. U. — — — [ Surya
Prajnapti Sutra It is 77,000 yojanas, 330 yojanas, and a part of a yojana in
length. Please tell me. At the highest point of the Uttarakuru mountain, there
are 18 muhurtas of day. There are 12 muhurtas of night. P. - So, when the sun
has risen above the entire circle and is moving, what is the arrangement of the
light? Please tell me. U. - The arrangement of the light is like the arrangement
of the petals of the Udumbara flower. Please tell me. Just as the darkness is
arranged in the inner circle, so is the light arranged in the outer circle. Just
as the light is arranged there, so is the darkness arranged in the outer circle.
This should be understood. At the highest point of the Uttarakuru mountain,
there are 18 muhurtas of night. There are 12 muhurtas of day. The measurement of
the light P. - So, on the Jambudvipa island, how much distance does the sun
travel upwards, how much distance does it travel horizontally, and how much
distance does it travel diagonally? U. - So, on the Jambudvipa island, the sun
travels 100 yojanas upwards. It travels 1800 yojanas horizontally. It travels
7,000 yojanas, 220 yojanas, and 21 parts of a yojana diagonally.

From the fifth (Pancham) onwards, the rays of the sun are obstructed by the
mountains. 26.  Where are the rays of the sun obstructed?  It is said.  There
are twenty (Vīsam) different opinions (Paḍivattī) stated, as follows:  Some
(Ege) said: 1.  The rays of the sun are obstructed by the Mandara mountain, it
is said.  Some (Ege) said, Some (Ege) again said: 2.  The rays of the sun are
obstructed by the Meru mountain, it is said.  Some (Ege) said, Some (Ege) again
said: 3.  The rays of the sun are obstructed by the Manoram mountain, it is
said.  Some (Ege) said, Some (Ege) again said: 4.  The rays of the sun are
obstructed by the Sudarsana mountain, it is said.  Some (Ege) said, Some (Ege)
again said: 5.  The rays of the sun are obstructed by the Sayamprabha mountain,
it is said.  Some (Ege) said, Some (Ege) again said: 6.  The rays of the sun are
obstructed by the Giriraja mountain, it is said.  Some (Ege) said, Some (Ege)
again said: 7.  The rays of the sun are obstructed by the Rayanuccaya mountain,
it is said.  Some (Ege) said, Some (Ege) again said: 8.  The rays of the sun are
obstructed by the Siluccaya mountain, it is said.  Some (Ege) said, Some (Ege)
again said: 9.  The rays of the sun are obstructed by the Loyamajha mountain, it
is said.  Some (Ege) said, Some (Ege) again said:

| Romanization (original text) |

50 ] [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra 10. Some said that the mountains are the rays of
the sun, others said that they are not. - 11. Some said that the mountains are
the rays of the sun, others said that they are not. - 12. Some said that the
mountains are like the sun, others said that they are not. - 13. Some said that
the mountains are the coverings of the sun, others said that they are not. - 14.
Some said that the mountains are the best, others said that they are not. - 15.
Some said that the mountains are in all directions, others said that they are
not. - 16. Some said that the mountains are the parts of the sun, others said
that they are not. - 17. Some said that the mountains are the nails of the
earth, others said that they are not. - 18. Some said that the mountains are the
horns of the earth, others said that they are not. - 19. Some said that the
mountains are the teeth of the earth, others said that they are not. - 20. Some
said that the mountains are the kings of the earth, others said that they are
not. - We, however, say that...

Page #102 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
##  [From the Fifth Chapter Onwards]  [51] Just as the sun's rays fall upon the
mountains, so they also fall upon the Mandara mountain, and even upon the
mountain king. [a] Those beings who are illuminated by the sun's rays are also
those who are touched by the sun's rays. [b] Even the unseen beings are touched
by the sun's rays. Those beings who are in the last stage of liberation are also
touched by the sun's rays.  1. Sixteen names of the Mandara mountain are
mentioned in the scriptures, as follows:  1. Mandara 2. Meru 3. Manorama 4.
Sudarsana 5. Sayamprabha 6. Giriraja 7. Rayanuccaya 8. Piyadarsana 9-19. In the
middle of the world, the navel [1] 11. Acchaya 12. Suryavatte 13. Suryavaranetti
14. Uttama 15. Disadi 16. Vadensei, sixteen in total [2]  a - Sam. S. 16, Su. 3
b - Jambu. Vakkh. 4, Su. 109  These two verses list sixteen names of the Mandara
mountain. In addition to these, there are four other metaphorical names.  These
twenty synonyms of the Mandara mountain are considered by different schools of
thought to be different mountains. However, the compiler of the Surya Prajnapti,
in accordance with the Samavayanga and Jambudvipa Prajnapti, has reconciled all
other beliefs by considering these twenty synonyms to be names of the Mandara
mountain.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

Page #103 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
The sixth **Praabhrut** (dawn) is the time when the sun rises.  **P.** - How do
you know that it is the time when the sun rises?  **U.** - There are nineteen
**Pativratti** (interpretations) about this. They are as follows:  1. Some say
that the sun rises and sets at the **Anusamaya** (instant). 2. Some say that the
sun rises and sets at the **Anumuhuutta** (moment). 3. Some say that the sun
rises and sets at the **Anuraidiya** (day). 4. Some say that the sun rises and
sets at the **Anupakkha** (fortnight). 5. Some say that the sun rises and sets
at the **Anumaasa** (month). 6. Some say that the sun rises and sets at the
**Anuu** (year). 7. Some say that the sun rises and sets at the **Anuayan**
(cycle of years). 8. Some say that the sun rises and sets at the
**Anusamvachchar** (century). 9. Some say that the sun rises and sets at the
**Anujug** (eon).

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

[54] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra] 22. Some say that the sun's rays increase and
decrease by an amount equal to an ocean of dust particles. Others say - 23. Some
say that the sun's rays increase and decrease by an amount equal to a thousand
oceans of dust particles. Others say - 24. Some say that the sun's rays increase
and decrease by an amount equal to a hundred thousand oceans of dust particles.
Others say - 25. Some say that the sun's rays increase and decrease by an amount
equal to the time of an Utsarpini-Avasarpini. We, however, say - (a) The sun's
rays increase and decrease by an amount equal to thirty muhurtas. (b) The sun's
rays decrease for six months. _ The sun's rays increase for six months. (c) The
sun's rays decrease when it is leaving the country. The sun's rays increase when
it is entering the country. P. - What is the reason for this? A. - This is what
we have learned. U. - The Jambudvipa, which is the center of all the islands and
oceans, is a circle with a diameter of a hundred thousand yojanas, three hundred
thousand yojanas, two hundred and twenty-seven yojanas, three kosas, twenty-
eight dhanus, thirteen angulas, and a little more than half an angula. 1. When
the sun travels through the entire circle, it takes eighteen muhurtas to
complete a day, which is equal to twelve muhurtas of night. 2. When the sun is
leaving the country, it travels through the inner circle in the first year of
the Avyamana Samvatsara. 1. It appears from these statements that the terms
'Palya-upam-Sagaro-upam, Utsarpini-Avasarpini', etc., which are used to denote
the time of the Aupamika Kala, were also used in other philosophical Puranas and
other texts besides the Jain Agamas. If these terms are used in any of the
Puranas or other texts, then scholars should try to find them and publish them.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

## Sixth Praabhrut  [55]  **1.** When the fresh sun, after entering the inner
circle, moves around it, then in one day, with one *raaidie* (unit of time), it
covers one part of the day-field, leaving the night-field, and moves around the
circle, which is divided into eighteen *tisas* (units of time).  Therefore, the
day is of eighteen *muhurtas* (units of time), less two *egaattibhagamuhurtas*
(units of time).  The night is of twelve *muhurtas* (units of time), more two
*egaattibhagamuhurtas* (units of time).  **2.** When the sun, after entering the
inner circle, moves around it, then in one day, with two *raaidies* (units of
time), it covers two parts of the day-field, leaving the night-field, and moves
around the circle, which is divided into eighteen *tisas* (units of time).
Therefore, the day is of eighteen *muhurtas* (units of time), less four
*egaattibhagamuhurtas* (units of time).  The night is of twelve *muhurtas*
(units of time), more four *egaattibhagamuhurtas* (units of time).  **3.** Thus,
when the sun, after entering the inner circle, moves around it, then it moves
from one circle to another, and with one *raaidie* (unit of time), it covers one
part of the day-field, leaving the night-field, and moves around the outer
circle.  **4.** When the sun, after entering all the inner circles, moves around
the outer circle, then it covers one part of the day-field, leaving the night-
field, and moves around the circle, which is divided into eighteen *tisas*
(units of time).  Therefore, the day is of eighteen *muhurtas* (units of time),
less two *egaattibhagamuhurtas* (units of time).  The night is of twelve
*muhurtas* (units of time), more two *egaattibhagamuhurtas* (units of time).
**5.** When the sun, after entering all the inner circles, moves around the
outer circle, then it covers one part of the day-field, leaving the night-field,
and moves around the circle, which is divided into eighteen *tisas* (units of
time).  Therefore, the day is of eighteen *muhurtas* (units of time), less four
*egaattibhagamuhurtas* (units of time).  The night is of twelve *muhurtas*
(units of time), more four *egaattibhagamuhurtas* (units of time).  **6.** Thus,
when the sun, after entering all the inner circles, moves around the outer
circle, then it moves from one circle to another, and with one *raaidie* (unit
of time), it covers one part of the day-field, leaving the night-field, and
moves around the outer circle.  **7.** When the sun, after entering all the
inner circles, moves around the outer circle, then it covers one part of the
day-field, leaving the night-field, and moves around the circle, which is
divided into eighteen *tisas* (units of time).  Therefore, the day is of
eighteen *muhurtas* (units of time), less two *egaattibhagamuhurtas* (units of
time).  The night is of twelve *muhurtas* (units of time), more two
*egaattibhagamuhurtas* (units of time).  **8.** This is the first six months,
this is the first six months, the *pajjavasaana* (end of the rainy season).
**9.** When the sun, after entering the outer circle, moves around it, then in
one day, with one *raaidie* (unit of time), it covers one part of the night-
field, leaving the day-field, and moves around the circle, which is divided into
eighteen *tisas* (units of time).  Therefore, the day is of eighteen *muhurtas*
(units of time), less two *egaattibhagamuhurtas* (units of time).  The night is
of twelve *muhurtas* (units of time), more two *egaattibhagamuhurtas* (units of
time).

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

aTThArasehiM sehiM saehiM chettA  /  tayA NaM aTThArasamuhuttA rAI bhavai, dohiM

Page #107 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
## 56 [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra ]  1. The day consists of twelve muhurtas, and the
night consists of twelve muhurtas.  2. When the sun enters, it traverses the
outer circle of its mandala, moving in four directions.  As the sun traverses
the outer circle of its mandala, it moves in four directions, causing two rays
to illuminate the field of light, and two rays to illuminate the field of day.
The mandala is divided into eighteen, thirty, and one hundred parts.  Therefore,
the day consists of eighteen muhurtas, minus four parts of a muhurta. The night
consists of twelve muhurtas, minus four parts of a muhurta.  3. Thus, as the sun
enters, it traverses the mandalas, moving from one mandala to another. Each
mandala, with its own rays, illuminates the field of light, and illuminates the
field of day. The sun traverses all the mandalas, moving in four directions.  4.
When the sun traverses all the outer mandalas, and all the inner mandalas, it
traverses the outermost mandala, causing one hundred rays to illuminate the
field of light, and one hundred rays to illuminate the field of day. The mandala
is divided into eighteen, thirty, and one hundred parts.  Therefore, the day
consists of eighteen muhurtas, when the sun reaches its highest point, just as
the night consists of twelve muhurtas.  This is the duration of the six months,
and this is the end of the six months. This is the duration of the solar year,
and this is the end of the solar year.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 56 ] [ sUryaprajJaptisUtra duvAlasamuhutte divase bhavai, dohiM
egaTThibhAgamuhuttehiM ahie| 2. se pavisamANe sUrie doccaMsi ahorattaMsi
bAhirANaMtaraM taccaM maMDalaM uvasaMkamittA cAraM cri| tA jayA NaM sUrie
bAhirANaMtaraM taccaM maMDalaM tavasaMkamittA cAraM carai, tayA NaM dohiM
rAiMdiehiM do bhAe oyAe rayaNikhettassa nivvuDDhettA, divasa-khettassa
abhivuDDhettA cAraM carai, maMDalaM aTThArasehiM tIsehiM saehiM chettaa| tayA
NaM aTThArasamuhuttA rAI bhavai, cauhiM egaTThibhAgamahuttehiM uunnaa|
duvAlasamuhutte divase bhavai, cauhiM egaTThibhAgamuhuttehiM ahie| 3. evaM khalu
eeNaM uvAeNaM pavisamANe sUrie tayANaMtarAo maMDalAo tayANaMtaraM maMDalaM
saMkamamANe saMkamamANe egamege maMDale, egamegeNaM rAidieNaM egamegaM bhAgaM
oyAe rayaNi-khettassa nivvuDDhemANe nivvaDaDhemANe divasa-khettassa
abhivaDaDhemANe abhivaDDhemANe savvabbhaMtaraM maMDalaM uvasaMkamittA cAraM cri|

uvasaMkamittA cAraM carai, tayA NaM savvabAhiraM maMDalaM paNihAya egeNaM
tesIeNaM rAiMdiyasaeNaM egaM tesIyaM bhAgasayaM oyAe rayaNikhettassa
nivvuDDhettA divasa-khettassa abhivuDDhettA cAraM carai, maMDalaM aTThAraseMhi
tIsehiM saehiM chettaa| tayA NaM uttamakaTThapatte ukkosae aTThArasamuhutte
divase bhavai, jahaNiyA duvAlasamuhuttA rAI bhvi| esa NaM docce chammAse, esa
NaM doccassa chammAsassa pjjvsaanne| esa NaM Aicce saMvacchare, esa NaM Aiccassa
saMvaccharassa pjvsaanne|

Page #108 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
**Seventh Prabhruta Surya by Pagasia Pavva**  **P. -** What is the Surya (Sun)
worshipped on? Please tell me.  **U. -** There are twenty different
interpretations (**Padivatti**) mentioned in this context, as follows:  1. Some
say that the Surya is worshipped on the **Mandara** mountain. 2. Others say that
the Surya is worshipped on the **Meru** mountain. 3. - 19. Similarly, other
interpretations should be considered in the same way. 20. Some say that the
Surya is worshipped on the **Pavvayaraya** mountain.  We, however, believe that
the Surya is worshipped on the **Mandara** mountain. This is also mentioned in
the **Surya Prajnaptti** (Chapter 5, Sutra 26).  The Surya is also worshipped on
the **Pavvayaraya** mountain.  (a) Those who see the Surya's rays (**Lesa**) are
worshipping the Surya. (b) Even those who cannot see the Surya are worshipping
it. (c) Even those who are in the last stage of **Lesa** (**Charimalesa**) are
worshipping the Surya.  1. In the **Surya Prajnaptti** (Chapter 5, Sutra 26),
under the heading "**Surya's Lesa Padihayaga Pavva**", twenty mountains that
obstruct the Surya's rays are mentioned. Here, all the speakers should be
considered according to the original text. 2. In the above mentioned section,
the compiler of the **Surya Prajnaptti** has considered the twenty names of the
**Mandara** mountain as synonyms and has harmonized them.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 saptama prAbhRta sUriyeNa pagAsiyA pavvayA pa. - tA kiM te sUriyaM varai ?
Ahietti vejjaa| u. - tattha khalu imAo vIsaM paDivattIo paNNattao taM jahA -
tatthege evamAhaMsu - 1. tA maMdare NaM pavvae sUriyaM varai, ege evmaahNsu| ege
puNa evamAhaMsu - 2. tA merU NaM pavvae sUriyaM varai ege evmaahNsu| 3-19. evaM
eeNaM abhilAveNaM NeyavvaM taheva jaav| ege puNa evamAhaMsu - 20. tA pavvayarAye
NaM pavvae sUriyaM varai, ege evmaahNsu| vayaM puNa evaM badAmo - tA maMdare NaM
pavvae sUriyaM varai, evaM pi pavuccai taheva jAva (1-20 sUriya. pA. 5, su. 26
ko dekheN)| tA pavvayarAye NaM pavvae sUriyaM varai, evaM pi pvucci| (ka) tA je
NaM poggalA sUriyassa lesaM phusaMti, te NaM puggalA sUriyaM vryNti| (kha)
adiTThA vi NaM poggalA sUriyaM vryNti| (ga) carimalessaMtaragayA viNaM poggalA
sUriyaM vryNti| 1. 'sUriyassa lessA paDidhAyagA pavvayA' isa zIrSaka ke
antargata sUrya. prA. 5, su. 26 meM bIsa pratipattiyoM ke anusAra sUrya kI lezyA
/  ko pratihata karane vAle bIsa parvatoM ke nAma ginAye haiN| yahAM bhI usI ke
anusAra mUla-pATha ke sabhI AlApaka kahane caahiye| 2. Upara ke TippaNa meM
sUcita zIrSaka ke antargata sUrya. pA.5,su. 26 ke anusAra sUryaprajJapti ke
saMkalanakartA ne yahAM bhI maMdara parvata ke bIsa nAmoM ko paryAyavAcI
mAnakara samanvaya kara liyA hai|

Page #109 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
## Eighth (Aṣṭama) and onwards: The Sunrise (Udaya-saṇṭhī)  **P.** - Tell me,
what is the Sunrise (Udaya-saṇṭhī)? **U.** - There are three (tiṇṇi) types of
Sunrise (Udaya-saṇṭhī) in this (tathā) context. They are:  **(a)** They (tathā)
said (āhamsu) that when it is eighteen (aṭṭhārasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the
Southern (dāhiṇadḍhe) part of Jambudvīpa, it is also eighteen (aṭṭhārasamuhuṭṭe)
Muhūrta days in the Northern (uttaredḍhe) part. When it is eighteen
(aṭṭhārasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Northern (uttaredḍhe) part of Jambudvīpa,
it is also eighteen (aṭṭhārasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Southern (dāhiṇadḍhe)
part.  **(b)** They (tathā) said (āhamsu) that when it is seventeen
(sattarasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Southern (dāhiṇadḍhe) part of Jambudvīpa,
it is also seventeen (sattarasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Northern
(uttaredḍhe) part. When it is seventeen (sattarasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the
Northern (uttaredḍhe) part of Jambudvīpa, it is also seventeen
(sattarasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Southern (dāhiṇadḍhe) part.  **(c)** They
(tathā) said (āhamsu) that when it is sixteen (solasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in
the Southern (dāhiṇadḍhe) part of Jambudvīpa, it is also sixteen (solasamuhuṭṭe)
Muhūrta days in the Northern (uttaredḍhe) part. When it is sixteen
(solasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Northern (uttaredḍhe) part of Jambudvīpa, it
is also sixteen (solasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Southern (dāhiṇadḍhe) part.
**(d)** They (tathā) said (āhamsu) that when it is fifteen (paṇṇarasamuhuṭṭe)
Muhūrta days in the Southern (dāhiṇadḍhe) part of Jambudvīpa, it is also fifteen
(paṇṇarasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Northern (uttaredḍhe) part. When it is
fifteen (paṇṇarasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Northern (uttaredḍhe) part of
Jambudvīpa, it is also fifteen (paṇṇarasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Southern
(dāhiṇadḍhe) part.  **(e)** They (tathā) said (āhamsu) that when it is fourteen
(cauddhasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Southern (dāhiṇadḍhe) part of Jambudvīpa,
it is also fourteen (cauddhasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Northern (uttaredḍhe)
part. When it is fourteen (cauddhasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Northern
(uttaredḍhe) part of Jambudvīpa, it is also fourteen (cauddhasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta
days in the Southern (dāhiṇadḍhe) part.  **(f)** They (tathā) said (āhamsu) that
when it is thirteen (terasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the Southern (dāhiṇadḍhe)
part of Jambudvīpa, it is also thirteen (terasamuhuṭṭe) Muhūrta days in the
Northern (uttaredḍhe) part.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

## Eighth Chapter  [59]  (a) If it is the thirteenth muhurta day in the northern
hemisphere, then it is the thirteenth muhurta day in the southern hemisphere.
(b) If it is the twelfth muhurta day in the southern hemisphere of Jambudvipa,
then it is the twelfth muhurta day in the northern hemisphere. If it is the
twelfth muhurta day in the northern hemisphere, then it is the twelfth muhurta
day in the southern hemisphere.  (c) If it is the fifteenth muhurta day in the
east-west direction of Mount Mandara in Jambudvipa, then it is the fifteenth
muhurta day in the east-west direction of Mount Mandara. This is the rule, O
monks! Some say this.  2. Some others say:  (a) If it is the eighteenth muhurta
day in the southern hemisphere of Jambudvipa, then it is the eighteenth muhurta
day in the northern hemisphere. If it is the eighteenth muhurta day in the
northern hemisphere, then it is the eighteenth muhurta day in the southern
hemisphere.  (b) If it is the seventeenth muhurta day in the southern hemisphere
of Jambudvipa, then it is the seventeenth muhurta day in the northern
hemisphere. If it is the seventeenth muhurta day in the northern hemisphere,
then it is the seventeenth muhurta day in the southern hemisphere.  (c) If it is
the sixteenth muhurta day in the southern hemisphere of Jambudvipa, then it is
the sixteenth muhurta day in the northern hemisphere. If it is the sixteenth
muhurta day in the northern hemisphere, then it is the sixteenth muhurta day in
the southern hemisphere.  (d) If it is the fifteenth muhurta day in the southern
hemisphere of Jambudvipa, then it is the fifteenth muhurta day in the northern
hemisphere. If it is the fifteenth muhurta day in the northern hemisphere, then
it is the fifteenth muhurta day in the southern hemisphere.  (e) If it is the
fourteenth muhurta day in the southern hemisphere of Jambudvipa, then it is the
fourteenth muhurta day in the northern hemisphere. If it is the fourteenth
muhurta day in the northern hemisphere, then it is the fourteenth muhurta day in
the southern hemisphere.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

Page #111 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):

60 ] [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra (c) Now, when it is thirteen muhurtas in the
southern part of Jambudvipa, it is also thirteen muhurtas in the northern part.
When it is thirteen muhurtas in the northern part of Jambudvipa, it is also
thirteen muhurtas in the southern part. (ch) Now, when it is twelve muhurtas in
the southern part of Jambudvipa, it is also twelve muhurtas in the northern
part. When it is twelve muhurtas in the northern part of Jambudvipa, it is also
twelve muhurtas in the southern part. (j) Now, when it is fifteen muhurtas in
the east and west of Mount Mandara in Jambudvipa, it is fifteen muhurtas in the
night. The night is called "Rati" and the day is called "Divasa". Thus, the
Samanas said. 3. Some others said: (k) Now, when it is eighteen muhurtas in the
southern part of Jambudvipa, it is twelve muhurtas in the night in the northern
part. When it is eighteen muhurtas in the northern part of Jambudvipa, it is
twelve muhurtas in the night in the southern part. (kh) Now, when it is eighteen
muhurtas in the southern part of Jambudvipa, it is twelve muhurtas in the night
in the northern part. When it is eighteen muhurtas in the northern part of
Jambudvipa, it is twelve muhurtas in the night in the southern part. (k) Now,
when it is seventeen muhurtas in the southern part of Jambudvipa, it is twelve
muhurtas in the night in the northern part. When it is seventeen muhurtas in the
northern part of Jambudvipa, it is twelve muhurtas in the night in the southern
part. (kh) Now, when it is seventeen muhurtas in the southern part of
Jambudvipa, it is twelve muhurtas in the night in the northern part. When it is
seventeen muhurtas in the northern part of Jambudvipa, it is twelve muhurtas in
the night in the southern part. (k) Now, when it is sixteen muhurtas in the
southern part of Jambudvipa, it is twelve muhurtas in the night in the northern
part.

| Romanization (original text) |

bhavai  /  (ka) tA jayA NaM jaMbuddIve dIve dAhiNaDDhe solasamuhutte divase
bhavai, tayA NaM uttaraDDhe duvAlasamuhuttA rAI bhavai  /

Page #112 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):

[Aṣṭama Prābhṛta] [ 61 If a day occurs in the North with sixteen Muhūrtas, then
a night occurs in the South with twelve Muhūrtas. (b) If a day occurs in the
South with sixteen Muhūrtas in Jambudvīpa, then a night occurs in the North with
twelve Muhūrtas. If a day occurs in the North with sixteen Muhūrtas, then a
night occurs in the South with twelve Muhūrtas. (a) If a day occurs in the South
with fifteen Muhūrtas in Jambudvīpa, then a night occurs in the North with
twelve Muhūrtas. If a day occurs in the North with fifteen Muhūrtas, then a
night occurs in the South with twelve Muhūrtas. (b) If a day occurs in the South
with fifteen Muhūrtas in Jambudvīpa, then a night occurs in the North with
twelve Muhūrtas. If a day occurs in the North with fifteen Muhūrtas, then a
night occurs in the South with twelve Muhūrtas. (a) If a day occurs in the South
with fourteen Muhūrtas in Jambudvīpa, then a night occurs in the North with
twelve Muhūrtas. If a day occurs in the North with fourteen Muhūrtas, then a
night occurs in the South with twelve Muhūrtas. (b) If a day occurs in the South
with fourteen Muhūrtas in Jambudvīpa, then a night occurs in the North with
twelve Muhūrtas. If a day occurs in the North with fourteen Muhūrtas, then a
night occurs in the South with twelve Muhūrtas. (a) If a day occurs in the South
with thirteen Muhūrtas in Jambudvīpa, then a night occurs in the North with
twelve Muhūrtas. If a day occurs in the North with thirteen Muhūrtas, then a
night occurs in the South with twelve Muhūrtas. (b) If a day occurs in the South
with thirteen Muhūrtas in Jambudvīpa, then a night occurs in the North with
twelve Muhūrtas. If a day occurs in the North with thirteen Muhūrtas, then a
night occurs in the South with twelve Muhūrtas. (a) If a day occurs in the South
with twelve Muhūrtas in Jambudvīpa, then a night occurs in the North with twelve
Muhūrtas. If a day occurs in the North with twelve Muhūrtas, then a night occurs
in the South with twelve Muhūrtas. (b) If a day occurs in the South with twelve
Muhūrtas in Jambudvīpa, then a night occurs in the North with twelve Muhūrtas. ]

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 aSTama prAbhRta ] [ 61 jayA NaM uttaraDDhe solasamuhutte divase bhavai, tayA
NaM dAhiNaDDhe bArasamuhuttA rAI bhvi| (kha) tA jayA NaM jaMbuddIve dIve
dAhiNaDDhe solasamuhuttANaMtare divase bhavai, tayA NaM uttaraDDhe
duvAlasamuhuttA rAI bhvi| jayA NaM uttaraDDhe solasamuhuttANaMtare divase
bhavai, tayA NaM dAhiNaDDhe bArasamuhuttA rAI bhvi| (ka ) tA jayA NaM jaMbuddIve
dIve dAhiNaDDhe paNNarasamuhutte divase bhavai, tayA NaM uttaraDDhe
duvAlasamuhuttA rAI bhvi| jayA NaM uttaraDDhe paNNarasamuhutte divase bhavai,
tayA NaM dAhiNaDDhe bArasamuhuttA rAI bhvi| (kha ) tA jayA NaM jaMbuddIve dIve
dAhiNaDDhe paNNarasamuhuttANaMtare divase bhavai, tayA NaM uttaraDDhe

Page #113 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
[62] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra] Where it is day for twelve muhurtas in the north,
it is night for twelve muhurtas in the south. Where it is day for fifteen
muhurtas on the eastern side of Mount Mandara in Jambudvipa, it is night for
fifteen muhurtas on the western side. Some say that the night is then in the
south. But we say: The sun in Jambudvipa rises in the east, moves towards the
south, moves towards the west, moves towards the north, and moves towards the
east again. (a) Where it is day on the southern side of Mount Mandara in
Jambudvipa, it is also day on the northern side. Where it is day on the northern
side, it is night on the eastern and western sides of Mount Mandara in
Jambudvipa. (b) Where it is day on the eastern side of Mount Mandara in
Jambudvipa, it is also day on the western side. Where it is day on the western
side, it is night on the north and south sides of Mount Mandara in Jambudvipa.
(a) Where it is day for eighteen muhurtas on the southern side of Mount Mandara
in Jambudvipa, it is also day for eighteen muhurtas on the northern side. Where
it is day for eighteen muhurtas on the northern side, it is night on the... 1.
P. In Jambudvipa, Venerable Sir, does the sun rise in the east, move towards the
south, move towards the west, move towards the north, and move towards the east
again? U. Yes, indeed! As stated in the first section of the fifth chapter,
where there is no... - Bhag. S. 5, U. 1, Su. 5 (a) Jamb. Vakkh. 7, Su. 150

 62 ] [ sUryaprajJaptisUtra jayA NaM uttaraDDhe bArasamuhuttANaMtare divase

Page #114 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):

[ Eighth Chapter ] [ 63 ] In the east and west, there are twelve muhurtas of
night. (b) When the sun rises in the east on Jambudvipa, the mountain Mandara,
it is eighteen muhurtas of day, and when it sets in the west, it is also
eighteen muhurtas of day. When the sun sets in the west, it is eighteen muhurtas
of day, and when it rises in the east on Jambudvipa, the mountain Mandara, it is
twelve muhurtas of night. Thus, it should be understood that On the day after
eighteen muhurtas - there are twelve muhurtas of night. On the day after
seventeen muhurtas - there are thirteen muhurtas of night. On the day after
seventeen muhurtas - there are thirteen muhurtas of night. On the day after
sixteen muhurtas - there are fourteen muhurtas of night. On the day after
sixteen muhurtas - there are fourteen muhurtas of night. On the day after
fifteen muhurtas - there are fifteen muhurtas of night. On the day after fifteen
muhurtas - there are fifteen muhurtas of night. On the day after fourteen
muhurtas - there are sixteen muhurtas of night. On the day after fourteen
muhurtas - there are sixteen muhurtas of night. On the day after thirteen
muhurtas - there are seventeen muhurtas of night.

| Romanization (original text) |

 aSTama prAbhRta ] [ 63 puratthima-paccatthime NaM jahaNiyA duvAlasamuhuttA rAI

Page #115 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):

[64] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra] On days with thirteen Muhurtas, the Sairag is
seventeen Muhurtas. As on days with twelve Muhurtas, the Ukkoshiya is eighteen
Muhurtas. This is how it should be said. (a) When the Vasa begins in the first
moment on the southern side of the Mandara mountain on Jambudvipa, it also
begins in the first moment on the northern side. When the Vasa begins in the
first moment on the northern side, it begins in the first moment on the eastern
and western sides of the Mandara mountain on Jambudvipa, in the subsequent time
period. (b) When the Vasa begins in the first moment on the eastern side of the
Mandara mountain on Jambudvipa, it also begins in the first moment on the
western side. When the Vasa begins in the first moment on the western side, it
begins in the first moment on the north and south sides of the Mandara mountain
on Jambudvipa, in the subsequent time period. As the time is, so are the
following: 1. Avaliya, 2. Anapanu, 3. Theve, 4. Lave, 5. Muhurta, 6. Ahoratta,
7. Pakkha, 8. Mase. These eight are the Alapagas. As the Vasa is, so it should
be said. Hemant (a) When the Hemant begins in the first moment on the southern
side of the Mandara mountain on Jambudvipa, it also begins in the first moment
on the northern side. When the Hemant begins in the first moment on the northern
side, it begins in the first moment on the eastern and western sides of the
Mandara mountain on Jambudvipa, in the subsequent time period. (b) When the
Hemant begins in the first moment on the eastern side of the Mandara mountain on
Jambudvipa, it also begins in the first moment on the western side. When the
Hemant begins in the first moment on the western side, it begins in the first
moment on the north and south sides of the Mandara mountain on Jambudvipa, in
the subsequent time period. 1. In the above Sutra, 'Padhame Samaye' is mentioned
eight times. In those places, the following Alapagas should be said, and for
each Alapaga, two Sutras should be said similar to the above - 1. Padhama
Avaliya, 2. Padamo Anapanu, 3. Padame Theve, 4. Padame Lave, 5. Padhame Muhurte,
6. Padhame Ahoratte, 7. Padhame Pakkha, 8. Padhame Mase.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

## Aṣṭama Prābhṛta ] 65 Uttara R-Dāhiṇe ṇam Aṇantara-Pacchākṛd-Kāla-Samayansī
Hemaṇṭāṇam Paḍhame Samaye' Paḍivvajjaī. Jahā Samao Tahā 1. Āvaliyā, 2. Āṇāpāṇū,
3. Thove, 4. Lave, 5. Muhutte, 6. Ahoratte, 7. Pakkhe, 8. Māse, Ee Aṭṭha
Ālāvagā, Jahā Hemaṇṭāṇam Tahā Bhāṇiyavvā. Gimha Uu (k) Tā Jayā ṇam Jambudīve
Dīve Mandarasssa Pavvayassa Dāhiṇadḍhe Gimhāṇam Paḍhame Samaye Paḍivvajjaī, Tayā
ṇam Uttaraḍḍhe'avi Gimhāṇam Paḍhame Samaye Paḍivvajjaī. Jayā ṇam Uttaraḍḍhe
Gimhāṇam Paḍhame Samaye Paḍivvajjaī, Tayā ṇam Jambudīve Dīve Mandarasssa
Pavvayassa Puratthima-Pacchthime ṇam Aṇantara Purakkhad - Kāla - Samayansī
Gimhāṇam Paḍhame Samaye Paḍivvajjaī. (kh) Tā Jayā ṇam Jambudīve Dīve Mandarasssa
Pavvayassa Puratthime ṇam Gimhāṇam Paḍhame Samaye Paḍivvajjaī, Tayā ṇam
Pacchthime'avi Gimhāṇam Paḍhame Samaye Paḍivvajjaī. Jayā ṇam Pacchthime ṇam
Gimhāṇam Paḍhame Samaye Paḍivvajjaī, Tayā ṇam Jambudīve Dīve Mandarasssa
Pavvayassa Uttara-Dāhiṇe ṇam Aṇantara-Pacchākṛd-Kāla-Samayansī Gimhāṇam Paḍhame
Samaye Paḍivvajjaī. Jahā Samao Tahā 1. Āvaliyā, 2. Āṇāpāṇū, 3. Thove, 4. Lave,
5. Muhutte, 6. Ahoratte, 7. Pakkhe, 8. Māse, Ee Aṭṭha Ālāvagā, Jahā Gimhāṇam
Tahā Bhāṇiyavvā. Ayaṇāī (k) Tā Jayā ṇam Jambudīve Dīve Mandarasssa Pavvayassa
Dāhiṇadḍhe Paḍhame Ayaṇe Paḍivvajjaī, Tayā ṇam Uttaraḍḍhe'avi Paḍhame Ayaṇe
Paḍivvajjaī. Jayā ṇam Uttaraḍḍhe Paḍhame Ayaṇe Paḍivvajjaī, Tayā ṇam
Dāhiṇadḍhe'avi Paḍhame Ayaṇe Paḍivvajjaī. Jayā ṇam Uttaraḍḍhe Paḍhame Ayaṇe
Paḍivvajjaī, Tayā ṇam Jambudīve Dīve Mandarasssa Pavvayassa Puratthima-
Pacchthime ṇam Aṇantara Purakkhad - Kāla-Samayansī Paḍhame Ayaṇe Paḍivvajjaī.
(kh) Tā Jayā ṇam Jambudīve Dīve Mandarasssa Pavvayassa Puratthime ṇam Paḍhame
Ayaṇe Paḍivvajjaī, Tayā ṇam Pacchthime'avi Paḍhame Ayaṇe Paḍivvajjaī. Jayā ṇam
Pacchthime ṇam Paḍhame Ayaṇe Paḍivvajjaī, Tayā ṇam Jambudīve Dīve Mandarasssa
Pavvayassa Uttara-Dāhiṇe ṇam Aṇantara-Pacchākṛd-Kāla-Samayansī Paḍhame Ayaṇe
Paḍivvajjaī. 1,2. Upara Sūtra Me 'Paḍhame Samaye' Aṭṭha Sthāno Par Hai Un Sthāno
Me Nīce Likhe Ālāpak Kahen, Aur Praṭyek Ālāpak Ke Do Do Sūtra Upara Ke Samān
Kahen - 1. Paḍhamā Āvaliyā, 2. Paḍamo Āṇāpāṇū, 3. Paḍhamre Thove, 4. Paḍhame
Lave, 5. Paḍhame Muhutte, 6. Paḍhame Ahoratte, 7. Paḍhame Pakkhe, 8. Paḍhame
Māse. 3. Jahā Jahā Paḍhame Ayaṇe Hai, Vahā Vahā Dīcce Ayaṇe Kahen.

[66] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra] Just as the first ayana is described, so is the
second ayana. Just as the ayana, so is the year, the yuga, the vasas, the
vasasahasra, the vasasayasahasra, the puvva, the puvve, until the seas are
filled with the sisaphelia. Ussappini Now, when the ussappini rises in the south
of Mount Mandara on Jambudvipa, then the ussappini also rises in the north. When
the ussappini rises in the north, then there is no ussappini, no osappini in the
east-west of Jambudvipa on Mount Mandara. At that time, the Samanauaso are
established. Thus, the osappini. The salt sea Now, when the day is in the south
of the salt sea, then the day is also in the north of the salt sea. When the day
is in the north of the salt sea, then there is rain in the east-west of the salt
sea. The rest is the same as in Jambudvipa, until the osappini. Dhayi Khand Now,
in the Dhayi Khand, the sun - 1. (a) Where there is 'ussappini', there is
'osappini'. 2. 'Just as the rotation of Jambudvipa is described, so is the salt
sea described in the same way.' Navaran - With this understanding, all the
ayanas should be described. P. (a) In the salt sea, O Master! The sun - Does it
rise in the north-west and set in the south-west? (b) Does it rise in the south-
west and set in the north-west? (c) Does it rise in the south-west and set in
the north-west? (d) Does it rise in the north-west and set in the north-west? U.
(a-d) Yes, O Master! In the salt sea, the sun - It rises in the north-west and
sets in the south-west, until it rises in the north-west and sets in the north-
west. With this understanding, it should be understood - until P. (a) When, O
Master! the first ussappini rises in the south of the salt sea, then does the
first ussappini also rise in the north? (b) When the first ussappini rises in
the north, then there is no osappini, no ussappini in the east-west of the salt
sea? Are the Samanauaso established at that time? U. Yes, O Master! That should
be said until the Samanauaso! - Bhag. S. 5, U. 1, Su. 22

Page #118 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
[Aṣṭama Prābhṛta] They rise in the east, move towards the south, until they set
in the west, and rise in the east again. On the day when the sun rises in the
south on the Mandara mountain in the Dhāyisaṇḍa island, it sets in the north on
the same day. On the day when the sun rises in the north, it sets in the east-
west direction on the Mandara mountain in the Dhāyisaṇḍa island. The same is
true for all the islands, from Jambudvīpa to Osappinī. The same is true for the
oceans, like the salt ocean. In the Abbhantar-Pukkharaḍḍha island, the sun rises
in the east, moves towards the south, until it sets in the west, and rises in
the east again. On the day when the sun rises in the south on the Mandara
mountain in the Abbhantar-Pukkharaḍḍha island, it sets in the north on the same
day. On the day when the sun rises in the north, it sets in the east-west
direction on the Mandara mountain in the Abbhantar-Pukkharaḍḍha island. The same
is true for all the islands, from Jambudvīpa to Osappinī.

| Romanization (original text) |

## Ninth Chapter: The Elimination of the Doubt Regarding the Sun's Rays - 30.
**Q:** How does the sun eliminate the doubt?  **A:** There are three views on
this matter:  1. Some say that the beings who are touched by the sun's rays
become heated, and these heated beings then heat the external beings. 2. Others
say that the beings who are touched by the sun's rays do not become heated, and
these unheated beings then heat the external beings. 3. Still others say that
the beings who are touched by the sun's rays become heated in a certain way, but
not in another way. Those who are heated in a certain way then heat the external
beings in that way, and those who are not heated in that way do not heat the
external beings in that way.  However, we say that the rays of the sun and moon,
which are emitted from the bodies of the gods, are scattered and spread out.
From the space between these rays, other rays emerge. These emerging rays, which
are scattered and spread out, then heat the external beings.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

paNNattAo, taM jahA - tatthege evamAhaMsu - 1. tAje NaM poggalA sUriyassa lesaM
phusaMti, te NaM poggalA saMtappaMti, te NaM poggalA saMtappamANA tadaNaMtarAiM
bAhirAI poggalAI saMtAveMtIti, esa NaM se samie tAvakkhette ege evamAhaMsu, eo
puNa evamAhaMsu - 2. tA je NaM poggalA sUriyassa lesaM phusaMti, te NaM poggalA
no saMtappaMti, te NaM poggalA . asaMtappamANA tadaNaMtarAI bAhirAI poggalAI
saMtAveMtIti, - esa NaM se samie tAvakkhette ege evamAhaMsu, ege puNa evamAhaMsu
- 3. tA je NaM poggalA sUriyassa lesaM phusaMti, te NaM poggalA atthegaiyA
saMtappaMti, atthegaiyA no saMtappaMti, tattha atthegaiyA saMtappamANA
tadaNaMtarAI bAhirAI poggalAI atthegayAiM saMtAveMti, atthegayAiM no

## Ninth Chapter  **Porisi-chchhaya-nivattana**  **31.**  **Q.** How does the
sun's porisi-chchhaya disappear?  **A.** There are twenty-nine different views
on this matter.  **Some say:**  1. The sun's porisi-chchhaya disappears in a
moment.  **Others say:**  2. The sun's porisi-chchhaya disappears in a muhurta.
These views are all to be rejected because they are contradictory.  **Some
say:**  25. The sun's porisi-chchhaya disappears in a ussappini-osappini.
**Others say:**  **We say:**  The sun's porisi-chchhaya disappears when:  1. The
height and the shadow are equal. 2. The height and the shadow are equal. 3. The
shadow and the height are equal.  **A.** There are two views on this matter.
**Some say:**  (a) 1. There are days when the sun's porisi-chchhaya disappears
four times. (b) There are days when the sun's porisi-chchhaya disappears twice.
**Others say:**  (a) 2. There are days when the sun's porisi-chchhaya disappears
twice.  1. Surya. Pa. 6. Su. 27 2. According to the compilation style of Surya
Prajnapti, there should be a question here. However, this question is not found
in any manuscript. Therefore, it is assumed that the question is missing. The
commentators of Surya Prajnapti are silent on this matter. Therefore, the space
for the question is left blank. If the question is found in any manuscript,
please inform the scholars so that it can be added in the next edition.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

70 ] [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra (b) Is there any increase in the size of the sun on
the days of the Jains, on the days of the Jains? Some say - (a) 1. There is an
increase in the size of the sun on the days of the Jains, on the days of the
Jains. (b) There is an increase in the size of the sun on the days of the Jains,
on the days of the Jains. They say, (a) When the sun travels in the inner
circle, it is 18 muhurtas long on the day of the Jain, and 12 muhurtas long on
the night of the Jain. On that day, the sun increases in size by four
porisichchhaya, as follows: - at the time of sunrise and at the time of sunset,
the size increases, but does not decrease.   (b) When the sun travels in the
outer circle, it is 18 muhurtas long on the day of the Jain, and 12 muhurtas
long on the night of the Jain. On that day, the sun increases in size by two
porisichchhaya, as follows: - at the time of sunrise and at the time of sunset,
the size increases, but does not decrease. Some say - 2. There is an increase in
the size of the sun on the days of the Jains, on the days of the Jains. There is
no increase in the size of the sun on the days of the Jains, on the days of the
Jains. They say, [a] When the sun travels in the inner circle, it is 18 muhurtas
long on the day of the Jain, and 12 muhurtas long on the night of the Jain. On
that day, the sun increases in size by two porisichchhaya, as follows: - at the
time of sunrise and at the time of sunset, the size increases, but does not
decrease. [b] When the sun travels in the outer circle, it is 18 muhurtas long
on the day of the Jain, and 12 muhurtas long on the night of the Jain. On that
day, the sun does not increase in size, as follows: - at the time of sunrise and
at the time of sunset,
