## Fifteenth Praabhrut  **The Relative Speed of the Moon, Sun, Planets,
Constellations, and Stars**  **Q:** How do these (Moon, Sun, Planets,
Constellations, and Stars) move in relation to each other?  **A:** The Moon
moves faster than the Sun, the Sun faster than the Planets, the Planets faster
than the Constellations, and the Constellations faster than the Stars. The Moon
is the slowest of all, and the Stars are the fastest.  **Q:** How many parts of
its own circle does the Moon traverse in a Muhurta (48 minutes)?  **A:** The
Moon traverses 77/64 parts of its own circle in a Muhurta. Its circle is 100,000
yojanas in circumference.  **Q:** How many parts of its own circle does the Sun
traverse in a Muhurta?  **A:** The Sun traverses 18/32 parts of its own circle
in a Muhurta. Its circle is 100,000 yojanas in circumference.  **Q:** Which of
these (Moon, Sun, Planets, Constellations, and Stars) moves faster or slower
than the others?  **A:** The Moon moves faster than the Sun, the Sun faster than
the Planets, the Planets faster than the Constellations, and the Constellations
faster than the Stars. The Moon is the slowest of all, and the Stars are the
fastest.  **Note:** The text does not mention the speed of the Planets. The
commentator explains that the Planets have irregular and unpredictable
movements, so their speed cannot be calculated in the same way as the Moon, Sun,
Constellations, and Stars.   **Commentary:**  The Planets move in a curved and
irregular manner, so their speed cannot be calculated in the same way as the
Moon, Sun, Constellations, and Stars. The text states that the Moon moves faster
than the Sun, the Sun faster than the Planets, and so on. The Planets are all
slower than the Moon.  **Further Explanation:**  * The Moon traverses 77/64
parts of its own circle in a Muhurta. * The Sun traverses 18/32 parts of its own
circle in a Muhurta. * The Planets have irregular and unpredictable movements,
so their speed cannot be calculated in the same way as the Moon, Sun,
Constellations, and Stars. * The Constellations are slower than the Planets. *
The Stars are the fastest of all.

##  Translation:  **158]**  **3. Q. How many parts of a *nakṣatra* does the moon
traverse in a *muhūrta*?**  **A.** The moon traverses 18 and 1/3 parts of the
*nakṣatra* in a *muhūrta*. The moon traverses 19 parts of the *maṇḍala* in
100,000 *maṇḍalas*.  **Specific Differences in the Motion of the Sun, Moon, and
*Nakṣatras***  **84**  **(Sun-Moon-Nakṣatra)**  **1. Q. What is the difference
in the motion of the moon and the sun when they are in conjunction?**  **A.**
The difference is 22 parts.  **2. Q. What is the difference in the motion of the
moon and the *nakṣatra* when they are in conjunction?**  **A.** The difference
is 77 parts.  **3. Q. What is the difference in the motion of the sun and the
*nakṣatra* when they are in conjunction?**  **A.** The difference is 5 parts.
**Conjunction of the Moon and *Nakṣatras***  When the moon is in conjunction
with a *nakṣatra* in the eastern part of the sky, it will be in conjunction with
the *nakṣatra* for 9 *muhūrtas* and 77 parts of a *muhūrta*. The conjunction
will then be in the *anupariyatṭa* state. When the conjunction is in the
*anupariyatṭa* state, it will be in the *vippajahaḍa* state until it becomes a
*vigayajogī*.  When the moon is in conjunction with a *nakṣatra* in the eastern
part of the sky, it will be in conjunction with the *nakṣatra* for 30
*muhūrtas*. The conjunction will then be in the *anupariyatṭa* state. When the
conjunction is in the *anupariyatṭa* state, it will be in the *vippajahaḍa*
state until it becomes a *vigayajogī*.  This should be applied to the 15th,
30th, and 45th *muhūrtas*. It should be said that the moon is in conjunction
with the *nakṣatra* until the *Uttaraṣāḍhā* *nakṣatra*.  **Conjunction of the
Moon and Planets**  **84. Q. When the moon is in conjunction with a planet in
the eastern part of the sky, what is the duration of the conjunction?**  **A.**
When the moon is in conjunction with a planet in the eastern part of the sky,
the conjunction will be in the *anupariyatṭa* state. When the conjunction is in
the *anupariyatṭa* state, it will be in the *vippajahaḍa* state until it becomes
a *vigayajogī*.  **Conjunction of the Sun and *Nakṣatras***  When the sun is in
conjunction with a *nakṣatra* in the eastern part of the sky, it will be in
conjunction with the *nakṣatra* for...  **1. The original text states that the
motion of the stars is the fastest, but it does not mention the measure of the
motion. The commentator has also not said anything about this.**

## Fifteenth Praabhrut  [159]  In the eastern part, when the sun sets, it joins
with the moon for four days and six muhurtas. When it joins, it gradually moves
away from the moon. When it moves away, it leaves the moon. The moon becomes
free from the sun's influence.  Thus, in six days and twenty-one muhurtas, in
thirteen days and twelve muhurtas, and in twenty days and three muhurtas, all
should be said as follows:  When the sun sets in the Uttaraashaadha Nakshatra,
it sets in the eastern part. When it sets in the eastern part, it joins with the
moon for twenty days and three muhurtas. When it joins, it gradually moves away
from the moon. When it moves away, it leaves the moon. The moon becomes free
from the sun's influence. The sun's influence on the moon is the time of its
departure.  When the sun sets in the moon's setting, it sets in the eastern
part. When it sets in the eastern part, it joins with the moon. When it joins,
it gradually moves away from the moon. When it moves away, it leaves the moon.
The moon becomes free from the sun's influence.  **A - The Moon's, Sun's, and
Nakshatra's Movement in a Nakshatra Month**  85.  **The number of circles of the
moon, sun, and nakshatra in five nakshatra months**  1. Q. How many circles does
the moon make in a nakshatra month? A. It makes thirteen circles and sixty-seven
parts of a circle.  2. Q. How many circles does the sun make in a nakshatra
month? A. It makes thirteen circles and forty-four parts of a circle.  3. Q. How
many circles does the nakshatra make in a nakshatra month? A. It makes thirteen
circles and forty-five parts of a circle.  **B - The Moon's, Sun's, and
Nakshatra's Movement in a Chandra Month**  1. Q. How many circles does the moon
make in a chandra month? A. It makes fourteen and one-fourth circles and one
part of a circle.  2. Q. How many circles does the sun make in a chandra month?
A. It makes thirteen and one-fourth circles and one part of a circle.  3. Q. How
many circles does the nakshatra make in a chandra month? A. It makes fifteen and
one-fourth circles and six parts of a circle.  **C - The Moon's, Sun's, and
Nakshatra's Movement in an Udu Month**  1. Q. How many circles does the moon
make in an udu month? A. It makes fourteen circles and thirty-one parts of a
circle.  2. Q. How many circles does the sun make in an udu month?

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

##  [Surya Prajnapti Sutra]  **160]**  **Q. How many mandalas does the moon
traverse in a *panna-rasa* month?** **A.** It traverses fifteen mandalas, and
three and a half *bhagas* of a mandala.  **Q. How many mandalas does the sun
traverse in a *panna-rasa* month?** **A.** It traverses fifteen mandalas, and
five and thirty-two hundredths *bhagas* of a mandala.  **Q. How many mandalas
does the *nakshatra* traverse in a *panna-rasa* month?** **A.** It traverses
fifteen mandalas, and five and thirty-two hundredths *bhagas* of a mandala.
**Q. How many mandalas does the moon traverse in an *abhivaddiya* month?**
**A.** It traverses fifteen mandalas, and sixty-three *bhagas* of a mandala.
**Q. How many mandalas does the sun traverse in an *abhivaddiya* month?** **A.**
It traverses sixteen mandalas, minus three *bhagas*, and two hundred and eighty-
eight *bhagas* of a mandala.  **Q. How many mandalas does the *nakshatra*
traverse in an *abhivaddiya* month?** **A.** It traverses sixteen mandalas, and
forty-one hundredths *bhagas*, fourteen and eighty-eight *bhagas* of a mandala.
**Q. How many mandalas does the moon traverse in a single *ahoratra*?** **A.**
It traverses half a mandala, minus thirty-one *bhagas*, and nine and fifteen
hundredths *bhagas* of a mandala.  **Q. How many mandalas does the sun traverse
in a single *ahoratra*?** **A.** It traverses half a mandala.  **Q. How many
mandalas does the *nakshatra* traverse in a single *ahoratra*?** **A.** It
traverses half a mandala, minus two *bhagas*, and seven and thirty-two
hundredths *bhagas* of a mandala.  **Q. How many *ahoratras* does the moon take
to traverse a single mandala?** **A.** It takes two *ahoratras*, minus thirty-
one *bhagas*, and four and forty-eight hundredths *bhagas* of an *ahoratra*.
**Q. How many *ahoratras* does the sun take to traverse a single mandala?**

[ Fifteenth Praabhrut ] [ 161 U. Ta dohin ahorattehin charai. 3. P. Ta egamegam
mandalam nakkhatte katihin ahorattehin charai? U. Ta dohin ahorattehin charai,
dohin bhaagehin unehin tihin sattasattahin saehin rainddiehin chetta.
Egamegajuge chand-sur-nakkhattaanam mandalacharam 1. P. Ta juge nam chande kai
mandalaain charai? U. Ta atthachulasie mandalasae charai. 2. P. Ta juge nam sure
kai mandalaain charai? U. Ta nav-pannarasamandalasae charai. 3. P. Ta juge nam
nakkhatte kai mandalaain charai? U. Ta attarasa panatise dubhagamandalasae
charai. Icchesa muhuttagai rikkh-udamas-rainddiy-jugamandal-pavibhatti sigdhgai
vaththa ahie tti bemi.

egamegajuge caMda-sUra-NakkhattANaM maMDalacAraM 1. pa. tA juge NaM caMde kai
maMDalAiM carai ? u. tA aTThaculasIe maMDalasae cri| 2. pa. tA juge NaM sure kai
maMDalAiM carai ? u. tA Nava-paNNarasamaMDalasae cri| 3. pa. tA juge NaM
Nakkhatte kai maMDalAiM carai ? u. tA aTThArasa paNatIse dubhAgamaMDalasae cri|
iccesA muhuttagaI rikkha-uDamAsa-rAiMdiya-jugamaMDala-pavibhattI sigdhagaI
vattha Ahie tti bemi|

The Sixteenth Praabhrut Signs of Doshanai 87. 1. P. How are the signs of
Doshanai? Tell me. U. They are Chandalesai. 2. P. Chandalesai and Doshanai, are
they one in meaning or in signs? U. They are one in meaning and one in signs. 1.
P. How are the signs of Sooralesa? Tell me. U. They are Sooralesai and Ayavei.
2. P. Sooralesai and Ayavei, are they one in meaning or in signs? U. They are
one in meaning and one in signs. 1. P. How are the signs of Chhaya? Tell me. U.
They are Chhaya and Andhkarai. 2. P. Chhaya and Andhkarai, are they one in
meaning or in signs? U. They are one in meaning and one in signs.

**Seventy-seventh Prabhṛta**  In the context of the sun and moon, what are their
distinct or shared characteristics?  The answer: Indeed, these celestial bodies
have certain qualities that can be elaborated upon as follows:  1. At the very
elemental level, the moon and sun share similarities, but as their journey
progresses, they separate and exhibit their unique attributes; this has been
stated.  2. In brief spans of time, the moon and sun reflect differences in
behavior; this has been noted.  3. It is said that in a similar manner as above,
so too can it be observed in the lower aspects and in the previously discussed
twenty-five aspects of the Prabhṛta, up till the ultimate particle of existence
according to scriptures.  4. In brief: the moon and sun exhibit distinctions
based on their phases, or qualitative aspects, unequally, and this is how they
relate; this has been stated. 5. Hence, in a minute measure of time, the moon
and sun also articulate their differences and shared characteristics; this is
acknowledged.  6. (Continued comments on the next page)

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

[Seventeenth Praabhrut] [165] They said thus: We are of this opinion and we
declare - those Chandīma-Sūriya gods are Mahīḍḍiya, Mahājuiyā-Mahābala,
Mahājasa, Mahāsaukka, Mahāṇubhāva. They are Vara Khatthadhara, Varamalladhara,
Varagandhaghara, Varābharaṇadhara, and at the time of the Avvochittiṇayattthaya,
some are born, some die, and the cycle of birth and death continues, thus we
declare.

| Romanization (original text) |

The eighteenth **Praabhrut** (chapter) **Chandayichchaina** (section)
**Bhoomibhagao** (topic) **Uddhattam** (question) 89. **P. Ta Kaham Te Ucchatte
Aahiteti Vadeja?** (How high are they?) **U.** (Answer) **Tath Khulu Imaao
Panavinsam Padivattio, Pannaattao, Tanjaha -** (There are nineteen opinions, as
follows) **Tathege Evam Ahansu - 1. To Egam Joyanasahas Suure Uddhe Ucchattenam,
Divaddham Chaande, Ege Evam Asu.** (Some say that the Sun is one **Joyanasahas**
(league) high, and the Moon is half that.) **Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 2. Ta Do
Joyanasahassai Suure Uddham Ucchattenam, Addatijai Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.**
(Some say that the Sun is two **Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is one and a
half that.) **Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 3. Ta Tinni Joyanasahassai Suure Uddham
Ucchattenam, Adhutthai Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is
three **Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is two and a half that.) **Ege Pun Evam
Ahansu - 4. Ta Chattari Joyanasahassain Suure Uddham Ucchattenam, Addhapanamaai
Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is four **Joyanasahas** high,
and the Moon is three and a half that.) **Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 5. Ta Panch
Joyanasahassain Suure Uddhe Ucchattenam, Addhachhatthai Chaande, Ege Evam
Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is five **Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is
four and a half that.) **Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 6. Ta Chha Joyanasahassai Suure
Uddham Ucchattenam, Addhasattamaai Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.** (Some say that
the Sun is six **Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is five and a half that.)
**Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 7. Ta Sattajoyanasahassain Suure Uddham Ucchattenam,
Advatthamaim Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is seven
**Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is six and a half that.) **Ege Pun Evam
Ahansu - 8. Ta Atth Joyanasahassai Suure Uddhe Ucchattenam, Addhanavamaim
Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is eight **Joyanasahas**
high, and the Moon is seven and a half that.) **Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 9. Ta
Navajoyanasahassain Suure Uddham Ucchattenam, Addhadasamaim Chaande, Ege Evam
Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is nine **Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is
eight and a half that.)

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 aThArahavA~ prAbhRta caMdAiccAiNaM bhUmibhAgAo uDDhattaM 89. pa. tA kahaM te
uccatte Ahiteti vadejA ? u. tattha khalu imAo paNavIsaM paDivattio, paNNattAo,
taMjahA - tatthege evamAhaMsu - 1. to egaM joyaNasahassa sUre uDDhe uccatteNaM,
divaDDhaM caMde, ege evmaasu| ege puNa evamAhaMsu - 2. tA do joyaNasahassAI sUre
uDDhaM uccatteNaM, aDDAtijAI caMde, ege evmaahNsu| _ ege puNa evamAhaMsu - 3. tA
tinni joyaNasahassAI sUre uDDhaM uccatteNaM, adhuTThAI caMde, ege evmaahNsu| _

[The Eighteenth Prabhrita] [167] Some say thus - 10. The sun is ten thousand
yojanas high in height, and the moon is half a yojana less, some say thus. Some
say thus - 11. The sun is eleven thousand yojanas high in height, and the moon
is half a yojana less, some say thus. These are to be understood in this manner
- 12. The sun is twelve, and the moon is half a yojana less than thirteen, 13.
The sun is thirteen, and the moon is half a yojana less than fourteen, 14. The
sun is fourteen, and the moon is half a yojana less than fifteen, 15. The sun is
fifteen, and the moon is half a yojana less than sixteen, 16. The sun is
sixteen, and the moon is half a yojana less than seventeen, 17. The sun is
seventeen, and the moon is half a yojana less than eighteen, 18. The sun is
eighteen, and the moon is half a yojana less than nineteen, 19. The sun is
nineteen, and the moon is half a yojana less than twenty, 20. The sun is twenty,
and the moon is half a yojana less than twenty-one, 21. The sun is twenty-one,
and the moon is half a yojana less than twenty-two, 22. The sun is twenty-two,
and the moon is half a yojana less than twenty-three, 23. The sun is twenty-
three, and the moon is half a yojana less than twenty-four, 24. The sun is
twenty-four, and the moon is half a yojana less than twenty-five, some say thus
- 25. The sun is twenty-five thousand yojanas high in height, and the moon is
half a yojana less than twenty-six, some say thus. We, however, say thus - In
this Ratnaprabha earth, the regions of the earth's surface extend to seventy-two
hundred yojanas upwards, and they move about in the lower Taravimanas. From the
Chandravimana, they rise up twenty yojanas upwards and move about in the upper
Tararupas. Similarly, in the longitudinal and latitudinal dimensions, they move
about in the innumerable Jyotisavisaya, the region of luminous bodies, extending
to ten hundred yojanas in breadth. The reasons for the unequal and equal nature
of the stars are ninety. There are, indeed, among the devas of the moon and the
sun - some who are inferior to the Tararupas, some who are equal, and some who
are equal as well as inferior to the Tararupas.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

[168] [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra ] Above the star-shaped vehicles, there are also,
some smaller, some equal, some larger. Above the star-shaped vehicles, there are
also, some smaller, some equal, some larger. As the gods' observance of the
rules of penance and celibacy is weak, so they are smaller or equal. Thus, the
gods of the moon and sun, there are also, some smaller, some equal, some larger.
Above the star-shaped vehicles, there are also, some smaller, some equal, some
larger. The family of the moon, planets and stars is 91. How many families of
planets are assigned to each moon god? How many families of constellations are
assigned? How many families of stars are assigned? Each moon god has 88 families
of planets assigned. 88 families of constellations are assigned. 64,000, 900 and
50 more. One family, of countless stars. Families are assigned. 1. 'Above'
refers to the moon and sun vehicles. 2. As those who have practiced weak penance
and celibacy in the past, have attained the state of being a god who presides
over star-shaped vehicles, they are inferior to the moon and sun gods in terms
of brilliance and other qualities. Those who have practiced intense penance and
celibacy in the past, have attained the state of being a god who presides over
star-shaped vehicles, they are equal to the moon and sun gods in terms of
brilliance and other qualities. This is not unreasonable. Even in the human
world, some people, due to the merit accumulated in past lives, attain kingship,
but they are equal in power to the king. 3. Jambu. Vakh. 7, Su. 163 4. a. 'Each
moon and sun god has 88 families of planets assigned.' - Sam. 88, Su. 1 b. Each
moon and sun god... (Remaining notes on the next page)

| Romanization (original text) |

[Eighteenth Praabhrut] [169 How many yojanas away from the Mandar mountain does
the sun travel? _A. The sun travels 11 yojanas and 21 yojanas away from the
Mandar mountain.1 What is the distance between the sun and the moon? P. How many
yojanas away from the moon are the stars located? U. The stars are located 11
yojanas and 11 yojanas away from the moon.2 What is the distance between the
stars? 93. 1 P. In Jambudvipa, which star travels in the innermost circle? 2 P.
Which star travels in the outermost circle? • 3 P. Which star travels in the
uppermost circle? 4 P. Which star travels in the lowermost circle? 1 U. Abhijit
star travels in the innermost circle. U. The verses - 88 and 28 are the stars.
One hundred and one families, I will tell you about these stars. Thirty-six
thousand, nine hundred and five hundred. One hundred and one families, the
number of stars is countless. - - Jiwa.P.3, U. 2, Su.194 G. Jiwaabhigaman Prati.
3, U.2, Su. 194 - 'The questions and answers are for both the moon and the sun.
In the original, there is only a symbol for the question and two verses as the
answer.' In the commentary - 'This is the symbol for the question - Egmegasas N.
Bhanta! Chandim-Suriyasya, etc. The commentator's explanation regarding this
symbol is - 'Ekaikasya Bhadant! Chandra-Suryaasya' by this word, just as the
moon is the lord of the stars, so is the sun, because of his Indrahood ....
....... Here, there is a lot of difference in reading in the books and the
verses are also corrupted in many books, therefore, to understand the difference
in reading as it is, and to extract the corrupted verses, even these easy ones
are being separated ..... 1. Sam. S. 11, Su. 3 K. Sam. S. 11, Su. 2 Kh. Jambu.
Vakkh.7, Su. 154 'Sarvaabhyantara, Sarvebhyo Mandalebyo Abhyantara,
Sarvaabhyantara, by this, the second and other circle-traveling sun is
described' 'Although Abhijit, etc., twelve stars are said to be the innermost
circle-traveling stars, still, this is located in the Meru direction, and it
travels in the circle, therefore, it is said to be the innermost circle-
traveling star'.

## 170] [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra. 2. U. In the Mrigashira constellation, the
charan moves outside everything. 3. U. In the Saayi constellation, the charan
moves above everything. 4. U. In the Bharani constellation, the charan moves
inside everything. The arrangement of the Chandra-Surya-Graha-Nakshatra Vimana
is 94. P. What is the arrangement of the Chandra Vimana? U. It is arranged in
the form of an Ardha-Kavitthaga, with all the sides falling in the form of an
Abhhuga-Yamusya-Pahasiya, adorned with various jewels and precious stones, with
Y-Vijay-Vejayanti-Padaga flags and umbrellas, rising high above the sky, with a
net of jewels and a cage of jewels, with a lotus-like arrangement of jewels,
with a white-colored moon-like appearance, inside and outside, with a beautiful
appearance, with a beautiful appearance, with a beautiful appearance. Similarly,
the Surya Vimana, the Graha Vimana, the Nakshatra Vimana, and the Tara Vimana.
'Sarvabahya-Sarvato Nakshatramandalikaaya Bahischcharam Charati'. 'Although the
Mrigashira and other constellations, which are the charans of the fifteen
mandalas, are said to be two stars each in the middle of the four stars of
Purvashadha and Uttarashadha, yet this is said to be Sarvabahya because it moves
in the direction of the salt water, being situated outside the other
constellations.' K. 'In the Jyotishchakra, which is 100 yojanas in length, the
area of the constellations is 4 yojanas in length, and in relation to that, the
lower and upper parts of the said constellations are to be known.' The quoted
passage is from the Jambudvipa Vyakhyana 7, Sutra 165 Tika. Kh. This Sutra of
the Surya Prajnapti is similar to Sutra 165 of the Jambudvipa Prajnapti. How do
the Ardha-Kavitthaga houses of the Gahaos not appear in the direction of the
rising moon, the Vimana of the Sun and Moon, which are situated in the
horizontal plane? The Ardha-Kavitthaga house is elevated, and the platform is
above it. The circular line is drawn from there, and the distance is equal in
all directions. This is a special explanation given by Jinabhadra Ganikashama
Shraman, with Akshapurassara. 'If the Chandra Vimana is situated in the form of
an Ardha-Kavitthaga, which is half the size of a Pitthaphala, then at the time
of sunrise or sunset, or if it is revolving horizontally during the full moon,
why is the half-Pitthaphala shape not visible?' Because the circular shape is
visible from the top of the head, because the part of the half-Pitthaphala that
is far away is not visible due to its distance, it is said to be circular. Here,
the half-Pitthaphala shape of the Chandra Vimana is not to be understood as a
whole, but the platform of the Chandra Vimana, and above the platform is the
palace of the Chandradeva, the king of the Jyotishchakra, and that palace is
arranged in such a way that it becomes circular with the platform, and due to
its distance, it appears to be circular to the people from a distance, so there
is no fault. - Surya Tika, Jambudvipa Vyakhyana 7, Sutra 125 4.

## The Eighteenth Praabhrut  **Dimensions of the Moon-Vehicle, Sun-Vehicle,
Earth-Vehicle, and Star-Vehicles**  **Q. A.** What is the **Aayam-Vikkhambha**
(length and breadth) of the Moon-Vehicle? **B.** What is its **Parikkheva**
(circumference)? **C.** What is its **Baahalla** (thickness)?  **A. A.** It is
**56/1** **Yojanas** in **Aayam-Vikkhambha**. **B.** It is **three times** its
**Aayam-Vikkhambha** plus **one** **Yojana** in **Parikkheva**. **C.** It is
**28/1** **Yojanas** in **Baahalla**.  **Q. A.** What is the **Aayam-
Vikkhambha** of the Sun-Vehicle? **B.** What is its **Parikkheva**? **C.** What
is its **Baahalla**?  **A. A.** It is **81/2** **Yojanas** in **Aayam-
Vikkhambha**. **B.** It is **three times** its **Aayam-Vikkhambha** plus **one**
**Yojana** in **Parikkheva**. **C.** It is **24/1** **Yojanas** in **Baahalla**.
**Q. A.** What is the **Aayam-Vikkhambha** of the Earth-Vehicle? **B.** What is
its **Parikkheva**? **C.** What is its **Baahalla**?  **A. A.** It is **1/2**
**Yojana** in **Aayam-Vikkhambha**. **B.** It is **three times** its **Aayam-
Vikkhambha** plus **one** **Yojana** in **Parikkheva**.  **Q. A.** What is the
**Aayam-Vikkhambha** of the Moon-Sphere? **B.** What is its **Parikkheva**?
**C.** What is its **Baahalla**?  **A. A.** It is **56/61** **Yojanas** in
**Aayam-Vikkhambha**. **B.** It is **three times** its **Aayam-Vikkhambha** plus
**one** **Yojana** in **Parikkheva**. **C.** It is **28/61** **Yojanas** in
**Baahalla**.  The Moon-Sphere is divided into **61** parts.  This Sutra clearly
states that the Moon-Vehicle and the Moon-Sphere are the same.  **Jambudvipa-
Vyakhyana 7, Sutra 145** **Samavayanga 61, Sutra 3**  **[171]**

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

## 172] [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra G. How much is the extent of the Kosha? P. K.
What is the extent of the Tanakkhatta Vimana in terms of its length and breadth?
Kh. What is its circumference? G. How much is its extent? U. K. The Kosha is the
extent of its length and breadth. Kh. Its circumference is three times its
extent plus a little more. G. Its extent is half a Kosha. P. K. What is the
extent of the Tara Vimana in terms of its length and breadth? Kh. What is its
circumference? G. How much is its extent? U. K. The Tara Vimana is half a Kosha
in terms of its length and breadth. Kh. Its circumference is three times its
extent plus a little more. G. Its extent is five Dhanushya. The Vimana of the
Moon, Sun, Planets and Stars. P. How many Deva Sahasri carry the Moon Vimana? U.
Sixteen Deva Sahasri carry it, such as - 1. P. K. Venerable Sir! What is the
extent of the Moon Vimana in terms of its length and breadth? What is its
extent? U. The Moon Mandala is fifty-six Bhae in diameter. Its extent is twenty-
eight Bhae. ||1|| The Sun Mandala is forty-nine Bhae in diameter. Its extent is
twenty-four Bhae. ||2|| The extent of the Planets and Stars is two Kosha. The
extent of the Stars is the same as their extent. ||3|| - Jambudvipa Vyakhyana 7,
Su. 165 'The extent of one Yojana is one-sixth of one Angula. The extent of the
Moon Mandala is fifty-six parts of one Yojana. The extent of the Sun Mandala is
forty-nine parts of one Yojana. The extent of the Planets and Stars is two
Kosha. The extent of the Stars is the same as their extent.' 'The circumference
of a circle is three times its diameter plus a little more.' This explanation is
given by the commentator of the Jambudvipa Prajnapti for the above mentioned
Sutra. Kh. Although the Jiva. P. 3, U. 2, Su. 197 are question-answer Sutras,
but they use the word 'Bhanta' and 'Go-yama' more.

## The Eighteenth Praabhrut  **1. P.** **U.** Four Deva-sahasris carry it from
the east, with lion-like faces. Four Deva-sahasris carry it from the south, with
elephant-like faces. Four Deva-sahasris carry it from the west, with bull-like
faces. Four Deva-sahasris carry it from the north, with horse-like faces. Thus,
the Surya-vimana also...  **P.** How many Deva-sahasris carry the Gah-vimana?
**U.** Eight Deva-sahasris carry it, as follows: Two Deva-sahasris carry it from
the east, with lion-like faces, and so on... Two Deva-sahasris carry it from the
north, with horse-like faces.  **P.** How many Deva-sahasris carry the
Nakshatra-vimana? **U.** Four Deva-sahasris carry it, as follows: One Deva-
sahasri carries it from the east, with lion-like faces, and so on... One Deva-
sahasri carries it from the north, with horse-like faces.  **P.** How many Deva-
sahasris carry the Tara-vimana? **U.** Two Deva-sahasris carry it, as follows:
Five Deva-sayas carry it from the east, with lion-like faces, and so on... Five
Deva-sayas carry it from the north, with horse-like faces.  **P.** How many
Deva-sahasris carry the Chandra-vimana, Bhante? **U.** Sixteen Deva-sahasris
carry it, Gotama!  The Chandra-vimana, from the east, has... **Se-a-na**
(beautiful), **Subhaga-na** (auspicious), **Supphaba-na** (radiant),
**Sankhatala-vimala-nimmala-dadhishana-gokhira-phena-rayana-nigara-prabhasa-na**
(with a brilliance like conch-shell, pure, spotless, like curds, milk, foam,
jewels, and mountains), **Thira-lattha-patta-vatta-piva-susilittha-visittha-
tikkha-daadha-vidambia-muha-na** (with firm, strong, broad, round, wide, well-
polished, excellent, sharp, strong, and smiling faces), **Rantuppa-lapatta-mauy-
sumala-talu-jiha-na** (with lips, teeth, soft, beautiful palates, and tongues),
**Mah-guli-a-pingala-kkha-na** (with large, round, and reddish eyes), **Pivara-
voru-padipunna-viula-kandha-na** (with wide, full, and broad shoulders)...

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 aThArahavA~ prAbhRta ] 1. pa. u. puratthimeNaM sIharUvadhArINaM cattAri
devasAhassIo parivahaMti, dAhiNeNaM gayarUvadhArINaM cattAri devasAhassIo

Page #225 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
The translation preserving the Jain terms is as follows:  The four divine
chariots of the Sihara-roopa (lion-formed) deities, carrying the charming,
beautiful, delicate, marked, excellent, variegated, kesara-like, shining,
raised, well-formed, expanded, long-tailed, vairamaya (diamond-like), shining,
sharp-toothed, sharp-fanged, tapanija (fiery) tongued, tapanija palated,
tapanija well-formed, well-joined, beautiful, lustful, desiring, mind-going,
mind-charming, victorious, amrita (nectar)-powered, heroic, manly-effort-making,
with a loud, sweet, charming sound of roaring, fill the sky and beautify the
directions.   The four divine chariots of the Gaya-roopa (bull-formed) deities,
carrying the beautiful, auspicious, bright, moving, trembling, proud-gait, well-
formed, marked, excellent, jewel-adorned, hanging, swinging, tinkling bell-
sounds, charming, with proper proportions, excellent-marked, beautiful-haired,
well-formed, sharp-tusked, diamond-like, variegated, jewel-crowned, necklace-
adorned, pure, diamond-like, sharp-pointed, ankusa (elephant-goad) -like, well-
bound, proud-armed, pure, dense, diamond-like, saliva-licking, well-formed,
marked, excellent, jewel-like, silver-bound, hanging bell-pairs, with sweet,
charming sounds, well-proportioned, excellent-marked, beautiful-haired, light,
agile, marked, excellent, jewel-like, fiery-tongued, fiery-palated, fiery well-
formed, beautiful, desiring, mind-going, mind-charming, victorious, amrita
(nectar)-powered, heroic, manly-effort-making, with a deep, rumbling, sweet,
charming sound, fill the sky and beautify the directions.

[The Eighteenth Prabhrita]  The chariots of the deities, adorned with beautiful
and melodious bells, resplendent with golden and jeweled bells, with the
garlands of fragrant flowers like lotus and jasmine, with excellent horses, of
various kinds, with teeth made of ivory, with tongues that move gracefully, with
palates that move gracefully, with eyes that shine beautifully, desirable,
delightful, enchanting, and charming, of immortal gait, of immense strength,
valor, and heroic prowess, roaring with a deep and captivating voice, filling
the sky with their sweet and enchanting sound, and illuminating the directions,
carry four thousand celestial beings of divine form, to the north of the lunar
mansion, the excellent, auspicious, resplendent, and supremely adorned chariots,
with swiftly moving, graceful, and agile movements, with swaying, pendulous, and
excellent ornaments, with well-crafted, well-joined, and beautifully made seats,
with long, broad, and proportionate tails, with delicate, soft, smooth, and
fine-haired bodies, with beautifully adorned manes of fine, soft, and delicate
texture, with excellent and beautiful forehead ornaments, with faces adorned
with beautiful crowns, fans, and waist ornaments, with gracefully moving hooves,
tongues, palates, and beautifully shining eyes, desirable, delightful,
enchanting, and charming, of immortal gait, of immense strength, valor, and
heroic prowess, roaring with a deep and sweet voice, filling the sky with their
captivating sound, and illuminating the directions, carry four thousand
celestial beings of divine form, to the north of the lunar mansion, the
excellent, auspicious, and resplendent chariots, with swiftly moving, graceful,
and agile movements, with swaying, pendulous, and excellent ornaments.

## 176] [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra **Concerning the fast and slow movement of the
celestial bodies** 95. Q. Now, tell me, among the moon, sun, planets,
constellations, and stars, which moves faster and which moves slower? A. The sun
moves faster than the moon, the planets move faster than the sun, the
constellations move faster than the planets, and the stars move faster than the
constellations. The moon moves slowest of all, and the stars move fastest of
all. **Concerning the small and large size of the celestial bodies** Q. Now,
tell me, among the moon, sun, planets, constellations, and stars, which is
smaller and which is larger? A. The constellations are larger than the stars,
the planets are larger than the constellations, the sun is larger than the
planets, and the moon is larger than the sun. The stars are smallest of all, and
the moon is largest of all. **Concerning the distance between the stars** Q.
Now, tell me, on Jambudvipa, what is the distance between the stars? A. There
are two distances between the stars, namely: 1. The distance of a "vaagha"
(tiger), and 2. The distance of a "nivvagha" (non-tiger). A. Now, the distance
of a "vaagha" is two hundred yojanas in length. B. The distance of a "nivvagha"
is twelve thousand yojanas plus two hundred yojanas in length. 1. A. B. Sutra 83
and this Sutra are similar. Jambudvipa Vakya 7, Sutra 169 Jambudvipa Vakya 7,
Sutra 170

## Eighteenth Praabhrut  [177]  **b.** There, those who are in the state of
liberation, they are, as it were, five hundred yojanas away,  separated by a
distance of half a yojana, like stars, from the star-like form, and from the
star-like form,  which is beyond measure. The chief queen of the moon, along
with her entourage of goddesses, is also...  **p.** So, how many chief queens
are there, who are the wives of the moon, the lord of the moon?  **u.** So,
there are four chief queens, namely: 1. Chandraprabha, 2. Dosinabha, 3.
Acchimali, 4. Pabhankara.  There, each of these goddesses has an entourage of
four thousand goddesses.   **p.** So, are these goddesses, each one of them,
surrounded by four thousand goddesses?  **u.** So, each of these goddesses is
surrounded by an entourage of four thousand goddesses.  Similarly, sixteen
thousand goddesses are present, along with their entire entourage. They are all
joyful.   **p.** So, are they, the moon, the lord of the moon, the lord of the
moon, in the moon-palace, in the assembly hall,  in the state of joy, along with
the joyful ones, enjoying celestial pleasures?  **u.** No, they are not.
**p.** So, how is it that they are not, the lord of the moon, the lord of the
moon, in the moon-palace, in the assembly hall,  in the state of joy, along with
the joyful ones, enjoying celestial pleasures?  **u.** **k.** So, the moon, the
lord of the moon, the lord of the moon, in the moon-palace, in the assembly
hall, in the state of joy,  there are many Jina-saints, who are gathered
together, in the human world, in the celestial world, in the world of the gods,
in the round, full world. They are the ones who are the moon, the lord of the
moon, the lord of the moon, who are worthy of being  worshipped, honored,
revered, respected, and praised by many other Jina-saints, gods, and goddesses.
They are the ones who  bring about auspiciousness, prosperity, and happiness.
Thus, the moon, the lord of the moon, the lord of the moon, is not in the  moon-
palace, in the assembly hall, in the state of joy, along with the joyful ones,
enjoying celestial pleasures.  **b.** So, the moon, the lord of the moon, the
lord of the moon, in the moon-palace, in the assembly hall, in the state of joy,
on the moon-throne, along with a thousand, four, chief queens, along with their
entourage, three attendants, seven others,  seven others, sixteen thousand
guardian-god-saints, and many other Jina-saints, gods...  **1.**  Jamb. Vakkh.
7, Su. 171

Page #229 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):

The translation preserving the Jain terms is as follows:  The devis (goddesses)
along with him (the sun god) are surrounded, singing and playing the
mahathahana-gita-vayika-tala-tala-tudiya-ghana-muinga (musical instruments),
emitting divine sounds, enjoying the divine pleasures, residing solely by the
power of their retinue. The chief queens of the sun, the devis, are the
ornaments of the sun's retinue.  Q. How many chief queens of the sun, the
jyotisirinda (lord of the stars), are mentioned? A. Four chief queens are
mentioned, namely - 1. Suraprabha, 2. Atava, 3. Accimali, 4. Prabhamkara. The
rest is as in the case of the moon, except that they do not engage in sexual
activity in the sun's palace.  The abode of the jyotisiya (astral) devas is 98
(palya). Q. For how long is the abode of the jyotisiya devas mentioned? A. At
the minimum, it is 8/9th of a palya, at the maximum, it is a palya, exceeding a
thousand years.  Q. For how long is the abode of the jyotisini (astral) devis
mentioned? A. At the minimum, it is 8/9th of a palya, at the maximum, it is half
a palya, exceeding fifty thousand years.  Q. For how long is the abode of the
devas in the moon palace mentioned? A. At the minimum, it is 1/4th of a palya,
at the maximum, it is a palya, exceeding a thousand years.  Q. For how long is
the abode of the devis in the moon palace mentioned? A. At the minimum, it is
1/4th of a palya, at the maximum, it is half a palya, exceeding fifty thousand
years.  Q. For how long is the abode of the devas in the sun palace mentioned?
A. At the minimum, it is 1/4th of a palya, at the maximum, it is a palya,
exceeding a thousand years.  Q. For how long is the abode of the devis in the
sun palace mentioned? A. At the minimum, it is 1/4th of a palya, at the maximum,
it is half a palya, exceeding five hundred years.  Q. For how long is the abode
of the devas in the planet palace mentioned?

| Romanization (original text) |
======================

## Eighteenth Praabhrut  [ 179 Q. How long do the gods in the Gahavimaana stay,
in terms of Jahanne and Ukkosa? A. They stay for one-fourth of a Jahanne and
half of an Ukkosa. Q. How long do the gods in the Nakkhattavimaana stay, in
terms of Jahanne and Ukkosa? A. They stay for one-fourth of a Jahanne and half
of an Ukkosa. Q. How long do the goddesses in the Nakkhattavimaana stay, in
terms of Jahanne and Ukkosa? A. They stay for one-eighth of a Jahanne and one-
fourth of an Ukkosa. Q. How long do the gods in the Taraavimaana stay, in terms
of Jahanne and Ukkosa? A. They stay for one-eighth of a Jahanne and one-fourth
of an Ukkosa. Q. How long do the goddesses in the Taraavimaana stay, in terms of
Jahanne and Ukkosa? A. They stay for one-eighth of a Jahanne and one-eighth and
a half of an Ukkosa.   Q. Among the Chandra, Surya, Gaha, Nakkhatta, and Tara,
which are few, many, equal, or have a special quality? A. Chandra and Surya are
equal, Nakkhatta are many, Gaha are numerous, and Tara are numerous. 1. Jambu.
Vakkh. 7, Su. 173 2. Jambu. Vakkh. 7, Su. 175 ]

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 aThArahavA~ prAbhRta ] [ 179 u. tA jahanneNaM caubbhAgapaliovamaM, ukkoseNaM
pliovmN| pa. tA gahavimANe NaM devINaM kevaiyaM kAlaM ThiI paNNattA? u. tA
jahanneNaM caubbhAgapaliovamaM, ukkoseNaM addhpliovmN| pa. tANakkhattavimANe NaM
devANaM kevaiyaM kAlaM ThiI paNNattA ? u. tA jahanneNaM caubbhAgapaliovamaM,

Page #231 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
The nineteenth **Praabhrut** of the moon, sun, constellations, and stars is 100.
How many moons and suns illuminate, brighten, shine, and radiate throughout the
universe?   The **Vaeyaja** said: There are twelve **Padivatti**
(interpretations) established in this regard:  1. Some say that one moon and one
sun illuminate, brighten, shine, and radiate throughout the universe. 2. Some
say that three moons and three suns illuminate, brighten, shine, and radiate
throughout the universe. 3. Some say that eight moons and eight suns illuminate,
brighten, shine, and radiate throughout the universe. 4. Some say that seven
moons and seven suns,  5. ten moons and ten suns,  6. twelve moons and twelve
suns,  7. forty-two moons and forty-two suns,  8. forty-two moons and forty-two
suns,  9. forty-two hundred moons and forty-two hundred suns,  10. forty-two
hundred moons and forty-two hundred suns,  11. forty-two thousand moons and
forty-two thousand suns,  12. forty-two thousand moons and forty-two thousand
suns illuminate, brighten, shine, and radiate throughout the universe.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

[Nineteenth Praabhrut] [181 - We say this and we know - Jambudvipa - in
Jambudvipa, the extent of a yojana That Jambudvipa, the island, with all the
islands and seas, with all the interiors and all the exteriors, up to one
hundred thousand yojanas in length and breadth, three hundred thousand yojanas,
sixteen thousand, two hundred and twenty-seven yojanas, three kosas, twenty-
eight dhanus and thirteen angulas, and a little more than half an angula, is
declared by calculation. 1 p. Jambudvipa, the island - How many moons shine, or
shine, or will shine? 2 p. How many suns rise, or rise, or will rise? 3 p. How
many planets move, or move, or will move? 4 p. How many stars shine, or shine,
or will shine? 5 p. How many constellations of stars shine, or shine, or will
shine? 1 u. That Jambudvipa, the island - Two moons shine, or shine, or will
shine. 2 u. Two suns rise, or rise, or will rise. 3 u. Sixty-six planets move,
or move, or will move. 4 u. Fifty-six stars shine, or shine, or will shine. 5 u.
One hundred thousand, thirty-three thousand, nine hundred and fifty
constellations of stars shine, or shine, or will shine. Gahas - Two moons, two
suns, fifty-six stars. Sixty-six planets, in Jambudvipa, the wise say. One
hundred thousand, thirty-three thousand, indeed, are the thousands. Nine hundred
and fifty, constellations of stars. The Salt Sea That Jambudvipa, the island, is
surrounded by the sea called Lavana, which is circular in shape and surrounds it
completely.

[182] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra] Q. Is the salt ocean (Lavana Samudra) a circular
or non-circular wheel-shaped universe? A. The salt ocean is a circular wheel-
shaped universe, not a non-circular wheel-shaped universe. Q. What is the
diameter and circumference of the salt ocean? A. The diameter of the salt ocean
is two hundred thousand yojanas, and the circumference is fifteen hundred
thousand yojanas, one hundred and one thousand yojanas, and forty yojanas,
slightly more. Verse: Fifteen hundred thousand, one hundred and one thousand,
and slightly more, is the circumference of the salt ocean. Q. How many moons
have shone, shine, or will shine in the salt ocean? Q. How many suns have risen,
rise, or will rise? Q. How many great planets have moved, move, or will move? Q.
How many constellations have joined, join, or will join? Q. How many billions of
billions of stars have shone, shine, or will shine? A. Four moons have shone,
shine, or will shine in the salt ocean. A. Four suns have risen, rise, or will
rise. A. Fifty-two great planets have moved, move, or will move. A. One hundred
and two constellations have joined, join, or will join. A. Two hundred thousand,
seven hundred and nine thousand, and nine hundred billions of billions of stars
have shone, shine, or will shine. Verses: Four moons and four suns in the salt
ocean. One hundred and two constellations, and fifty-two great planets. Two
hundred thousand, seven hundred and nine thousand, and nine hundred billions of
billions of stars in the salt ocean. Dhayee Sand Deepa Q. Is the island called
Dhayee Sand Deepa, which is circular and surrounded by a wall, a circular or
non-circular wheel-shaped universe? A. The island called Dhayee Sand Deepa is a
circular wheel-shaped universe, not a non-circular wheel-shaped universe.

| Romanization (original text) |

[Nineteenth Praabhrut] [183] Q. What is the diameter of the Dhaayee-sande island
and what is its circumference? Please tell me. A. Its diameter is four hundred
thousand yojanas and its circumference is eighty-four hundred thousand yojanas,
ten thousand nine hundred and one yojanas, a little more than that. Please tell
me.  **Gatha** 1. Q. Dhaayee-sande island - Dhaayee-sande's circumference is
eighty-four hundred thousand. Nine hundred and one, a little less than that. How
many moons shine, or will shine, or will shine? 2. Q. How many suns shine, or
will shine, or will shine? 3. Q. How many great planets revolve, or will
revolve, or will revolve? 4. Q. How many constellations are seen, or will be
seen, or will be seen? 5. Q. How many stars, countless in number, shine, or will
shine, or will shine? 1. A. Twelve moons shine, or will shine, or will shine. 2.
A. Twelve suns shine, or will shine, or will shine. 3. A. One thousand six
hundred and fifty-six great planets revolve, or will revolve, or will revolve.
4. A. Thirty-six hundred constellations are seen, or will be seen, or will be
seen. 5. A. Gatha - One hundred thousand, three thousand seven hundred. One
hundred and one families, countless stars. Twenty-four moons and suns, thirty-
six hundred constellations. One thousand great planets, six hundred and fifty-
six in Dhaayee-sande. One hundred thousand, three thousand seven hundred.
Dhaayee-sande island, countless stars. Kalo-e ocean  So, the Dhaayee-sande
island is called Kalo-e ocean, it is circular in shape and is completely
surrounded by a ring. Q. Is the Kalo-e ocean circular or elliptical? A. The
Kalo-e ocean is circular, not elliptical.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

[184] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra] ... P. What is the circumference of the ocean of
time, and what is its depth? A. The circumference of the ocean of time is eight
hundred thousand yojanas. Its depth is one hundred and nine thousand, seventy
thousand, six hundred and fifty yojanas, a little more. Gatha - One hundred and
nine thousand, seventy thousand is the circumference of it. Six hundred and
fifty is the depth of the ocean of time. 1. P. What number of moons have shone,
shine, or will shine in the ocean of time? 2. P. What number of suns have risen,
rise, or will rise? 3. P. What number of great planets have moved, move, or will
move? 4. P. What number of constellations have joined, join, or will join? 5. P.
What number of kodi-kodi of stars have shone, shine, or will shine? 1. A. Forty-
two moons have shone, shine, or will shine in the ocean of time. 2. A. Forty-two
suns have risen, rise, or will rise. 3. A. Three thousand, six hundred and
sixty-nine great planets have moved, move, or will move. 4. A. Eleven hundred
and sixty-four constellations have joined, join, or will join. 5. A. Twenty-
eight hundred thousand, twelve thousand, nine hundred and fifty kodi-kodi of
stars have shone, shine, or will shine. Gatha - Forty-two moons, forty-two suns.
In the ocean of time, they move with their associated planets. One thousand and
sixty-four constellations. Six hundred and sixty-nine great planets, three
thousand. Twenty-eight hundred thousand, twelve thousand. Nine hundred and fifty
kodi-kodi of stars.

[Nineteenth Chapter] [185] [The Island of Pukhkaravara]  At that time, there is
an island named Pukhkaravara in the ocean, which is circular in shape and
completely surrounded on all sides.  Q. Is that island of Pukhkaravara circular
or elliptical in shape? A. That island of Pukhkaravara is circular, not
elliptical.  Q. What is the diameter of that circular island of Pukhkaravara?
What is its circumference? A. It has a diameter of sixteen thousand yojanas.
Its circumference is one yojana kodi, eighty-nine thousand, eight hundred and
forty-nine yojanas.  Verse: One kodi, eighty-nine thousand, Eight hundred and
forty-nine, Is the circumference of Pukhkaravara.  Q. On that island of
Pukhkaravara, 1. How many moons shine, shone, or will shine? 2. How many suns
rise, rose, or will rise? 3. How many great planets revolve, revolved, or will
revolve? 4. How many constellations move, moved, or will move? 5. How many kodi-
kodi stars shine, shone, or will shine?  A. 1. Forty-two hundred moons shine,
shone, or will shine. 2. Forty-two hundred suns rise, rose, or will rise. 3.
Twelve thousand, six hundred and sixty great planets revolve, revolved, or will
revolve. 4. Four thousand and thirty-two constellations move, moved, or will
move. 5. Sixteen thousand, forty-two thousand and four hundred kodi-kodi stars
shine, shone, or will shine.  Verses: Forty-two hundred moons, Forty-two hundred
suns, Shine on the island of Pukhkaravara.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 unnIsavA~ prAbhRta ] [ 185 pukkharavaradIve tA kAloyaM NaM samudaM pukkharavare
NAma dIve vaTTe valayAkArasaMThANasaMThie savvao samaMtA saMparikkhittA NaM
citttthi| pa. tA pukkhare NaM dIve kiM samacakkavAlasaMThie visamacakvAlasaMThie
? u. tA pukkharavare NaM dIve samacakkavAlasaMThie, no vismckvaalsNtthie| pa. tA
pukkharavare NaM dIve kevaiyaM samacakkavAlavikkhaMbheNaM ? kevaiyaM
parikkheveNaM ? u. tA solasa joyaNasayasahassAI ckkvaalvikkhNbhennN| egA
joyaNakoDI bANauiM ca sayasahassAI auNAvanaM ca sahassAiM aTTha cauNaue
joyaNasae parikkheveNaM, Ahie tti vejjaa| gAhA - koDI bANauI khalu, auNANauiM
bhave shssaaii| aTThasayA cauNauyA, parirao pokkhrvrss|| 1. pa. tA pukkharavare
NaM dIve - kevaiyA caMdA pabhAsiMsu vA, pabhAsiMti vA, pabhAsissaMti vA ? 2 pa.
kevaiyA sUrA taviMsu vA, taveMti vA tavissaMtti vA ? 3 pa. kevaiyA gahA cAraM
cariMsu vA, caraMti vA carissaMti vA ? 4 pa. kevaiyA NakkhattA jogaM joiMsu vA,
joeMti vA joissaMti vA ? 5 pa. kevaiyA tArAgaNakoDikoDIo sobhaM sobheMsu vA
sobhaMti vA sobhissaMti vA ? 1 u. tA coyAlaM caMdasayaM pabhAseMsu vA,
pabhAsiMti vA, pabhAsissaMti vaa| 2 u. coMyAlaM sUriyANaM sayaMtaviMsu vA,
taveMti vA, tavissaMti vaa| 3 u. bArasa sahassAiM chacca bAbatarA mahaggahasayA
cAraM cariMsu vA, caranti vA, carissaMti vaa| 4 u. cattAri sahassAiM battIsaM ca
NakkhatA jogaM joiMsu vA, joyaMti vA, joissaMti vaa| 5 u. chaNNauisayasahassAI,
coyAlIsaM sahassAiM catAri ya sayAI tArAgaNakoDikoDINaM sobhaM sobhesu vA,
sobheti vA, sobhissaMti vaa| gAhAo cattAlaM caMdasayaM, cattAlaM ceva sUriyANa
syN| pokkharavaradIvammi ya, caraMti ee pbhaasNtaa||

Page #237 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):

[186] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra] There are four thousand and thirty-two
constellations. There are six hundred and seventy-two great planets and twelve
thousand planets. There are sixty-nine hundred thousand and forty-four thousand
stars. There are four hundred star clusters, countless kotis of stars.  In the
Manushutra mountain, In the Manushutra mountain, which is described in the
scriptures, the Pushkaravar island, which is circular in shape and is divided
into two parts, is situated. These two parts are: 1. The inner Pushkaravardha,
and 2. The outer Pushkaravardha. In the inner Pushkaravardha, Q. Is the inner
Pushkaravardha circular or non-circular? A. It is circular, not non-circular. Q.
What is the diameter and circumference of the inner Pushkaravardha? A. The
diameter of the inner Pushkaravardha is eight hundred thousand yojanas, and the
circumference is one kodi, forty-two hundred thousand, thirty thousand, and two
yojanas. "The diameter of the inner Pushkaravardha is one hundred thousand." Q.
How many moons shine, are shining, or will shine in the inner Pushkaravardha? Q.
How many suns shine, are shining, or will shine? Q. How many planets move, are
moving, or will move? Q. How many constellations shine, are shining, or will
shine? Q. How many star clusters shine, are shining, or will shine? A. Sixty-two
moons shine, are shining, or will shine. A. Sixty-two suns shine, are shining,
or will shine. A. Six thousand great planets, three hundred and sixty-four
planets move, are moving, or will move. A. Two thousand and sixteen
constellations shine, are shining, or will shine. A. Countless kotis of star
clusters shine, are shining, or will shine. These are the first two lines of the
verse.

## Nineteenth Prabhruta  **5. U.** Eighty-eight hundred thousand, twenty-two
thousand, two hundred, star-group-kodi-kodi, shine, shine in, shine, or will
shine.  **Gatha:**  * In the realm of the Pukkhara-varda, * Seventy-two are the
moons, seventy-two are the suns. * They move, these shining ones. * Three
hundred thirty-six, six hundred thousand are the great planets. * Sixteen, two
thousand. * Of the stars, there are * Twenty-two thousand. * Star-group-kodi-
kodi.  **88 hundred thousand, two hundred in the realm of the Pukkhara, in the
Samayakshetra.**  **P.** So, in the Samayakshetra, what is the length, what is
the breadth, what is the circumference? Tell me.  **U.** So, eighty-eight
hundred thousand yojana is the length, breadth. One yojana-kodi, eighty-two
hundred thousand, two hundred, forty-five yojana is the circumference. Tell me.
**Gatha:**  * Eighty-eight hundred thousand, * The circumference of the
Samayakshetra. * One kodi, eighty-two thousand, two hundred, forty-five. * The
circumference of the Samayakshetra, the same for the realm of the Pukkhara.
**1. P.** So, in the Samayakshetra, how many moons shine, shine in, or will
shine? **2. P.** How many suns move, move in, or will move? **3. P.** How many
planets move, move in, or will move? **4. P.** How many stars join, join in, or
will join? **5. P.** How many star-group-kodi-kodi shine, shine in, or will
shine?  **187**  **1. U.** So, thirty-two hundred moons shine, shine in, or will
shine. **2. U.** Thirty-two hundred suns move, move in, or will move. **3. U.**
So, eleven thousand, six hundred sixteen great planets move, move in, or will
move.

## 188] [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra 4. Those three thousand six hundred and sixty-
nine constellations, they shine, or they are shining, or they will shine.  5.
Those eighty-eight hundred thousand, forty thousand, seven hundred stars, they
are the brilliance of the kodi-kodi (infinite) stars.  Gatha: Thirty-two hundred
moons, thirty-two suns, they are the brilliance of all the human world.  Eleven
thousand, six hundred and sixteen great planets, six hundred and sixty-nine
constellations, three thousand.  Eighty-eight, forty thousand, hundred thousand
in the human world.  Seven hundred less, the kodi-kodi stars.  This is the star
cluster, in summary, in the human world.  But outside, the stars are countless,
as said by the Jinas.  This is the star cluster, as spoken in the human world.
It shines, moving like a flower cluster, in the four kalpas.  Sun, moon,
planets, constellations, they are like this in the human world.  Their names and
lineage, they are not to be known, they are beyond knowledge.  The clusters of
the shining ones: The cluster of the moon, in the human world.  Two moons, two
suns, they are in one cluster.  The cluster of the great planets, in the human
world.  Sixty-seven planets, they are in one cluster.  The cluster of the
constellations, in the human world.  Fifty-six constellations, they are in one
cluster.

## Nineteenth Chapter  **The Rows of the Zodiac**  - There are four rows of the
zodiac in the human world. Each row has six signs. There are sixty-six signs in
the human world. Each row has six signs. - There are sixty-six signs in the
human world. Each row has six signs. - There are fifty-six rows of
constellations in the human world. Each row has six signs.  **The Circle of the
Zodiac**  - All the circles are in the form of a lotus. - They revolve around
Mount Meru, in a circular motion, with the moon, sun, and planets. - The
constellations and stars are also in a circular motion, revolving around Mount
Meru.  **The Movement of the Zodiacal Circles**  - The moon and sun do not move
up or down. - The movement of the circles is only from inside to outside and
from outside to inside.  **The Four Causes of Happiness and Suffering in the
Zodiac**  - The moon, sun, constellations, and planets are the four causes of
happiness and suffering for humans.  **The Zodiacal Sphere**  - The sphere of
the zodiac expands when they enter it. - It contracts when they leave it. - The
sphere of the zodiac is like a lotus bud. - The moon and sun are inside the
sphere, and they expand outwards.

| Romanization (original text) |

## 190] [ Surya Prajnapti Sutra ]  **Gatha:** How does the moon increase? How
does the moon decrease? Is it by time or by space? By what nature does the moon
increase and decrease? How does the Rahu-Vimana always remain inseparable from
the moon? It is four angulas in size, and the moon always travels with it.
**Gatha:** It increases by twenty-eight, day by day, during the bright
fortnight. As the moon increases, it also decreases in time.  **Gatha:** It
increases by one-fifteenth, and it also decreases by one-fifteenth.  **Gatha:**
Thus, the moon increases, and the moon decreases. It is by time or by space, by
this nature does the moon increase and decrease.  **Gatha:** What are the
celestial bodies in the human realm? There are four types of celestial bodies.
There are five types of celestial bodies: the moon, the sun, and the planets.
**Gatha:** Beyond these, there are the moon, the planets, the stars, and the
constellations. There are not four types of celestial bodies, but they are to be
considered as four.  **Gatha:** What is the measure of the celestial bodies in
the Jambudvipa, the Lavana, and the Dhāyisaṇḍa?  **Gatha:** In the Jambudvipa,
there are twice as many, in the Lavana there are four times as many, and in the
Lavana-Gāha there are three times as many. In the Dhāyisaṇḍa, there are twelve
moons and suns.  **Gatha:** There are two moons in this Jambudvipa, four in the
Lavana, and twelve moons and suns in the Dhāyisaṇḍa.

| Romanization (original text) |
======================

## Nineteenth Chapter  **The Measure of the Distance of the Stars from Humans**
**Verse:**  - The moon is three times the size of the earth, and the sun is many
times larger than the moon. The sun is like a blazing fire, and the moon is like
a cool, refreshing water. The stars are like tiny sparks, and the earth is like
a small speck of dust.  **Verse:**  - The distance between the moon and the sun
is fifty thousand yojanas. The distance between the sun and the sun is one
hundred thousand yojanas. The distance between the moon and the moon is one
hundred thousand yojanas. The distance between the earth and the stars is many
yojanas.  **The One Hundred and One Family of Stars**  **Verse:**  - There are
eighty-eight constellations and twenty-eight stars in the one hundred and one
family of stars. There are sixty-six thousand, nine hundred and fifty stars in
the one hundred and one family of stars.  **The Movement of the Stars in the
Human Realm**  **Question:**  - In the human realm, what is the movement of the
moon, sun, constellations, and stars? Are they moving in a straight line, a
circle, a spiral, or a combination of these?  **Answer:**  - The moon, sun,
constellations, and stars are not moving in a straight line, a circle, a spiral,
or a combination of these. They are moving in a way that is beyond our
comprehension.

[192] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra] They are not aerial, not terrestrial, not
celestial. With a vast, magnificent, and well-arranged structure, extending for
thousands of yojanas, with thousands of such regions outside, and with a
surrounding, vast, and magnificent, celestial palace, with a resounding,
musical, and melodious sound of celestial drums, with a roaring, loud, and
thunderous sound of celestial lions, they enjoy celestial pleasures and wander
about. With a beautiful, bright, and radiant light, with a mind full of joy,
with various celestial pleasures, they shine, illuminate, and radiate light in
all directions, like stars in the sky. P. Then, which Indra do these gods
worship? How do they worship him? U. Four or five Samaṇīya gods reside in that
place, until another Indra is born in this world. P. For how long is it ordained
that they reside in the Indra's abode? U. For one period, or six months, in the
higher realm.  The transformation of the moon and the sun, the stars and the
constellations, outside the human realm - P. Are those gods, the moon, the sun,
the stars, and the constellations, outside the human realm, aerial, terrestrial,
celestial, or all of these? Are they four-bodied, two-bodied, terrestrial, or
celestial? U. Those gods are not aerial, not terrestrial, not celestial, not all
of these, not four-bodied, not two-bodied, not terrestrial, not celestial. With
a vast, magnificent, and well-arranged structure, extending for hundreds of
thousands of yojanas, with hundreds of thousands of such regions outside, and
with a surrounding, vast, and magnificent, celestial palace, with a resounding,
musical, and melodious sound of celestial drums, with a roaring, loud, and
thunderous sound of celestial lions, they enjoy celestial pleasures and wander
about. With a beautiful, bright, and radiant light, with a mind full of joy,
with various celestial pleasures, they shine, illuminate, and radiate light in
all directions, like stars in the sky. P. Then, which Indra do these gods
worship? How do they worship him? U. Four or five Samaṇīya gods reside in that
place, until another Indra is born in this world. P. For how long is it ordained
that they reside in the Indra's abode? U. For one period, or six months, in the
higher realm.

 192 ] [ sUryaprajJaptisUtra no thAraTThaIyA gairaiyA gaisamAvaNNA  /

[Nineteenth Praabhrut] [193 The extent of the Sesana island-ocean is 101. That
island, named Pukkharode, is situated in the Pukkharode ocean, circular in
shape, completely surrounded on all sides. Q. Is that Pukkharode ocean circular
or elliptical? A. It is circular, not elliptical. Q. What is the diameter of
that Pukkharode ocean? What is its circumference? What is said? A. It is said to
be of the extent of countless yojanas in diameter, and countless yojanas in
circumference. Q. How many moons shine in that Pukkharode ocean, and how many
constellations of stars shine brightly? A. Countless moons shine in that
Pukkharode ocean, and countless constellations of stars shine brightly. Thus, in
the same way - 1. Varunavare island, 2. Varunode ocean, 1. Kheeravare island, 2.
Khirode ocean, 1. Ghayavare island, 2. Ghayode ocean, 1. Khoyavare island, 2.
Khoyode ocean, 1. Nandisaravare island, 2. Nandisaare ocean, 1. Aruna island, 2.
Arunode ocean, 1. Arunavare island, 2. Arunavarode ocean, 1. Arunavaroabhase
island, 2. Arunavarabhasode ocean, 1. Kudale island, 2. Kudalode ocean, 1.
Kudalavare island, 2. Kudalavarode ocean, 1. Kudalavaroabhase island, 2.
Kudalavarabhasode ocean. The diameter and circumference of all of them are the
same as the Pukkharodesagar. That Kudalavarabhasode ocean is situated around the
Ruya island, circular in shape, completely surrounded on all sides.

[194] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra] "Tell me, is the Sun a world with a circular or an
elliptical shape?" "It is a world with a circular shape, not an elliptical one."
"Tell me, what is the diameter and circumference of the Sun?" "It is said that
the diameter of the Sun is countless thousands of yojanas, and its circumference
is countless thousands of yojanas." "Tell me, how many moons and stars adorn the
Sun?" "It is said that countless moons and countless star-clusters adorn the
Sun." In the same way, there are: 1. The Ruya-Gava-world, 2. The Ruya-Gava-
ocean, 1. The Ruya-Gava-world with light, 2. The Ruya-Gava-ocean with light. In
the same way, there are three worlds and oceans, up to: 1. The Sun-world, 2. The
Sun-ocean, 1. The Sun-world with light, 2. The Sun-ocean with light. All of
these have a diameter and circumference equal to the Ruya-Gava-world. Now, the
Sun-ocean with light is surrounded by a world called Deva, which is circular in
shape and completely enclosed. "Tell me, is the Deva-world circular or
elliptical?" "It is circular, not elliptical." "Tell me, what is the diameter
and circumference of the Deva-world?" "It is said that the diameter of the Deva-
world is countless thousands of yojanas, and its circumference is countless
thousands of yojanas." "Tell me, how many moons and star-clusters adorn the
Deva-world?"

| Romanization (original text) |

**The Subtlety of the Moon and Sun**  102. **P.** How is that subtlety? Please
explain. **U.** There are two interpretations here, as follows:  **1.** Some
say: The Moon and Sun are neither living nor non-living, neither gross nor
subtle, nor bodies of water, wind, or fire. They do not have 1. rising, 2.
trembling, 3. strength, 4. heroism, 5. activity of merit. They do not attract
lightning, nor thunder, nor clouds. Even when the wind blows strongly, it
attracts lightning, thunder, and clouds. 'Some say this.'  **1.** Others say:
The Moon and Sun are living, not non-living, gross, not subtle, bodies of water,
wind, and fire. They do have 1. rising, 2. trembling, 3. strength, 4. heroism,
5. activity of merit. They attract lightning, thunder, and clouds. 'Some say
this.'  We, however, say: The Moon and Sun are the great servants, great lords,
great powerful, great glorious, great happy, great influential ones of the gods.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

## Twentieth Chapter  Those who wear fine clothes, those who wear fine garlands,
those who wear fine ornaments, some eat, some fast.  **The Nature of Rahu
Karma**  103. P. How is Rahu Karma? Tell me. U. There are two interpretations
here, as follows:  Some say: 1. There is a Rahu deity who swallows the moon or
the sun.  Others say: 2. There is no Rahu deity who swallows the moon or the
sun.  Those who say: "There is a Rahu deity who swallows the moon or the sun,"
they say: When Rahu deity swallows the moon or the sun: 1. He swallows it with
his mind and releases it with his mind. 2. He swallows it with his mind and
releases it with his mouth. 3. He swallows it with his mouth and releases it
with his mind. 4. He swallows it with his mouth and releases it with his mouth.
1. He swallows it with his left hand and releases it with his left hand. 2. He
swallows it with his left hand and releases it with his right hand. 3. He
swallows it with his right hand and releases it with his left hand. 4. He
swallows it with his right hand and releases it with his right hand.  Those who
say: "There is no Rahu deity who swallows the moon or the sun," they say:  There
are fifteen types of celestial bodies, as follows: 1. Simha, 2. Jadil, 3. Khara,
4. Khat, 5. Anjana, 6. Khanjana, 7. Sitla, 8. Himasitla, 9. Kelasa, 10.
Arunabha, 11. Parijja, 12. Nabhasura, 13. Kavilia, 14. Pingala, 15. Rahu.  When
these fifteen celestial bodies are in a particular position with respect to the
moon or the sun, people say: "Rahu is swallowing the moon or the sun." When
these fifteen celestial bodies are not in a particular position with respect to
the moon or the sun, then...

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

[198] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra] Indeed, in this human world, humans say this:
"Indeed, Rahu swallows the moon or the sun, they say so." But we say this: Rahu
is a god, mighty, powerful, strong, glorious, very happy, very virtuous, a
bearer of good things, a bearer of good strength, a bearer of good ornaments.
Rahu has nine names. Indeed, that god Rahu has nine names, namely: 1. Singhaḍa,
2. Jaḍila, 3. Khara, 4. Khetta, 5. Ḍaḍḍara, 6. Magara, 7. Maccha, 8. Kaccbha, 9.
Kaṇṇasappa. Rahu's chariot is of five colors. Indeed, that god Rahu's chariot is
of five colors, namely: 1. Black, 2. Blue, 3. Red, 4. Yellow, 5. White.
Sometimes Rahu's chariot is said to be of the color of a crow. Sometimes Rahu's
chariot is said to be of the color of a blue lotus. Sometimes Rahu's chariot is
said to be of the color of a ruby. Sometimes Rahu's chariot is said to be of the
color of a yellow lotus. Sometimes Rahu's chariot is said to be of the color of
a shining star. When Rahu, the god, comes, goes, moves, or revolves, and covers
the moon or the sun from the west, he swallows it from the east. When Rahu, the
god, comes, goes, moves, or revolves, and covers the moon or the sun from the
south, he swallows it from the north. Therefore, he swallows it from the east
when he covers it from the west, and he swallows it from the north when he
covers it from the south. When Rahu, the god, comes, goes, moves, or revolves,
and covers the moon or the sun from the southwest, he swallows it from the
northeast. When Rahu, the god, comes, goes, moves, or revolves, and covers the
moon or the sun from the southeast, he swallows it from the northwest.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

## Twenty-first Chapter  [199]  When Rahu, either in the north or in the south,
covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said to be in the north-west, and when it
covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said to be in the south-west.  When Rahu,
while approaching, departing, or passing by, covers the Moon or the Sun, it is
said to be in the north-east, and when it covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said
to be in the south-east.  When Rahu, while approaching, departing, or passing
by, covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said to be in the north-east, and when it
covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said to be in the south-east.  When Rahu,
while approaching, departing, or passing by, covers the Moon or the Sun, it is
said to be in the north-east, and when it covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said
to be in the south-east.  When Rahu, while approaching, departing, or passing
by, covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said to be in the north-east, and when it
covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said to be in the south-east.  When Rahu,
while approaching, departing, or passing by, covers the Moon or the Sun, it is
said to be in the north-east, and when it covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said
to be in the south-east.  When Rahu, while approaching, departing, or passing
by, covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said to be in the north-east, and when it
covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said to be in the south-east.  When Rahu,
while approaching, departing, or passing by, covers the Moon or the Sun, it is
said to be in the north-east, and when it covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said
to be in the south-east.  When Rahu, while approaching, departing, or passing
by, covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said to be in the north-east, and when it
covers the Moon or the Sun, it is said to be in the south-east.  When Rahu,

Page #251 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
[Sūryaprajñapti Sūtra]  In the remaining time, the moon becomes bright and dark.
There, those who are the moon's followers, in the minimum, for six months, and
in the maximum, for forty-two months of the moon, and for forty-two years of the
sun. The moon's name is Śaśi.   How then is the moon called Śaśi, the moon Śaśi?
It should be said.  Then, the moon, the lord of the stars, the king of the
stars, has divine lovers, divine beloveds, and divine furniture, bedding, seats,
vessels, and other accoutrements.   The moon god himself, the lord of the stars,
the king of the stars, Soma, is the beloved, auspicious, lovely to behold, and
handsome.  Thus, it should be said that the moon is Śaśi, the moon Śaśi.  The
sun's name is Āditya.  How then is the sun called Āditya, the sun Āditya? It
should be said.  Then, the sun rises, sets, breathes in and out, or stands
still, up to the ascending and descending cosmic cycles. Thus, it should be said
that the sun is Āditya, the sun Āditya.  The description of the sensual
pleasures of the moon and the sun.   How many chief queens are ascribed to the
moon, the lord of the stars, the king of the stars?  Four chief queens are
ascribed: 1. Candraprabha, 2. Doṣiṇābhā, 3. Accimālī, 4. Prabhāṃkarā. As stated
before, they do not engage in sexual activity.  The same should be understood
for the sun as well.  How do the moon and sun, the lords of the stars, the kings
of the stars, experience sensual pleasures?  It is like this: There is a man,
capable of the prime of youth, together with a wife capable of the prime of
youth, who has recently married, who is seeking wealth and searching for it, who
has traveled to sixteen countries, who, having obtained the desired wealth, has
returned home, satisfied and content.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

Page #252 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
[The Twentieth Prabhrita] [201] Having bathed, having performed the Kayotsarga,
having recited the Mangala-paryushana, having purified the body, having adorned
the body with excellent ornaments, having eaten a pure meal of eighteen
varieties, while residing in such a pleasant abode, within which there is no
activity of the soul, outside, on a beautiful, spacious, and variegated terrace,
on a soft and smooth surface, divided into many parts, in a moonlit night, in
the pleasant fragrance of excellent aloe, camphor, and other perfumes, becoming
fragrant, in such a pleasant resting place, lying on a high and deep bed,
embraced on both sides, with both sides adorned with garlands, on the beautiful
banks of the Ganga, with soft sand, covered with a clean, white, and soft cloth,
with a pleasant touch of cool breeze, fragrant with the powder of excellent
flowers, engaged in the pleasures of the senses, along with a beautiful and
charming woman, skilled in the arts of love, affection, and conversation, not
thinking of anything else, experiencing the fivefold human sensual pleasures of
sound, touch, taste, form, and smell - how does that person experience the
highest happiness?

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

## Eighty-Eight Mahāggaha  106. There are eighty-eight Mahāggaha, namely:  1.
Ingāla, 2. Viyāla, 3. Lohiyakkha, 4. Saṇicchare, 5. Āhuṇie, 6. Pāhuṇie, 7. Kaṇe,
8. Kaṇae, 9. Kaṇakaṇae, 10. Kaṇaviyāṇae, 11. Kaṇasatāṇae.  12. Some, 13. Sahie,
14. Assāsane, 15. Kajjoyae, 16. Kabbaḍae, 17. Ayakarae, 18. Dundabha, 19.
Sankhe, 20. Sankhavaṇṇe, 21. Sankhavaṇṇābha, 22. Kamse.  23. Kamsavaṇṇe, 24.
Kamsavaṇṇābha, 25. Nīle, 26. Nīlobhāse, 27. Ruppi, 28. Ruppobhāse, 29. Bhāse,
30. Bhāsarāsi, 31. Tile, 32. Tilpūpfavaṇṇe, 33. Dage.  34. Dagapāñcavaṇṇe, 35.
Kāle, 36. Kākaṇḍhe, 37. Indaggi, 38. Dhūmakeū, 39. Hari, 40. Piṅgale, 41. Buhe,
42. Sukke, 43. Bahassai, 44. Rāhu.  45. Agatthi, 46. Māṇavage, 47. Kāse, 48.
Phāse, 49. Dhūre, 50. Pamuhe, 51. Viyaḍe, 52. Visandhi, 53. Niyallae, 54.
Payalle, 55. Jaḍiāille.  56. Aruṇe, 57. Aggille, 58. Kāle, 59. Mahākāle, 60.
Sotthiya, 61. Sovatthie, 62. Vaddhamāṇage, 63. Palambe, 64. Niċċāloe, 65.
Niċċujjoe, 66. Sayamphabe.  67. Obhāse, 68. Seyankare, 69. Khemankara, 70.
Ābhankara, 71. Pabhankare, 72. Aparājie, 73. Arae, 74. Asogae, 75. Viyasogae,
76. Vimale, 77. Viyatte.  78. Vitathe, 79. Visale, 80. Sāle, 81. Suvvae, 82.
Aniyaṭṭi, 83. Egajaḍi, 84. Dujaḍi, 85. Karakarie, 86. Rāyaggale, 87. Pūpfakeū,
88. Bhāvakeū.  1. In the **Stāṇāṅga** (A. 2, U. 3, Sū. 95), the number of the
eighty-eight planets of the two moons and two suns of Jambudvīpa is given as two
by two.

Nila, 27-28. Ruppo Ya Hoti Chattari. 29-30. Bhas, 31-32. Tilpusphavanna, 33-34.

Page #255 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
107. This is the conclusion of this Pahuḍa, the joy of the liberated soul. This
has been spoken by the Bhagavan, the well-wisher of the world. This is the
essence of the saints, the one who is worthy of respect and reverence. It should
not be given to many, but should be given to the worthy. With faith, wisdom,
enthusiasm, effort, strength, energy, and respect, the saint who has learned
this, will be freed from the cycle of birth and death. He is outside the family,
clan, community, and assembly, free from the shackles of attachment and
aversion. He is worthy of being called an Arhat, a Ther, a member of the
assembly of the liberated. Therefore, for those who have learned faith, wisdom,
enthusiasm, effort, strength, and energy, the rules should be followed, and they
should not be given to the unworthy. I bow down to the victorious Bhagavan, the
one who is free from old age, death, defilements, and faults. May I attain
liberation through his teachings. || The Surya Pannatti is complete ||

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

Page #256 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):

Suya-thavira-paniya Chandapannatti-sutta: Homage to the Arhats!  1. The hero,
whose lotus-like eyes are wide open, whose gait is majestic, whose prowess is
like the flowing of a river, is victorious.  2. Bowing down to him who is
worshipped by the gods, asuras, and serpents, the Arhat, the Siddha, the Acarya,
the Upadhyaya, and all the Sadhus.  3. (This text) is the essence of the
previous scriptures, subtle, comprehended by the Ganadhara, and the exposition
of the science of astrology.  4. Goamama, paying homage in three ways, asks the
Jina about the exposition of the science of astrology.  5-8. (Questions about)
the movement of the planets, the paths of the stars, the brightness of the sun,
the setting of the sun, the position of the lunar mansions, the increase and
decrease of the moon, the speed of the planets, and their characteristics.  9.
In this way, there are twenty questions about the various phenomena.  10. Sutra
1: The increase and decrease (of the moon), the position of the muhurtas, who
observes the (celestial) movements, and what they do in between.

| Romanization (original text) |
