##  [Chapter 206] [The Sutra of the Knowledge of the Sun]  **Verse 11:**  There
are five types of *kevali* and six types of *vikampa*. There are seven types of
*mandala* formations, eight types of *vikkhambha*, and eight *pahuḍa*.  **Verse
12:**  The second *sutra* states that six, seven, eight, and three are the
*paḍivatti* (transformations). The first *pahuḍa* has these *paḍivatti*.
**Verse 13:**  The third *sutra* states that the *paḍivatti* arise from the
*udaya* (rising) and *aduv* (setting) of the celestial bodies. They are also
related to the *bheyagha* (fearful), *kaṇṇakala* (ear-related), and *muhutta*
(moments).  **Verse 14:**  When the celestial bodies are setting, they move
quickly, and when they are rising, they move slowly. There are 108 *purisa*
(units of time), and these are the *paḍivatti* for them.  **Verse 15:**  The
fourth *sutra* states that there are eight *bheyagha* (fearful) and two
*paḍivatti* related to them. There are four *muhutta* (moments) and three
*paḍivatti* related to them.  **Verse 16:**  The fourth *sutra* also states that
there are one *āvaliya* (cycle), two *muhutta* (moments), three *evambhāga*
(divisions), four *jogassa* (connections), five *kulāiṁ* (families), six
*puṇṇamāsi* (full moons), seven *sannivāe* (gatherings), and eight *sanṭhiī*
(arrangements).  **Verse 17:**  There are nine *tāraggaṁ* (star-related), ten
*caṇetā* (movements), eleven *candamaggatti* (moon-related), twelve *devatāṇam
ajjhayana* (study of deities), and thirteen *muhuttāṇam nāmayā* (names of
moments).  **Verse 18:**  There are fourteen *divasa* (days), fifteen *rāi*
(nights), sixteen *tihi* (three), seventeen *goṭṭa* (groups), eighteen
*bhoyanāṇi* (food), nineteen *āicca* (sun-related), twenty *māsa* (months), and
twenty *pañca samvachchārā* (five years).  **Verse 19:**  There are twenty-one
*joissassa dārāi* (astrological knowledge), twenty-two *nakkhatavicaye* (study
of constellations). In the tenth *pahuḍa*, there are twenty-two *pahuḍa-pahuḍa*
(sub-chapters).  **Verse 1:**  At that time, in that era, there was a city named
*Mihila* in the *riddhasthimīyasamiddha* (prosperous and stable) region,
inhabited by people of good character and knowledge, and full of joy.  **Verse
2:**  Thirty *yojana* (miles) north of the city of *Mihila*, there was a place
called *Maṇibhaddā* where a *ceiya* (shrine) was built.  **Verse 3:**  Thirty
*yojana* (miles) south of the city of *Mihila*, there was a king named
*Jiyasattūṇāma* and a queen named *Dhāriṇī Devī*.  **Verse 4:**  At that time,
in that era, in the *ceiya* (shrine) of *Maṇibhaddā*, a gathering of people took
place. The *samī* (leader) of the gathering spoke about the *dharma*
(righteousness). The people listened, and the king and queen also came to the
gathering.  **Verse 6:**  At that time, in that era, the *samana* (ascetic)
*Bhagavā Mahāvīra* had a disciple named *Indabhūī* who was an *anagāra*
(celibate) from the *goyam* clan.  **Verse 7:**  ... (The text continues with a
description of *Indabhūī* and his life.)

[Suryaprajnapti Sutra] [207 P. How do you say that the increase in muhutas is
present? U. Gotama! You should say that there are twenty-seven muhutas and
seventy-six parts of a muhuta. || Sutra 8 || Jao ................. This is a
valuable thing, rare for the ignorant. It is the proclamation of the Bhagavati
Joisraya. || 1 || This is to be kept secret, to be honored by the worthy. It
should not be given to many, it should be given to the worthy. || 2 || (Faith)
With enthusiasm, effort, strength, and diligence, one should test the learned
saint. || 3 || He who is outside the family, clan, and assembly of the virtuous,
who is deficient in knowledge and discipline, is a liar, a deceiver of the
Arhats and the elders. || 4 || Therefore, one should hold fast to faith,
enthusiasm, effort, strength, diligence, and knowledge. One should not give it
to the undisciplined. || 5 || I bow down to the victorious Bhagavan, free from
old age, death, defilements, and faults, with respect and reverence. || 6 ||
Sutra 107 || The twentieth chapter is complete. || || The Chandapanatti is
complete. ||

## Appendix ## Mathematical Section of the Surya-Chandra Prajnapti Sutra ##
Sutra Number 8 ## Loss and Gain in the Magnitude of Muhurta: Magnitude of
Muhurta in a Nakshatra Masa  There are 1830 days and nights in a Yuga. There are
67 Nakshatra Masas in a Yuga. Dividing the number of days in a Yuga by the
number of Nakshatra Masas in a Yuga (1830 / 67) gives us 27 days and 21/67
Muhurtas. This is calculated as follows:  67) 1830 (27 134 490 469 21 21/67  To
convert this into Muhurtas, we multiply by 30, which gives us 21430 = 630.
Dividing this by 67 (630:67) gives us 9 Muhurtas and 27/67 parts. Therefore, a
Nakshatra Masa is equal to 27 days, 9 Muhurtas and 27/67 parts.   Multiplying 27
by 30 to convert it into Muhurtas gives us 27 x 30 = 810. Adding 9 to this gives
us 819. Therefore, the number of Muhurtas in a Nakshatra Masa is 819 and 27/67.
## Number of Muhurtas in a Surya Masa  There are 1830 days in a Yuga and 60
Surya Masas in a Yuga. To calculate the number of days in a Surya Masa, we
divide 1830 by 60, which gives us 30 days and 30/60. To convert this into
Muhurtas, we multiply the number of days in a Surya Masa by 30, which gives us
30 x 30 = 900. Multiplying 30/60 by 30 gives us 30 x 30 / 60 = 15 Muhurtas.
Adding this to 900 gives us 915 Muhurtas. Therefore, the number of Muhurtas in a
Surya Masa is 915.  ## Number of Muhurtas in a Chandra Masa  There are 62
Chandra Masas in a Yuga and 1830 days in a Yuga. To calculate the number of days
in a Chandra Masa, we divide 1830 by 62, which gives us 29 days and 32/62. To
convert this into Muhurtas, we multiply by 30, which gives us 29 x 30 = 870.
Multiplying 32/62 by 30 gives us 960/62, which is equal to 15 Muhurtas and 30/62
parts.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

## Appendix ] Adding this number to the aforementioned 870, the total number of
Muhurtas will be 885 Muhurtas and 30/62 Muhurtas. The number of Muhurtas in a
Karmamas is  There are 30 days in a Karmamas. To calculate the number of
Muhurtas, we multiply 30 by 30, which gives us 30 x 30 = 900. This is the number
of Muhurtas in a Karmamas. Months 1. Nakshatra Maas 2. Surya Maas 3. Chandra
Maas 4. Karma Maas || The eighth Sutra of the first Prabhrit ends here || Sutra
numbers 9, 10, 11 The measure of 366 nights and days The Sun travels through 184
mandalas in 366 days. - Sutra [ 209 The Sun takes (366 nights and days) to
travel from the innermost mandala to the outermost mandala and from the
outermost mandala to the innermost mandala. - Sutra no. 9 The measure of the
loss and gain of night and day No. 10 Number of Muhurtas _811x27/67 Mu. 915 Mu.
885. 30/62 Mu. 900 Mu. The Sun revolves from the innermost mandala to the
outermost mandala and from the outermost mandala to the innermost mandala in 366
days. It takes 183 days to revolve from the innermost mandala to the outermost
mandala. When the Sun is in the innermost mandala, there are 18 Muhurtas of day
and 12 Muhurtas of night. It takes 183 days to travel from the innermost mandala
to the outermost mandala, and during that time there is a loss or gain of 6
Muhurtas. There is a gain or loss of 2/61 parts of a Muhurta in a day. That is,
there is a loss of 2/61 parts of a Muhurta in the duration of the day and a gain
of 2/61 parts of a Muhurta in the duration of the night. As the Sun moves
towards the outer mandala, the duration of the day decreases and the duration of
the night increases. When the Sun is present in the outermost mandala, there are
12 Muhurtas of day and 18 Muhurtas of night. As the Sun moves towards the
innermost mandala, the day increases and the night decreases. In the first six
months, the day decreases and the night increases. In the next six months, the
day increases and the night

##  [210] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra]  **Sutra 11:** The rate of loss and gain is
2/61 parts of a Muhurta.  **First Prabhrut, First Prabhrut-Prabhrut ends.**
**Third Prabhrut-Prabhrut:** The meaning cannot be understood because the
'Sayamegam Choyalam' gatha is incomplete. The remaining part is a separate
section. Thus, Shri Aamolak Rishiji has written in the language of Surya
Prajnapti, and even with the commentary by Malayagiri, the actual mathematics
does not come to 144. Those who have knowledge of the mathematical process, if
they are kind enough to explain, it will be considered a service to the
scriptures.  **First Prabhrut, Third Prabhrut-Prabhrut ends.**  **Sutra 15:**
The difference in the time of movement of the two Suns (Bharat and Eravata)
During their movement, there is a difference of 5 yojanas and 35/61 parts in
each mandala between the two Suns. When both Suns are present in the innermost
mandala, there is a difference of 99640 yojanas between them.  The Jambudvipa
region is one lakh yojanas in diameter. Each Sun travels 180 yojanas in its
descent.  Out of 100000 yojanas, the descent area of both Suns is 180 and 180
yojanas, totaling 360 yojanas. Subtracting this from 100000 yojanas, 99640
yojanas remain, which is the difference between the two Suns present in the
innermost mandala.  There are 183 differences in the 184 solar mandalas, and
there is a difference of 2 yojanas and 48/61 parts from one mandala to the next.
Therefore, when the Sun moves from one mandala to another, the difference
between the two mandalas on both sides, when added together (2 yojanas 48/61 and
2 yojanas 48/61), becomes 5 yojanas and 35/61 parts.  The difference between the
two Suns present in the outermost mandala:  The difference between the two Suns
in each mandala is 5 yojanas and 35/61 parts, as explained earlier. The
outermost mandala is the 183rd from the innermost mandala. Multiplying 183 by 5
yojanas and 35/61 parts, we get 3434°, which comes to 1020 yojanas. Adding this
1020 yojanas difference to 99640, we get 100660 yojanas, which is the difference
between the two Suns present in the outermost mandala.  **Sutra 15**  **First
Prabhrut, Fourth Prabhrut-Prabhrut ends.**  **The Sun's movement area in one day
and night:**  The Sun travels 2 yojanas and 48/61 parts in one day and night. In
183 days, the Sun travels 510 yojanas...

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 210 ] [ sUryaprajJaptisUtra ghaTatI hai| hAni-vRddhi kA pramANa muhUrta ke 2/61

## Appendix] The Sun traverses 2 yojanas and 48/61 parts in a day. The Sun
traverses 183 mandalas in 183 days. It traverses one mandala in a day. The total
area traversed by the Sun in all the mandalas is 510 yojanas. The traversal of
one mandala in a day is 2 yojanas and 48/61 parts. - Sutra 18 || The sixth
prabhrut of the first prabhrut - prabhrut ends || Sutra 20 The diameter-extent
of each mandala When the Sun is in the innermost mandala, it traverses 48/61
parts of 1 lakh yojanas from the outer edge, with an extent of 99640 yojanas, a
diameter of 315089 yojanas, and a displacement of 315089 yojanas. Then there is
a superior day of 18 muhurtas and an inferior night of 12 muhurtas. When the Sun
traverses to the mandala next to the innermost mandala, it traverses 48/61 parts
of one yojana from the outer edge, with an extent of 99645 yojanas and 35/61
parts, a diameter of 315107 yojanas, and a slightly less displacement. Then the
measure of day and night is the same as in the innermost mandala. The measure of
extent-diameter in the innermost mandala [ 211 One Sun traverses by moving 180
yojanas. Compared to the two Suns of Jambudvipa, the traversal of 360 yojanas is
reduced from the 1 lakh yojanas of the Jambudvipa region, leaving 99640 yojanas.
This is the extent-diameter of the innermost mandala. Sutra 20 The displacement
of the innermost mandala The displacement of the innermost mandala is (315089)
yojanas. It is as follows: (Diameter of the innermost mandala) 2x10 Considering
the displacement from this formula, it will be as follows: ) (99640) 2x10
)9928129600×10 ) 99281296000 99281296000

## Appendix ] 1) 1156000 1 1 207 01560 7 1449 [ 213 2145011100 5 10725 2150
00375 To make 1075 yojanas, divide by 61 [ 1075 / 61] which gives 17 yojanas
38/61. In each mandala, the parikshep increases by 17 yojanas 38/61. The
parikshep of each parimandala is 18 yojanas by vyavahar and 17 yojanas 38/61 by
nischya. Adding 18 yojanas to the parikshep of each mandala gives the parikshep
of the next mandala. Doing this, the sun transits and reaches the outermost
mandala, then the ayam vishkambh becomes 100660. The parikshep of the outermost
mandala is 318314.869. By vyavahar, it is 618315. Method to calculate the ayam -
vishkambh - parikshep of the outermost mandala In each mandala, 5 yojanas 35/61
increase, so how much will the increase be in the outermost mandala? Since there
are 183 parimandala, multiplying by 5 yojanas 35/61 gives 183 mandalas 45
yojanas = 915 yojanas. 35 parts × 183 mandalas = 6405. To make these into
yojanas, divide 6405 by 61, which gives 105 yojanas. Adding 105 yojanas to the
aforementioned 915 yojanas gives 1020 yojanas. Adding 1020 yojanas to the ayam
of the innermost mandala, 99640 yojanas, gives the ayam of the outermost
mandala, 100660 yojanas. The parikshep of the outermost mandala is 318315
yojanas. The method to obtain this is as follows: Method to calculate the
parikshep of the outermost mandala To calculate the parikshep: ) (ayam) 2x10 )
(100600) 2×10 ) 10132435600×10 -

## Appendix] To divide 6954 yojanas by 61, we get 114 yojanas. Adding 114
yojanas to 3111 yojanas, we get 3225 yojanas, which is the increase in the
circumference of the 183rd circle. Adding 3225 yojanas to the circumference of
the innermost circle, which is 315089 yojanas, we get the circumference of the
outermost circle, which is 318314 yojanas. The original text of this formula
states that the circumference of the outermost circle is 318315 yojanas. This
should be understood practically. Because when we calculate the circumference of
each circle, a remainder of 375 yojanas increases. Multiplying this by 183
circles, we get 68625. Dividing this number by 2150, we get 31. Since this is
more than the expected 61 half-parts, it is considered complete in practice and
is stated as 318315. Ka Formula 2.3 The speed of the Sun in each circle per
muhurta The difference between each circle is 2 yojanas 48/61 parts. The
difference between both the Sun's circles is 5 yojanas 35/61 parts. The area of
the entire circle is 510 yojanas. Formula 20 || The first prabhrit is the eighth
prabhrit-prabhrit ends || [ 215 - That is, in 2 days and nights, both Suns
complete one circle. The specific speed of the Sun in each muhurta can be known
from this formula - - Speed in 1 muhurta = Circumference of the circle /
Muhurtas in 2 days and nights According to 30 muhurtas in 1 day and night, there
are 60 muhurtas in 2 days and nights. The circumference of the innermost circle
is 315089 yojanas. Both Suns complete the revolution of the innermost circle in
60 muhurtas. When the Sun transitions between circles, it transitions with its
own specific speed. Both the Suns of Bharat Kshetra and Airāvata Kshetra
transition with their specific speeds and complete one circle in 60 muhurtas.
The speed of the Sun in 1 muhurta in the innermost circle Circumference of the
innermost circle / 60 muhurtas = Speed in 1 muhurta. 315089 yojanas / 60
muhurtas = 5251 yojanas 29/60 parts is the speed of the Sun in 1 muhurta.
Practically, there is a difference of 18 yojanas in the circumference of each
circle. That is, adding 18 yojanas to the circumference of the innermost circle,
we get the circumference of the next circle. Accordingly,

##  [216] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra]  The circumference of the third circle is
obtained by adding 18 yojanas to the circumference of the second circle. In this
way, the circumference of each circle can be determined.  To know how much the
Sun's speed increases in one muhurta in each circle, this formula should be
used:  Increase in circumference of each circle / 60 muhurtas.  There is an
increase of 18 yojanas in the circumference of each circle. Dividing it by 60
muhurtas will give the speed increase in one muhurta.  18 yojanas (increase in
circumference of each circle) / 60 muhurtas = 18/60 yojanas increase in speed
per muhurta.  **Method to determine the difference in the Sun's visual path
area**  To determine the difference in the Sun's visual path area in each
circle, the following formula should be used:  The Sun's speed in one muhurta in
each circle is half of the day-measure.  The measure of the Sun's visual path
area in the innermost circle is 47263 yojanas 21/60 parts. Using the above
formula to know this: 5251 yojanas 29/60 parts.  (Sun's speed in one muhurta in
the innermost circle) x 9 muhurtas (half of the day-measure) = 31508949 2835801
/ 60 = 47263 yojanas 21/60 parts is the Sun's visual path area in the innermost
circle.  **Another method to know the measure of the Sun's visual path area in
the innermost circle**  Circumference of each circle x half of the day-measure
60  Circumference of each circle x half of the day-measure 60  31508949 60

[Appendix] [ 217 =2835801 60 -47263 Yojan 21/60 parts is the field of vision of
the Sun in the innermost circle. The proof of the field of vision of the Sun in
the outermost circle The speed of the Sun in one Muhurta in the outermost circle
is the time taken by the outermost circle to revolve around the circle - - 60
Muhurta 318315 Yojan = 5305 Yojan 15. 60 parts is the speed of the Sun in one
Muhurta. To find the proof of the field of vision of the Sun in the outermost
circle, the following formula should be used - The speed of the Sun in one
Muhurta in the outermost circle is half of the day-measure = 31831546 Muhurta
half of the day-measure 60 = 1909890 60 = 31831 Yojan 30. 60 parts is the proof
of the field of vision in the outermost circle. Second method - Circumference x
half of the day-measure 60 = 31831546 60 = 1909890 60 . = 31831 Yojan 30. 60
parts is the proof of the field of vision in the outermost circle 1 - To find
the speed of the Sun in one Muhurta in each circle, the circumference of each
circle should be

[218] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra] Dividing 60 by 1 gives the speed of 1 Muhurta. 2 -
To find the measure of the field of vision, multiply the speed of 1 Muhurta by
half the day-span (of the Sun). The result is the measure of the field of
vision. - Sutra 23 || Second Prabhrut is complete || Sutra 24 The measure of the
area illuminated by the Sun _When the Sun is in the innermost circle, it
illuminates one and a half parts of the five imagined circles of Jambudvipa and
one part remains unilluminated. In Jambudvipa, both Suns illuminate three parts
of the five circles and two parts remain unilluminated. That is, in the five
imagined parts of Jambudvipa, three parts are day and two parts are night. _
Imagining 366 parts of Jambudvipa, 1 part (circle) has 732 parts, 3 circles have
2196 parts. That is, out of 3660 parts, 2196 parts are day and 1464 parts are
night, or both Suns complete one revolution of the circle in 60 Muhurtas.
Imagining 5 circles of Jambudvipa, 1 circle is 12 Muhurta-like. The time of 12
Muhurtas is 732 parts in the imagined 3660 parts of Jambudvipa. When the Sun
moves from the innermost circle towards the outermost circle, there is a loss-
gain of 2.61 parts in the day-night in each circle. . Reducing the innermost
circle, the outermost circle comes 183rd. By doing 18342, there is a loss-gain
of 366/61 parts in the day-night. That is, there is a loss of 6 Muhurtas in the
day and an increase in the night. With respect to both Suns, there is a loss-
gain of 12 Muhurtas. In the outermost circle, the Sun illuminates one part and
one and a half parts remain unilluminated. As mentioned earlier, with respect to
each Sun, there is 1 part day and 1 and a half parts night. With respect to both
Suns, there are 2 parts day and 3 parts night. In the innermost circle, there
are 3 parts day and 2 parts night. In the outermost circle, there are 2 parts
day and 3 parts night. 1 part should be known as 12 Muhurta-like.

| Romanization (original text) |

## 220] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra 6324547 048447100 44271829 63245546 0427527100
379473276 63245552 48053824 776 is greater than half (500) of one thousand.
According to the rule 'Ardhaadurdhvamekam Grahyam', the previous number is
counted and 31623 Yojanas are mentioned in practice. Multiplying them by three
gives 94869. Dividing them by 10 gives 9486 Yojanas 9/10 parts, which is the
magnitude of the innermost outer boundary of the Tapaskhetra. The magnitude of
the outermost boundary from the circumference of Jambudvipa is ‘Parikshep =
(Vishkambh)410 The circumference of Jambudvipa is well-known. Multiplying it by
3 and dividing by 10 gives 94868 Yojanas 4/10. The circumference of Jambudvipa
is 316227 Yojanas, 3 Gavyutis 128 Yojanas and 13/ Angulas. But in practice,
considering it as 316228 Yojanas and multiplying it gives 948684 Yojanas.
Dividing them by 10 gives 94868 Yojanas 4/10 parts, which is the magnitude of
the outermost boundary. The dimension of the Tapaskhetra from North to South
direction is Aayam = Difference between North and South direction Vishkambh =
Difference between East and West direction The dimension of the Tapaskhetra is
78333 Yojanas 1/3 parts. From Meru Parvat to Jambudvipa, it is 45000 Yojanas.
One-sixth of the extent of the Lavana Samudra is 33333.333 Yojanas. Adding both
gives the dimension of the Tapaskhetra as 78333.333 Yojanas. The magnitude of
the innermost outer boundary of the Andhakar Sansthiti is The magnitude of the
innermost outer boundary of the Andhakar Sansthiti is 6324 Yojanas 6/10 parts.
Multiplying the circumference of Meru Parvat by 2 and dividing by 10 gives 63246
Yojanas. Dividing them by 10 gives 6324 Yojanas 6/10, which is the innermost
outer boundary of the Andhakar Sansthiti.

## Appendix ] [ 221 The outermost boundary of the darkness region extending from
the salt sea to the nearby Jambudvipa The outermost boundary is obtained by
multiplying the circumference of Jambudvipa by 2 and dividing by 10. The
circumference of Jambudvipa is 316228 yojanas. Multiplying it by 2 gives 632456
yojanas. Dividing by 10, we get 63245 yojanas 6/10 parts as the outermost
boundary. The length of the darkness region should be known as the length of the
heat region. The heat region in the innermost circle should be known as the
darkness region in the outermost circle. The darkness region in the innermost
circle should be known as the heat region in the outermost circle. That is, the
inner boundary of the heat region in the outermost circle is 6324 yojanas 6/10
parts. The outer boundary is 63245 yojanas 6/10 parts. The length of the heat
region is 78333.333 yojanas. The darkness region in the outermost circle has an
inner boundary of 9486 yojanas 9/10 parts. The remaining boundary is 94868
yojanas 4/10 parts. The length of the darkness region is 78333.333 yojanas. -
Sutra 25 ends || Fourth Prabhrut ends || Sutra 33 Second Prabhrut of the tenth

##  [222] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra Muhurta]  This section explains how many
Muhurtas a particular Nakshatra (constellation) forms with the Moon.  **To
determine the Muhurta formed by a Nakshatra with the Sun:**  * **Nakshatra
Name:** Abhijit, Shatabhisha, Bharani, Aardra, Ashlesha, Swati, Jyeshta,
Shravana, Dhanishta, Purva Bhadrapada, Revati, Ashwini, Krittika, Mrigashira,
Pushya, Magha, Purva Phalguni, Hasta, Chitra, Anuradha, Moola, Purva Ashadha,
Uttara Bhadrapada, Rohini, Punarvasu, Uttara Phalguni, Visakha, Uttara Ashadha.
* **Days:** 203  **Calculation:**  * A Nakshatra travels a certain number of
parts out of 67 parts of a day with the Moon. * To find the Muhurta formed with
the Sun, divide the number of parts traveled with the Moon by 5. * The result
will be in days and parts of a Muhurta. * To convert parts of a Muhurta to full
Muhurtas, multiply by 30.  **Example:**  * Abhijit Nakshatra travels 21/67 parts
of a day with the Moon. * Dividing 21 by 5 gives 4 days and 1.5 parts of a
Muhurta. * Multiplying 1.5 by 30 gives 6 Muhurtas. * Therefore, Abhijit
Nakshatra forms a conjunction with the Sun for 4 days and 6 Muhurtas.  **Another
Example:**  * Shatabhisha Nakshatra travels 33/67 parts of a day with the Moon.
* Dividing 33 by 5 gives 6 days and 3/5 parts of a Muhurta. * Multiplying 3/5 by
30 gives 18 Muhurtas. * Therefore, Shatabhisha Nakshatra forms a conjunction
with the Sun for 6 days and 18 Muhurtas.  **Note:** This calculation applies to
all the Nakshatras listed above.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

sUrya ke sAtha yoga nakSatra saMkhyA sUrya ke sAtha yoga nakSatroM kA nAma
divasa abhijita zatabhiSA, bharaNI, AdrA, AzleSA, svAti, jyeSThA zravaNa,
dhaniSThA, pUrvA, bhA. revatI, azvinI kRtikA, mRgazira, puSya, maghA; pU. phA.

## Appendix ] [ 223 30 Muhurta Yoga with Moon, Nakshatra's Yoga Time with Sun If
Shravana Nakshatra makes a yoga of 67 parts with the Moon in one day, then how
much time does it make yoga with the Sun? To know the time of yoga with the Sun,
divide the time of yoga with the Moon by 5, the quotient obtained from the
divisor-dividend ratio should be understood as the yoga time of the Nakshatra
with the Sun. 67/5 = 13, days To get 2.5 Muhurta, multiply by 30, which makes 12
Muhurta. Therefore, in that way, 13 days 12 Muhurta should be known as the yoga
time of the Sun with other Nakshatras. 45 Muhurta Yoga with Moon, Nakshatra's
Yoga Time with Sun Uttarabhadrapada Nakshatra makes a yoga of 201 parts with the
Moon. To understand how much time it makes yoga with the Sun, divide by 5, 201/4
= 201. Making days out of them, there will be 20 days and 3 Muhurta time. Which
is the yoga time of Uttarabhadrapada Nakshatra with the Sun. - Sutra 34 ends . .
|| Second Prabhrit of the Tenth Prabhrit - Prabhrit ends || Sutra 40 Full Moon
and New Moon's Moon Yoga, Sannipat Purnima Total Nakshatra, Upkula Nakshatra,
Kulopakul Nakshatra, Shravana, Magh Dhanishtha, Shravana Abhijit, Bhadrapada,
Falguni, U. Bhadrapada, P. Bhadrapada, Shatabhisha, Ashwini, Chaitri Ashwini,
Revati, Kartika, Vaishakhi, Krittika Bharani, Margashirsha, Jyeshta Mrigashira,
Rohini, Pausha, Ashadha, Pushya Punarvasu, Madhvi, Shravana Ashlesha, Falguni U.
Falguni, P. Falguni, Chaitri, Ashwini, Chitra Hasta, 10. Vaishakhi, Kartiki,
Visakha, Swati Amavasya 2. ni ni Aadra w Magha Bhadrapada

## Appendix ] The 22nd (twenty-second) Prabhrit-Prabhrit of the tenth Prabhrit
**Sutra 62** **Section on the Circumference of the Boundary** 630 1005 2010 3015
56 (See the names of the Nakshatras in the second Prabhrit-Prabhrit of the tenth
Prabhrit) One should imagine 67 parts of an Aho-ratra. **Nakshatra Number** 2
**Ardhakshetra Nakshatras 12** **Samakshetra Nakshatras 30** **Dvyardhakshetra
Nakshatras 12** **Sutra 72: Twelfth Prabhrit** **Proof of the Years** There are.
Five types of years have been mentioned. - It is 67 parts. [ 1. Nakshatra
Samvatsara, 2. Chandra Samvatsara, 3. Ritu Samvatsara, 4. Aditya Samvatsara, 5.
Abhivrdhit Samvatsara. In a Nakshatra month, there are 27 days and 21/67
Muhurtas. A Nakshatra month is 119 Muhurtas and 27/ 1. Nakshatra Samvatsara 225
**Name of the Nakshatra** Two Abhijit Two Shatabhasha up to two Jyestha Two
Shravana up to two Purvashadha Two Uttarabhadrapada up to two Uttarashadha
**Sutra 62 ends.** How many days are there in a Nakshatra Samvatsara? - There
are 327 days and 51/67 parts. A Nakshatra Samvatsara is 9832 Muhurtas and 55/67
parts. 1830x30 67 There are 67 Nakshatras in one Yuga. There are 1830 days in
one Yuga. To find the days of a Nakshatra month, divide 1830 by 67, which gives
27 days and 21/67 parts. = To find the Muhurtas of a Nakshatra month, multiply
the days of the Nakshatra month by 30 Muhurtas of one day, which will give the
number of Muhurtas - 54900 67 819 Muhurtas and 27/67 parts To find the days of a
Nakshatra Samvatsara, multiply the days of a Nakshatra month by 12.

##  [226] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra] 1830412 21960 - = 67 327 Muhurta 51/67 parts
67. Nakshatra Samvatsara has these days. To calculate the Muhurta of Nakshatra
Samvatsara, multiply the days of Nakshatra Samvatsara by 30. Doing so, 21960 x
30 - 658800 - 9832 Muhurta 56/67 parts are the Muhurta of Nakshatra Samvatsara.
2. Chandra Samvatsara The Chandra Maas has 29 days 32/62 Muhurta. Chandra Maas
is 885 Muhurta 30/60 parts. Chandra Samvatsara is 354 days 12/62 Muhurta.
Chandra Samvatsara is 10625 Muhurta 50/62 parts. 1 Yuga has 62 Chandra Maas. 1
Yuga has 1830 days. To know the days of 1 Chandra Maas, divide 1830 by 62. 1830
/ 62 = 29 days 32/62 Muhurta. To know the Muhurta of Chandra Maas, multiply the
number of days of Chandra Maas by 30 - 1830 x 30 - 54900 - 885 Muhurta 30/62
parts. 62 To know the days of Chandra Samvatsara, multiply the days of Chandra
Maas by 12. 1830 x 12 - 21960 - 354 days 12/62 Muhurta is Chandra Samvatsara. 67
67 To know the Muhurta of Chandra Samvatsara, multiply the days of the year by
30. 21960 x 30 - 658800 - 10625 Muhurta 50/62 parts. 62 2. Ritu Samvatsara 1
Yuga has 61 Ritu Maas. 1 Ritu Maas has 30 days. 1 Ritu Maas has 900 Muhurta.

**Appendix** [227] 1. There are 360 days in a season year. 2. There are 10,800
moments (an ancient Indian unit of time) in a season year.  3. In the
Adityasamvat (the year starting with the sun), there are 60 Adityamasa (solar
months).  4. Each Adityamasa has 30 days.  5. Each Adityamasa has 915 moments.
6. There are 366 days in an Adityasamvat.  7. There are 10,980 moments in an
Adityasamvat.   2. In the Abhivardhita samvat (an enhanced year), there are 31
days in an Abhivardhita month, 29 moments, and 17/62 parts.  1. Each
Abhivardhita month has 959 moments and 17/62 parts.  2. In an Abhivardhita
samvat, there are 383 days, 21 moments, and 18/62 parts.  3. An Abhivardhita
samvat has 11,511 moments and 18/62 parts.  - Sutra 72 ends, Sutra 73 begins.
Evidence for the day and night of the nine yugas 1. Nakshatrasamvat (lunar year)
has 327 days, 22 hours, and 51 minutes.  2. Chandrasamvat (lunar year) has 354
days.  3. Ritusamvat (season year) has 360 days.  4. Adityasamvat has 366 days.
5. Abhivardhita samvat has 383 days and 21 moments (time unit).  Total moments
in the nine yugas 1,791,157 and 55/67 parts   How many days are needed to
complete a yuga in the nine yugas? - 38 days and 10 moments: Completing a yuga
requires adding 12/67 parts.  Day 3 5 x x x x x x

[228] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra]  How many Muhurta are required to complete the
Muhurta of a Yuga? 38430-1041+10-11 Muhurta, 1150 Muhurta, divided by 12/67,
when added to the Churnita Bhaga, complete the Muhurta of a Yuga. How many days
are there in a Yuga? 1830 days. How many Muhurta are there in a Yuga? 1830 x
430-54900 Muhurta. How many Vasathiya Bhaga are there in 54900 Muhurta? 54900 x
462 = 3403800 Vasathiya Bhaga. - Sutra 73 ends || Twelfth Prabhrut ends || Sutra
79 Thirteenth Prabhrut, the decrease and increase of the Moon In the Shukla
Paksha, there is an increase, and in the Krishna Paksha, there is a decrease. In
the Shukla Paksha, there is an increase of 442 Muhurta 46/62 Bhaga. In the
Krishna Paksha, there is a decrease of 442 Muhurta 46/62 Bhaga. The measure of
the Chandra Masa and the measure of the Muhurta of the Chandra Masa should be
known according to Sutra 72. In the Shukla Paksha, there are 442 Muhurta 46/62
Bhaga. In the Krishna Paksha, there are 442 Muhurta 46/62 Bhaga. One Paksha is
14 days 47/62 Bhaga. - Sutra 79 ends. Sutra 80 In one Yuga, there are 62 Purnima
and 62 Amavasya. Until Amavasya and Purnima, there are 442 Muhurta 46/62 Bhaga.
From Purnima to Amavasya, there are 442 Muhurta 46/62 Bhaga. From Purnima to
Purnima, there are 885 Muhurta 30/62 Bhaga. From Amavasya to Amavasya, there are
885 Muhurta 30/62 Bhaga. - Sutra 80 ends. || Thirteenth Prabhrut ends ||

## Appendix ] ## Sutra 83 ## The Moon's Motion in One Muhurta (1/60th of a
Ghati)  In one Muhurta, the Moon travels 1768 parts of its respective Mandala
(circle). There are 1768 Ardhamandalas (half-circles) in one Yuga (epoch). One
Yuga is 1830 days. How many nights and days does the Moon take to complete one
Mandala (circle)?  To find this: - 1830 days x 2 Ardhamandalas 3660 1768 parts
1768 = 2 days 124/1768 parts.  To convert 124/1768 parts into Muhurtas, multiply
them by 30: 124 x 30 = 3720 = 465 221 x 109800 13725 = - 1768 1768 221 = 2 days
2 Muhurtas 23/221 parts.  Therefore, the Moon completes one Mandala in 2 days 2
Muhurtas 23/221 parts.  What is the Moon's speed in one Muhurta?  If the Moon
travels 109800 parts (the circumference of the Mandala) in 62 Muhurtas 23/221
parts, then to find its speed in one Muhurta: 24265800 13725 Multiplying by 1768
parts The Moon travels 1768 parts in one Muhurta.  The Sun travels 1830 parts in
one Muhurta. The Sun completes one Mandala in two days, meaning it travels
109800 parts in 60 Muhurtas. How many parts does it travel in one Muhurta? [229
-

[230] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra 109800 1830 60 Surya travels 1830 parts in one
part. Nakshatra travels 1835 parts in one Muhurta. To know Muhurta, it is
necessary to find the transition time of 1 Mandala. It takes 1830 days to
complete 1835 Ardha Mandala. How many days does it take to complete two Ardha
Mandala? 24183° = 1 day 1825/1835 Muhurta 1835 1825 parts of Muhurta are made,
1825430 - 1875 29 Muhurta 307/367 come. That is, it takes 1 day 29 Muhurta
307/367 parts of time for Nakshatra to complete 1 Mandala. That is, it takes
307/367 parts of time in 59 Muhurta. That is, it travels 109800 parts in 59
Muhurta. How many parts will it travel in one Muhurta? 1835 59307 367 21960 367
3674109800 21960 = 1835 parts travel in one Muhurta. What is the special feature
in the movement of Surya-Chandra? Surya-Chandra travels 62 parts special. Surya
1830 - Chandra 1768 = 62 parts When Chandra's movement is completed, what is
special about Nakshatra's movement? Nakshatra travels 67 parts special. Because
Nakshatra travels 1835 parts. Chandra travels 1768 parts. Nakshatra 1835 -
Chandra 1768 = 67 parts travel more.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 230 ] [ sUryaprajJaptisUtra 109800 1830 60 sUrya eka bhAga meM 1830 bhAga
gamana karatA hai| nakSatra eka muhUrta meM 1835 bhAga gamana karatA hai|
muhUrta jAnane ke liye 1 maMDala kA saMkramaNakAla nikAlanA jarUrI hai| 1835
ardhamaMDala pUrNa karane meM 1830 divasa lagate haiN| do ardhamaMDala pUrNa
karane meM kitane divasa lagate haiM ? 24183deg = 1 divasa 1825/1835 muhUrta
1835 1825 bhAga ke muhUrta banAne ke liye 1825430 - 1875 29 muhUrta 307/367 Ate
haiN| arthAt nakSatra ko 1 maMDala pUrNa karane meM 1 divasa 29 muhUrta 307/367
bhAga samaya lagatA hai| arthAt 59 muhUrta meM 307/367 bhAga samaya lagatA hai|

bhAga parikSepa karegA? 1835 59307 367 21960 367 3674109800 21960 = 1835 bhAga

[Appendix] [ 231 Sutra 85 How many mandalas does the Moon traverse in a
Nakshatra month? The Moon traverses 13 mandalas and 13/67 parts in a Nakshatra
month. The reason for this is that there are 67 Nakshatra months in a Yuga. The
lunar mandala is 884. In 67 Nakshatra months, the Moon traverses 884 lunar
mandalas. How many mandalas does it traverse in one Nakshatra month? 884 / 67 =
13 mandalas and 13/67 parts. How many mandalas does the Sun traverse in a
Nakshatra month? It traverses 13 mandalas and 44/67 parts. If the Sun traverses
915 solar mandalas in 67 Nakshatra months of a Yuga, how many mandalas does it
traverse in one month? 915 / 67 = 13 mandalas and 44/67 parts. How many mandalas
does a Nakshatra traverse in a Nakshatra month? It traverses 1835 ardhamandalas
in 67 Nakshatra months of a Yuga. 1835 / 67 = 27 ardhamandalas and 26/67 parts.
Upon dividing them by 2 to form mandalas, we get 1835 / 2 = 13 16/67 mandalas.
How many mandalas does the Moon traverse in a Chandra month? It traverses 884
mandalas in 124 parvas. How many mandalas does it traverse in 2 parvas? 248 /
884 = 1768 / 124 = 124 / 124 = 144 14 mandalas and 32/124 parts of the fifteenth
mandala. How many mandalas does the Sun traverse in a Chandra month? One-fourth
less than 15 mandalas and one part of 124 parts. 14 mandalas and 94/124 parts of
the fifteenth mandala. How is this so?

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
 pariziSTa ] [ 231 sUtra 85 nakSatramAsa meM candra kitane maMDala gati karatA
hai ? candra eka nakSatramAsa meM 13 maMDala 13/67 bhAga gati karatA hai  /
isakA kAraNa yaha hai ki eka yuga ke nakSatramAsa 67 haiN| candramaMDala 884
hai| 67 nakSatramAsa meM 884 candramaMDala candragati karatA hai| eka
nakSatramAsa meM kitane maMDala gati karatA hai ?  /  884 5 67 = 13 maMDala

[232] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra] If the Sun travels 915 **mandalas** in 124
**parvas**, then how many **mandalas** does it travel in 2 **parvas**? 24915 .
1830 . 147 124 - 124 - 10 124 **mandalas** it travels. How many **mandalas**
does the Moon travel in a **Chandra masa**? 14 **mandalas** and 34 parts of the
15th **mandala**. In 124 **parvas**, the Moon travels 1835 **ardha mandalas**.
How many **ardha mandalas** does it travel in 2 **parvas**? 241835 3670 124 -
124 - 29 124 Since two **ardha mandalas** make one **mandala**, dividing by two
gives - 36702.4 **mandalas** and 99/124 parts. 124 = 14 **mandalas** and How
many **mandalas** does the Moon travel in a **Ritu masa**? In 61 **karma
masas**, the Moon travels 884 **mandalas**. How many **mandalas** will it travel
in one **karma masa**? 884  _ 61. 30 14 - 61 14 **mandalas** and 30/61 parts of
the 15th **mandala**. How many **mandalas** does the Sun travel in a **Ritu
masa**? In 61 **karma masas**, the Sun travels 915 **mandalas**. How many
**mandalas** will it travel in one **karma masa**? 915 - = 61 15 **mandalas** it
travels.

##  [234] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra]  How many lunar mandalas does the moon
traverse in an adhimasa (intercalary month)? There are 573 adhimasas in a Yuga.
As stated in the Muhurta Parva of an adhimasa, there are 95937 Muhurtas in a
month. 959462 + 17 - 51675 Muhurtas in a Yuga = 1830430 - 54900 Muhurtas. These
should be divided into 62 parts. 54900 / 62 = 3403800 parts. 59475 / 62 Muhurtas
make up one adhimasa. How many months will there be in 54900 Muhurtas? 54900 /
62 = 3403800.  59475 / 59475 = 57.3 (The remainder is 4775). 57 x 13725 = 57
adhimasas = 3/13 parts.  The moon traverses 884 lunar mandalas in 57 adhimasas.
So, how many lunar mandalas will it traverse in one adhimasa? 57.3 = 744/13. How
many lunar mandalas will the moon traverse in 744/13 adhimasas?  884 / 13 =
11492.15 744 744 185 15 lunar mandalas. 83/186 parts.  How many lunar mandalas
does the sun traverse in an adhimasa?  There are 744/13 adhimasas in a Yuga, and
the sun traverses 915 solar mandalas in them. So, how many solar mandalas will
the sun traverse in one adhimasa?  915 / 13 = 11895.15245 744 = 744 - 15248

Appendix - 2 Surya Prajnapti Sutra Sutras 20 and 24 The dimensions,
circumference and diameter of the solar sphere are described. **Question:**
Venerable Sir! What are the dimensions, circumference and diameter of the solar
sphere? **Answer:**  Venerable Sir! The solar sphere is described as having a
diameter of 49 yojanas and 61 angulas, a circumference of three times the
diameter plus 22 angulas, and a diameter of 24 yojanas and 61 angulas. -
Jambudvipa Vakya 7, Sutra 130 The area illuminated by the sun on Jambudvipa is
described. **Question:** Venerable Sir! On Jambudvipa, is the area illuminated
by the sun the same, less or more than the area illuminated by the sun?
**Answer:** Venerable Sir! The area illuminated by the sun is not the same, it
is less than the area illuminated by the sun, and it is not more than the area
illuminated by the sun. **Question:** Venerable Sir! Is the area illuminated by
the sun in front or behind? **Answer:** Venerable Sir! The area illuminated by
the sun is in front, not behind. **Question:** Venerable Sir! Is the area
illuminated by the sun in one direction or in six directions? **Answer:**
Venerable Sir! The area illuminated by the sun is in one direction, not in six
directions. 1. (a) The solar sphere is described as having a diameter of 49
yojanas and 61 angulas. - Sama 48, Sutra 3 (b) The solar sphere is described as
having a diameter of 13 yojanas and 61 angulas less than the diameter of the
Jambudvipa. - Sama 13, Sutra 8 2. The word "Yavat" is used to indicate that the
area illuminated by the sun is limited. **Question:** Venerable Sir! Is the area
illuminated by the sun dense or sparse? **Answer:** Venerable Sir! The area
illuminated by the sun is dense, not sparse. **Question:** Venerable Sir! Is the
area illuminated by the sun continuously dense or intermittently dense?
**Answer:** Venerable Sir! The area illuminated by the sun is continuously
dense, not intermittently dense. **Question:** Venerable Sir! Is the area
illuminated by the sun inside or outside? **Answer:** Venerable Sir! The area
illuminated by the sun is both inside and outside. **Question:** Venerable Sir!
Is the area illuminated by the sun above, sideways or below? **Answer:**
Venerable Sir! The area illuminated by the sun is above, sideways and below.
**Question:** Venerable Sir! Is the area illuminated by the sun at the
beginning, middle or end? **Answer:** Venerable Sir! The area illuminated by the
sun is at the beginning, middle and end. **Question:** Venerable Sir! Is the
area illuminated by the sun with or without a shadow? **Answer:** Venerable Sir!
The area illuminated by the sun is with a shadow, not without a shadow. (To be
continued)

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

[Appendix-2] [239] Q. Gotama! Do they shine in one direction, or in all six
directions? A. Gotama! They do not shine in one direction, they shine in all six
directions. - Viya. S. 8, U. 8, Su. 39, 40 Q. Venerable Sir! On Jambudvipa, does
the sun's light illuminate the land that is below, the land that is above, or
the land that is neither above nor below? A. Gotama! It does not illuminate the
land that is neither above nor below, it illuminates the land that is below, it
does not illuminate the land that is above, it is like this, it is like this, as
long as they shine in all six directions. - Viya. S. 8, U. 8, Su. 41-42 Q.
Venerable Sir! On Jambudvipa, how high does the sun's light extend? How low does
it extend? How far does it extend sideways? A. Gotama! It extends one hundred
yojanas high, eighteen hundred yojanas low, and sixty-six yojanas sideways,
twice that number of yojanas, and twenty-one yojanas. - Viya. S. 8, U. 8, Su. 45
Q. Venerable Sir! Does it shine proportionally, or disproportionately? A.
Gotama! It shines proportionally, it does not shine disproportionately. Q.
Venerable Sir! In which direction does it shine? A. Gotama! It shines in all six
directions. - Viya. S. 8, U. 8, Su. 39 Note [Q. Venerable Sir! Does it shine in
one direction, or in all six directions? A. Gotama! It does not shine in one
direction, it shines in all six directions.] (Variant reading) 1. Jambu. Vakkh.
7, Su. 137 2. Jambu. Vakkh. 7, Su. 137 3. (a) Jambu. Vakkh. 7, 139 (b) Suriy.
Pa. 4, Su. 25 The sun's chariot is one hundred yojanas above the chariot of
Saturn, and that is the limit of the celestial sphere. Therefore, there is no
heat zone above this. 4. From the western Mahavideha of Jambudvipa towards the
Jayanta Gate, near the Salt Sea, the land is one thousand yojanas below. In
comparison to this, the sun's chariot is one thousand yojanas high and eight
hundred yojanas high from the level ground near Meru. Combining these eight
hundred yojanas, the heat zone below the sun's chariot is eighteen hundred
yojanas. In other islands, the land remains level. Therefore, the heat zone
below the sun there is only eight hundred yojanas. Combining the eighteen
hundred yojanas of the heat zone below and the one hundred yojanas of the heat
zone above, the sun's heat zone is nineteen hundred yojanas. 5. The sideways
heat zone is mentioned in relation to the east-west direction, meaning that the
sun is visible to the human eye at that distance. In the north, the sun is
visible at a distance of forty-five thousand yojanas minus one hundred and
eighty yojanas, and in the south, it is visible at a distance of thirty-three
thousand three hundred and thirty-three yojanas in the island and one hundred
and eighty yojanas in the Salt Sea, plus one-third of a yojana.

| Romanization (original text) |

ujjoveti  /  pa. jaMbuddIve NaM bhaMte! dIve sUriyA kiM tIyaM khettaM ujoveMti
paDuppannaM khettaM ujjoveMti, aNAgayaM khettaM ujjoveMti ? u. goyamA! no tIye
khettaM ujoveMti, paDuppannaM khettaM ujjoveMti, no aNAgayaM khettaM ujoveMti,
evaM taveMti, evaM bhAsaMti jAva niyamA chaddisiM bhaasNti| _jaMbuddIve
sUriyANaM tAva khettaM pamANaM - viyA. sa.8, u.8,su. 41-42 pa. jaMbuddIveNaM
bhaMte ! dIve sUriyA kevaiyaM khettaM uDDhaM tavaMti ? kevaiyaM khettaM ahe
tavaMti ? kevaiyaM khettaM tiriyaM tavaMti? u. goyamA! egaM joyaNasayaM uDDhaM
tavaMti, aTThArasajoyaNasayAI ahe tavaMti, sIyAlIsaM joyaNasahassAI doNNi
tevaDhe joyaNasae ekkavIsaM ca saTThibhAe joyaNassa tiriyaM tvNti| - viyA sa. 8,

##  Anadhyaya Kaal (Excerpt from Nandi Sutra, edited by Acharya Pravara Shri
Atmaramji Maharaj)  The study of scriptures should be done only during the time
prescribed in the Agamas for self-study.  Studying during the Anadhyaya Kaal is
prohibited.  The Manusmriti and other Smritis also describe Anadhyaya Kaal in
detail. Vedic people also mention the Anadhyayas of the Vedas. Similarly, other
Aarya Granthas are also considered Anadhyaya.  Since the Jain Agamas are
considered Sarvajnokt (spoken by the omniscient), Devaadhisthit (divine), and
Swaravidya (self-knowledge), their Anadhyaya Kaal is also mentioned in the
Agamas. For example:  **Ten Anadhyayas related to the sky:**  1.  Ukkavaate
(meteor shower): If there is a large meteor shower, one should not study
scriptures for one prahar (3 hours).  **Ten Anadhyayas related to the body:**
1.  Atthi (bone):  One should not study scriptures when a bone is broken.
**Four Mahapratipada (major festivals):**  1.  Ashadha Padivaa 2.  Inda
Mahapadivaa 3.  Katta Padivaa 4.  Sugimha Padivaa  **Four Mahapratipada Purnima
(full moon days of major festivals):**  1.  Ashadha Padivaa Purnima 2.  Inda
Mahapadivaa Purnima 3.  Katta Padivaa Purnima 4.  Sugimha Padivaa Purnima
**Four Sandhya (twilight times):**  1.  Pradimate (dawn) 2.  Pachchimaate
(sunset) 3.  Majjhane (noon) 4.  Addharatte (midnight)  **Four Kaal (times):**
1.  Puvvane (morning) 2.  Avarane (afternoon) 3.  Paose (evening) 4.  Pacchuse
(night)  According to the above Sutrapath, there are 32 Anadhyayas, which are
divided into ten related to the sky, ten related to the body, four
Mahapratipada, four Mahapratipada Purnima, and four Sandhya.  These are briefly
described as follows:  **Ten Anadhyayas related to the sky:**  1.  Ukkavaate
(meteor shower): If there is a large meteor shower, one should not study
scriptures for one prahar (3 hours).

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

anya ArSa granthoM kA bhI anadhyAya mAnA jAtA hai| jainAgama bhI sarvajJokta,

Page #292 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):

##  [Chapter of Non-Study] [241]  2. **Digdaha** -  One should not study when
the direction appears to be filled with fire, i.e., when the direction appears
blood-red. 3. **Garjit** - One should not study for one prahar (3 hours) after
the thunder of clouds. 4. **Vidhyut** - One should not study for one prahar
after lightning. However, the non-study period due to thunder and lightning
should not be considered during Chaturmas (four months of the rainy season).
This is because thunder and lightning are often a natural occurrence during this
season. Therefore, non-study is not considered from Ardra to Swati Nakshatra
(constellations). 5. **Nirghat** - When there is a loud roar in the sky without
clouds, or when there is thunder with clouds, there is a non-study period of two
prahar. 6. **Yupaka** - In the Shukla Paksha (bright fortnight), the meeting of
the evening glow and the moonlight on the first, second, and third days is
called Yupaka. One should not study during these days until the night. 7.
**Yakshadipt** - When there is a light in a direction that appears like
lightning, but occurs intermittently, it is called Yakshadipt. One should not
study until the light in the sky disappears. 8. **Dhumika-Krishna** - The time
from Kartik to Magh (October-February) is the time of clouds. During this time,
a fine mist of water with a smoky color falls. This is called Dhumika-Krishna.
One should not study until this mist disappears. 9. **Mihika-Shweta** - In
winter, a fine mist of water with a white color falls. This is called Mihika.
One should not study until this mist disappears. 10. **Raj-Udghāt** - Due to
wind, dust spreads all around in the sky. One should not study until this dust
settles.  The above ten reasons are related to the sky. The following ten
reasons are related to the body.  11-12-13. **Haddi, Mans, and Rudhir** - If the
bones, flesh, and blood of a five-sensed animal are visible, one should not
study until these things are removed from there. The commentator considers non-
study for 60 hands (approximately 100 feet) around these things.  Similarly,
non-study is considered for bones, flesh, and blood of humans. The difference is
that the non-study period for these is 100 hands and one day and night. The non-
study period for a woman's menstrual cycle is three days. The non-study period
for the birth of a boy and a girl is seven and eight days respectively.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

Page #293 (AI-GENERATED, RESEARCH USE ONLY):
---------------------------
##  [242] [Surya Prajnapti Sutra]  **14. Impurity:**  Asvadhyaya (study) is
prohibited until the appearance of excrement and urine.  **15. Cremation
Ground:** Asvadhyaya is prohibited within a hundred cubits (hastas) around a
cremation ground.  **16. Lunar Eclipse:** During a lunar eclipse, Asvadhyaya
should not be performed for eight praharas (a unit of time) for the lowest
category, twelve praharas for the middle category, and sixteen praharas for the
highest category.  **17. Solar Eclipse:** During a solar eclipse, Asvadhyaya is
also prohibited for eight, twelve, and sixteen praharas respectively.  **18.
Demise:** When a great king or a national leader passes away, Asvadhyaya should
not be performed until their cremation. Alternatively, Asvadhyaya should be
gradually resumed until a new authority takes over.  **19. Royal Conflict:**
When neighboring kings engage in war, Asvadhyaya should be prohibited until
peace is restored. Even after peace is established, Asvadhyaya should be avoided
for one day and night.  **20. Noble Body:** When a five-sense being dies within
an Upashraya (Jain temple), Asvadhyaya should be prohibited until the body is
removed. If the lifeless body remains within a hundred cubits, Asvadhyaya should
be avoided.  The above ten reasons for Asvadhyaya are related to the noble body.
**21-28. Four Festivals and Four Mahapratipada:** The four festivals are Ashadha
Purnima, Ashwin Purnima, Kartik Purnima, and Chaitra Purnima. The pratipada
(first day) following these full moons is called Mahapratipada. Asvadhyaya is
prohibited during these periods.  **29-32. Morning, Evening, Midday, and
Midnight:** Asvadhyaya should be avoided one ghari (a unit of time) before and
after sunrise, one ghari before and after sunset, one ghari before and after
midday, and one ghari before and after midnight.

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================

sAmane dikhAI dene taka asvAdhyAya hai| 15. zmazAna - zmazAnabhUmi ke cAroM ora

======================
| Romanization (original text) |
======================
Agama prakAzana samiti, byAvara dvArA prakAzita Agama-sUtra nAma anuvAdaka-
sampAdaka AcArAMgasUtra [do bhAga zrI candra surAnA 'kamala' upAsakadazAMgasUtra
DaoN. chaganalAla zAstrI (ema. e. pI-eca. DI.) jJAtAdharmakathAMgasUtra paM.
zobhAcandra bhArilla ankRddazAMgasUtra sAdhvI divyaprabhA (ema. e., pI-eca. DI)
anuttarovavAiyasUtra sAdhvI muktiprabhA (ema. e., pI-eca. DI) sthAnAMgasUtra
paM. hIrAlAla zAstrI samavAyAMgasUtra paM. hIrAlAla zAstrI sUtrakRtAMgasUtra zrI
candra surAnA 'surANA' vipAkasUtra anu. paM. rozanalAla zAstrI sampA, paM.
zobhAcanda bhArilla nandIsUtra anu. sAdhvI umarAvakuMvara 'arcanA' sampA. kamalA
jaina 'jIjI' ema. e. aupapAtikasUtra DaoN. chaganalAla zAstrI
vyAkhyAprajJaptisUtra [cAra bhAga] zrI amaramuni rAjapraznIyasUtra vANIbhUSaNa
ratanamuni, saM. devakumAra jaina prajJApanAsUtra [tIna bhAga] jainabhUSaNa
jJAnamuni praznavyAkaraNasUtra anu. muni pravINaRSi sampA, paM. zobhAcandra
bhArilla uttarAdhyayanasUtra zrI rAjendramuni zAstrI nirayAvalikAsUtra zrI
devakumAra jaina dazavaikAlikasUtra mahAsatI puSpavatI AvazyakasUtra mahAsatI
suprabhA (ema. e. pIeca. DI.) jambUdvIpaprajJaptisUtra DaoN. chaganalAla zAstrI
anuyogadvArasUtra upAdhyAya zrI kevalamuni, saM. devakumAra jaina,
sUryaprajJapti, candraprajJaptisUtra sampA. muni zrI kanhaiyAlAlajI 'kamala'
jIvAjIvAbhigamasUtra [do bhAga] zrI rAjendra muni nizIthasUtra munizrI
kanhaiyAlAla jI 'kamala', zrI tilokamuni trINichedasUtrANi munizrI kanhaiyAlAla
jI 'kamala', zrI tilokamuni zrI kalpasUtra (patrAkAra) upAdhyAya muni zrI
pyAracaMda jI mahArAja zrI antakRddazAMgasUtra (patrAkAra) upAdhyAya muni zrI
pyAracaMdajI mahArAja vizeSa jAnakArI ke liye samparkasUtra Agama prakAzana
samiti zrI braja-madhukara smRti bhavana, pIpaliyA bAjAra, byAvara-305901 di
DAyamaNDa jubilI presa, ajamera 9431898
